description: I love this place. My whole family loves this place. This is our family birthday spot.  We've been having birthdays for our 70yr old to our 2 yr old for years. The food is delicious and the service is great. Great music. Dancing. Cant go wrong.
author: Queen N.

description: Nice place. Good food and service )
author: Alexander B.

description:
**Review is about dining**

Felt adventurous and decided to try food that I never tried before! I've never had Senegalese food before, but I'm glad I found this place.

My friend and I got the fried plantain appetizer (sorry, can't remember the name). It came with a yogurt dipping sauce. I normally do not like plantains, but this stuff was GOOOOD. I wanted to eat the whole plate to myself but of course, sharing is caring. 

For my main dish, I got the Risa Au Cari with chicken which came with red curry, potatoes, carrots, etc. I got it with rice but next time I'm going to try couscous instead. The curry was not too thick and not too watery, which I like! The flavor was delicious. The chicken was cooked perfectly and fell off the bone when I tried to separate the meat and the bone with my fork.

I can't wait to try the rest of their dishes next time!
author: Julian Y.

description: My friend and I came here for dinner at 9:15, ordered just in time (since they close the kitchen at 9:30), and stayed until the dance floor opened at 10. We got 3 appetizers, an entrée, and a couple of delicious delicious cocktails. Aloko: fried plantains; Avocat Creole: avocado, tuna, and fries; Baobab Gambas: shrimp in sauce with pita; and Seafood Coco: tilapia goodness. Any drinks with ginger are amazing--their cocktails will not disappoint! The dancing was fun too, since the music was just so happy! :)
author: Helen K.

description:
Amazing happy hour! $4 cocktails, plus a great deal that includes 1 drink, 1 app and 1 entree for $20! 

Awesome place. I only had a chance to try the plantains which were delicious but I would love to come back and try the other food!
author: Ilana B.

description:
I have had this spot bookmarked for some time and was sad it was short of my expectations. We were looking forward to live music. Not sure why there wasn't any live music that evening. It's a bit snug and dark indoors. Without live music, it just felt warm & stuffy and made me sleepy. Food wise, it was ok. 

Must order: 
Yassa, the mustard taste in the food actually went really well with the dish. 

Less memorable dishes:
- Infused Coconut Rum: way too sweet, I couldn't finish my drink 

- Aloko: for appetizer the ripe plantains were way too sweet. We left it to the side to eat after our meal. Actually, we kept dipping the Aloko with leftover mustard sauce from the Yassa dish

- Mafe: I was most excited about this dish after seeing all the reviews and pictures. It was very salty
author: Ruby C.

description:
What a gem!

I have not eaten here but the late night vibes are unparalleled. Expect high spirited dance parties with live bongos and Caribbean/ R&B tracks. 

I always have fun here with a group of friends. It is my favorite place to go in the Mission.
author: Tara N.

description:
So much excitement, but failed so hard.

In other words, this place is WHACK.

So this is how it goes down there; it's a restaurant up until 10pm on weekends, and then becomes a club and has a straight up dance floor. That's cool and all, but I was here for dinner. It legit took an hour to get our food after ordering. It seemed like they were struggling to get their orders out, because the cute waitress was apologizing to the table behind us about their order. The food was cold on top of that, not sure if fried yuca is supposed to be cold, but I have a hunch it's not. Maybe I just caught them on a bad night, but I'm only coming back to get the cute waitress's number (HAH, jk). Eleni Yasmin, you're fine, but I'm sure you know that already. Hahaha

In summary:

Service: 0 (SLOW and inattentive)
Food: 0 (COLD)
Wild Card: hella cute waitress and chill busboy (+1)
author: Aaron C.

description: Tiny, dirty & over priced, that was my experience on a Sunday night. The restaurant is located in a not so trendy part of San Francisco and really not worth going unless there is a band playing.
author: Aditya J.

description:
Not great if u are in a rush... Or in a large group. We were a party of 11-12 and were glad they accomodated us. Then it took about 20 min for a waitress to come. 

The food was tasty and drinks are great.  The bill was almost impossible to split bc all the itemized things were listed as a zero for price bc of their specials.

Loved the live music and vibe tho!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Second time I am writing this review as it was somehow scrubbed from yelp. 

Terrible experience. Rude staff which scammed me and my friends. Was made to feel intimidated and yelled at by staff when I tried to get refund upon walking in and seeing how crazy it was inside. 

Really felt bullied and scammed. Too crowded and dangerous. Every time I have come previously at least someone I know gets their phone or cards stolen. Management is very unethical and rude. Go somewhere else.
author: Valery N.

description:
SURPRISINGLY THAT GOOD!!! OH MY!!!
(5 stars)

Senegalese? Senegal? Africa!!! There is a first for everything... it was such a HIT.

- FOOD, amazingly good
- PRICES, affordable
- SERVICE, fast
- AMBIANCE, reminds me of a Caribbean place but not really

Where do I begin?
I've always wondered about this place. It is a "hipster" joint BUT IT IS A VERY WORTHY HIPSTER JOINT. Every Tuesday night there is something happening and this evening they had dancing and drumming. Place gets very packed and we got a table. Great menu, alcoholic drinks are cheaper then regular drinks, and there's happy hour specials on the food. 

HEFER STATS.

We stayed with the happy hour food special (1 cocktail, 1 appetizer, and 1 main dish) for $20... worth it and you will be leaving STUFFED. Check-in with yelp and you get free Aloko.

(1) ALOKO - Ripe plantains fried to perfection and served with our handmade tamarind yogurt dipping sauce. This was pretty good, that handmade tamarind sauce put the good sweet factor on top of the plantains.

(2) BAOBAB GAMBAS - Sauteed prawns marinated in garlic and cayenne pepper, served in a red curry with pita bread. CRACKING!!! OMG SO GOOD!!! It came with pieces of flatbread. If you think chachacha's gambas are good, you really have no idea about Baobab Gambas. One of the best gambas I've ever had. I couldn't get enough of this. I like to call this GAMBAS IN CRACK SAUCE, so addicting and delicious. We wrapped up dinner a couple hours ago and I'm still sprung on it.

(3) MAFE - Chicken, sauteed mushrooms, onions, tomatoes, and spinach served in a curry peanut sauce. This was very nice. The chicken was fall off the bone good and the sauce reminded me of a Filipino dish called KareKare. It had a nice peanut flavor, at first the heat isn't there but after half way you will start to feel some heat. ITS SO GOOD!!!! 

(4) TATU - hibiscus margarita. Nothing margarita about this drink at all. It tasted like spiked hibiscus juice!!!! 

(5) PITCHER OF SORANGE - i think thats the drink. We shared a pitcher, enjoyed each others company, and some music. I think i like this drink better then the Tatu.

After dinner we were able to watch the performances of drummers and dancers. Pretty fun for a Tuesday. 

Will I be back? You don't have to ask me twice.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
Senegal.

Well, we all know how my geography is. I thought Cancun was in the United States so naturally, I thought Senegal was in Spain. Why? Because "Senegal, Spain" had a nice ring to it. I then remember that I confused that with Portugal.

Umm yah, I wouldn't last a day much less a round on the Amazing Race. =/

Anyhow, Senegalese cuisine is like Afro-Caribbean cuisine; where most meat and veggies dishes are stewed then poured over rice or couscous. Bissap Baobab and Little Baobab are the only restaurants in SF that serve Senegalese cuisine. They're actually two places in one as Bassip Baobab (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bissap-baobab-san-francisco) is inside Little Baobab. Both serve the same food but Bassip has late night live music performances while Little Baobab turns into a club after dinner.

Little Baobab is one funky place; it's divey, loud, hot, and kitschy. Not an ideal place to bring a date because there's just too much going on (i.e annoying flashing lights) that it's distracting to even maintain a convo, however, it's a cool place to check out once as it showcases the vast diversity of the city. 

Little Baobab offers numerous deals. From their everyday happy hour menu: http://bit.ly/17xI6Yj and 1 app, 1 entrée, and 1 house cocktail for $20 before 7 pm to their 30% off your entire dinner bill (including drinks) if you book a reservation on Savored.com. Looks like they also have a Yelp deal and my friend told me they have a Bloomspot deal as well. Make sure to take advantage of these if you come. Had it not been for the Savored.com deal, this would be a 2 star review. As a a side note, there seems to be a lot of sketchy 5 star reviews. 

Overall the food and drinks were about 3.5. The much raved about Tatu: Hibiscus Margarita ($7): http://bit.ly/1038Auk was way too strong but the Coconut Infused Rum ($7): http://bit.ly/18cPXvv was deliciously creamy. If it wasn't a Sunday night, I would have gotten a pitcher all for myself. 

The Avocat Creole ($8.75): http://bit.ly/130czNG was canned tuna with spicy mayo NOT crab (they should update their menu to reflect this since some people are allergic to fish). The accompanying yucca fries were hard and stale. I would skip this app. For my entrée, I order the Mafe w/ Chicken in a Peanut Sauce & Couscous ($11.75): http://bit.ly/11VI8qM which was delicious. The chicken drumsticks were stewed to a fall-off-the-bone tenderness with a decadently creamy peanut sauce that I slathered all over the couscous before devouring. It was one satisfying dish. 

Service was a whole other story though. 

For a 15 year old restaurant, they sure operate like a rookie. Service was like watching paint dry on the wall.

6:50 pm: Arrived for our 7 pm reservations.
6:55 pm: Ordered drinks.
7:10 pm: Ordered one appetizer while waiting for our friend to arrive.
7:15 pm: Ordered two more appetizers and entrees.
7:35 pm: Asked waitress for an update on our apps.
7:45 pm: After a 35 min wait, the wrong app was brought (ordered yucca fries but received chips and guacamole).
7:55 pm: Second app (Avocat Creole) arrived and we ask what happened to the third app.
8:05 pm: We were told they ran out of shrimp which was why they couldn't make the third app. It took 50 minutes to figure out they ran out of shrimp?!?
8:06 pm: Entrees arrived 50 minutes after ordering. 

Most of the dishes are stews which means its pre-made or at least semi pre-made so it should NOT take 50 minutes to get your food....on a Sunday night...at a less than half full restaurant. 

Our waitress was super sweet and apologetic about the wait and comped the apps (thank you). We later found out it was her first day so we can't fault her. Instead, the owner/manager who was making cocktails for his friends at the bar should have been overseeing his staff especially new wait staff. Instead of socializing, he could of helped the kitchen and waitresses to ensure the food arrives to customers before the paint on the walls dry.

A good restaurant doesn't need to offer deals to attract business especially not simultaneous deals. Although dinner was cheap with the Savored.com deal, you get what you pay for at Little Baobab. A lot of wasted time.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
So I had a groupon or living social (I forget which one) for a while and when I finally remembered- it was the day it was due to expire! I went wit two of my sisters. It was also Happy Hour. The deal was for two- Pitcher of your choice of their signature cocktails. I want to be clear that they fill their pitch to the rim! the waitress almost spilled some lol by the way, that is a good problem. It also came with a shared appetizer- we got the yummy guacamole with the yucca fries instead of the tortilla chips and boy did we make the BEST decision that night. Yucca fries are a root veggie like potatoes, same texture but heavier.. delicious! Oh, we both got an entree. I ordered the coconut shrimp and fish curry, to die for! My sister got only shrimp curry. My other sister for the Happy Hour deal that consisted of a drink, appetizer and a entree.

I will def. return soon for live music and dancing. I hear it's pretty pack but enjoyable.
author: Drea W.

description: Came in for midnight pizza - demolished a medium between 2 ppl.  The baobab yassa was _delicious_.  Will be back to try the new seafood and peanut butter sauce based pizzas when they come out!
author: Robby H.

description: Yum Yum Yum!!! It was my first time trying any african food and it was so delicious. Having an indian palette, I love anything heavily spiced and Baobab did not disappoint. Being vegetarian, we ordered the Mafe and the dibi. One word of advice.. always order the couscous. Its so good! The dibi came with plantains and they were so good. We also had the little baobab drink and the sorange. Both the drinks had tamarind in it. We were a little skeptical about that, but it turned out great! We had the banana flambee for desert, which was a little sweet for my taste buds but my husband loved it! Definitely coming back!
author: Ashmita V.

description: I attempted to go back to Baobab last night because my friend loves the night life there. We waited in line for about 15 min. At around a little past 12 the security at door yelled out that it was $15 to get inside. I asked why. He said there was a special event. I asked what that special event was and he couldn't give me an answer. If this isn't due to the vast amount of people behind us who were willing to pay the $15 dollars then idk the reason for the price hike. It's not worth it.
author: Brenda S.

description: Haven't had the food here but came for some late night grooves. It was recommended by my friend and I can see why it's very popular! They play a mix of Caribbean, reggae, and some other dance tunes. I loved the chill and fun vibe of the place! Mixed crowd and it was a grand old time! I would definitely check it out again!
author: Natalie M.

description:
This place was delicious! I loved all the food I tried, and the honey wine is incredible! 

It's a small restaurant, but a cool location. The patio is dog friendly, which is nice. 

The staff and owner are all really knowledgable and super nice. I had a great experience and would definitely go back!
author: Hayley F.

description: I cannot say enough about how great this place is. My lady friend and I went here for dinner after realizing that neither of us knew what Senegalese food is. It's amazing is what it is. The aloko (plantain chips) were beyond anything we had imagined, and both of our dishes (and, I imagine, anything on the menu) were some of the best food either of us had ever had.
author: Des H.

description: Great for dancing! Love the music here a mix of a lot of cultures and diverse crowd. I shall try the food soon!
author: Piarpreet K.

description: Love the food. Had a big group of people and everything went according to plan. Food came on time. Drinks were awesome. Had the tamarind margarita. A little strong, but was good. Service and host were nice.
author: Kat N.

description:
This review is only for the dance club/nightlife. 

It's with great sadness that I write a two star review for Little Baobab. For the past four years, Little Baobab was my absolute favorite place to go dancing in the city. It had an amazing vibe: good Caribbean/African music, chill people looking to dance without inhibitions, People of Color (POC) having drinks and enjoying the night in community.... but the scene is no longer that way. 

My past few visits have made me realize that the Little Baobab I knew and loved no longer exists; it has become a victim of it's own success. Little Boabab has become extremely crowded on Friday and Saturday nights. They've expanded the venue and it is still bursting at the seams; there is simply no space to move around. The crowd has changed as well. Last night as I was struggling to dance without getting hit, I saw that the majority of people dancing with clueless vigor were mostly white hipsters and yuppies. The usually energetic African and Black dancers were standing to the sides just watching, maybe they were feeling what I was feeling: displaced in my favorite spot in the city. 

The vibe has changed. No longer is it a small, familiar, and safe place for a night of dancing and flirtation. Girls were getting catty in the line for the bathroom and the bartenders looked stressed out. Usually ones to close the night out at Little Baobab, we left early last night, disappointed. 

If you want taste of the Little Baobab of the past, head over to the new and still cozy/genuine Baobab in Oakland before the masses find it and turn it into a mainstream club as well.
author: Krithika H.

description:
All I can start with is..
Awesome food and really interesting cocktails! Having tried no other Senegalese restaurants before, I'm already pretty sure that this one's always gonna be pretty high up and other places (if I ever try one outside of Little Baobab) will have live up to this one. 

Food: Good appetizers. Try the Somone if you like something fried. Perfect for a cold rainy evening (El nino). For the entrees, Mafe is a straight forward choice. Most of the pictures on yelp are Mafe. Even the Seafood Coco was good, although a little sweet for my taste. Will get it spiced up a notch next time.

Drinks: Excellent! Everything from Hot Ginger (non-alcoholic) to the interesting cocktails are awesome! Slightly expensive at 10$ each... but they have happy hour everyday... :) Try the Sedem! that was my favorite along with Hot Ginger!

Great food, great drinks and great service, coupled with a cozy-rustic ambience, gets this place 5 stars from me..!
author: Vikram C.

description: the food here is SOOOOOO good. the lamb doesn't taste gamey at all and is very tender. their happy hour special is absolutely killer: an appetizer, main dish and drink for $20!!! their drinks are pretty stiff too. i had only been here for drinks before but always wanted to try their food. this place will definitely become a staple for me and any friends i have visiting from out of town!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
So in love with this place. Great environment and friendly service. I enjoyed every dish and can't wait to come back for more.

Aloko is their fried plantain. The description says it's served with a yogurt  sauce but I thought it's more like a vinaigrette. I preferred a heavier yogurt base in the sauce, but still good. 

Pastellas with beef: Carbs and Protein are my absolute favorite! This reminded me of an empanada except it's served in a sauce which was delicious.

Baobab Gambas: Shrimp in red curry  sauced served with pita bread. I am so happy they have this dish. All I needed was a scoop of rice and a spoon.

My favorite dish here is the Seafood CoCo with Talapia. The Talapia is skewered on a bamboo stick, seared to perfection and served in a coconut curry sauce with rice. BOMB! My fiancé couldn't stop pointing at the dish with his fork after each bite. The rice is a bit dry so make sure you mix it into the curry to soak up that flavor.

We also ordered the Chicken Mafe. Its drumsticks braised in a peanut based curry sauce. The chicken was soft and fell off the bone. The description says peanut curry, so expect a very strong peanut base. I don't mind peanuts, but this was a bit much for me.

The hibiscus juice was a popular item on yelp so we ordered a regular hibiscus and ginger hibiscus. It was refreshing, but not worth the $3.50 price tag.

Lastly we had the Thiakry for dessert. I didn't like this. It reminded me of tapioca balls or oatmeal in hot milk.

I'm so glad I finally stopped here after book marking it for so long.
author: Charisa N.

description:
Love love love this place! Went here with a discount offer when I lived in San Francisco but there is really no need for discounts to get me to eat here! 

I had the seafood Coco and it was amazing. Cocktails were also delicious. 

Highly recommended...sad I didn't get to go here again before moving back to the east coast.
author: Janelle G.

description:
Officially my new favorite place in the Mission. I went on a Saturday night to dance. The crowd was a lot of fun. It felt like good unadulterated fun. It's a nice change from the typical club scene.

However, I'm making a plan to come back for dinner and drinks because that looked just as good too
author: Katherine D.

description: An amazing little restaurant that will introduce you to the wondrous cuisine of Senegal! Eleni is the best waitress and hostess in the world, I love her and will come again just to see her. Best dish is the lamb Dibi and the tuna appetizer. The fried bananas are really yummy too :). Came with a few best friends from college and the entire place is full of love and good food. A favorite in San Francisco mission district
author: Kristin C.

description:
It's been years since I've been to Little Baobob.

I used to go for the beats and sweaty rowdy dancing.

This past week I visited with my friend for their food (since their main restaurant location closed down awhile back - Little Baobob has put an increased emphasis on their cuisine)

Though the company was amazing - I wasn't blown away by the food.

The yucca frites and guacamole weren't very memorable. The yucca fries were thin and the guacamole lacked oomph

For my entree I ordered the tilapia in a coconut sauce with rice. The sauce was quite lovely (it's hard to mess up coconut sauce) and I enjoyed the rice. The tilapia was OK.

They were unfortunately out of their chocolate cake for dessert so we went with the banana flambe. It was a massive portion and while it was definitely delicious - it was swimming in butter - so both of us - proceeded with caution. 

Our server was extremely attentive and the portions were solid - but I don't think I'll rush back to Little Baobob anytime soon for the food. 

But I am so thankful for my amazing friend for reintroducing me to this place.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
It's unique. It's affordable. It's popular. But...it's a little over-rated. 

Some of my most fun & interesting friends are Baobab devotees. They praise the laid-back, unpretentious, multi-cultural vibe. They swear by the sweaty, bass-heavy dance floor sessions and the cheap tropical drinks. It all sounds so promising. 

We checked it out on a Friday night, but were disappointed that the "world music" Baobab prides itself on, was really just a DJ. There were no actual musicians or instruments. It was just like any other club, only the DJ was playing some very un-danceable Latin music. I LOVE Reggaeton, but on this particular night, the music was just off. We felt old, and too sober. 

But, the coconut-rum cocktail was SO amazing (and worth a 2nd round at just $7), I'm tempted to return just for that. There's a dude making crepes in the front of the club, and has his own little dance party going on behind the counter. The cover is $5 for girls, $10 for guys, and the male:female ratio was pretty 50/50, despite the unfair price difference. 

It's totally A-OK: not douchey, very casual, and has potential for fun depending on your mood & level of intoxication. If you're thinking of checking it out, at least you can enjoy one of the best coconut drinks in town if nothing else.
author: Nique F.

description:
Wow. I'm pleasantly surprised how good this place is. The space itself is a little dingy but food and drinks were great.

We had the coconut infused rum ($7) and little baobab ($7) drinks. They were sweet and not strong (the way I like them).

Avocat Creole ($8.75) - Was strange at first but as I keep eating it I didn't want it to end.
Mafe chicken ($11.75) - I can eat a bucket of this with rice!
Dibi tilapia ($13.75) - Was good as well but not as good as the mafe. The fish had a slight crisp on the outside and was seasoned well. I loved the salad dressing that the salad had.
Banana flambee ($6.25) - Sucked. 

Service was friendly. 

I would come back in a heartbeat for food and drinks. Skip dessert.
author: Andy W.

description:
3.5 stars.

A no frills kind of joint.  They aren't going to be winning awards for their food presentation, but the food is definitely flavorful and you will leave stuffed to the brim.  

We started with the avocat creole which consisted of a half avocado stuffed with spicy crab and rice salad served with a side of the yucca fries and the baobab gambas which were sautéed prawns served in a red curry.  Though both dishes were pretty good, they both were not very memorable and honestly sounded better than they actually were in my opinion.

For the mains we enjoyed the dibi, one lamb and one tilapia, which were both served with fried plantains, salad, and couscous.  These dishes were really flavorful and I would come back for these again without hesitation.

They also have an interesting drink menu but I would highly recommend the infused coconut rum.  Flavorful, smooth, and really worth a try even if you aren't a fan of rum.

We stuck around at the bar when they started converting the place into a club and enjoyed some live music and a little bit more of that addicting and slow creeping coconut rum.
author: Erich D.

description:
This review if for the afterparty/dancing not dinner 

baobab has a great atmosphere for relaxed non-clubby dancing. It starts at 10:00 technically but really gets going closer to maybe 11

Everyone just lets go and has a good time and the music is really fun. The vibe is very friendly and unpretentious and that seems to translate to everyone that's there 
Definitely gets pretty sweaty later on... But
Not necessarily in a bad way

Thematic decor is enjoyable too!
author: Alisha S.

description:
Delicious food, friendly servers, amazing cocktails, and oh so amazing music / dance scene!!

Get the spicy Senegalese chicken and black eyed peas dish. Everyone around the table agreed that's the best dish. 

Fried bananas were great as an appetizer.

The ginger hibiscus cocktail was sooooooo good. 

Highly recommend.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Tons of fun here on a Saturday night a few weeks back. Lots of fun! A good mixed crowd. Apparently they've expanded in the last few years. Decor is very "worldly". Here's a timeline of the night's progression:

~10pm - $5 cover. It's sparsely populated, a good African-sounding music going. Not many people dancing, mostly standing around and chatting. Easy to get to the bar - get their ginger cocktail - DELICIOUS! Plenty of room for my group to take liberty with the space and start dancing. Line for the TWO single bathrooms already long. I say: risk breaking the seal - go to the bathroom now before the line gets worse!!

~11pm - getting more crowded. Music definitely more top-40-esque. Get your drinks now - it's much more crowded up at the bar!

~midnight - the place is packed. It's HOT - like muggy, stuffy, not. Either bring a fan or grab one of those laminated dinner menus that might still be sitting around because you'll need it. Music - definitely Top 40s now, but they have a guy banging on an African drum so I guess that makes it like African music? Doesn't seem quite authentic but the music's still upbeat and fun to dance to. A few circles form around some good dancers.

~12:30am - I am old and lame and decide to walk the few blocks home. Given me a few years back and I would've stayed til closing - it honestly was a good time there - but I was just damn tired. My ears are ringing on the way back the music was so loud. 

I'll be back, for sure! To try their food too.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Tilapia, tilapia, tilapia from Senegal! Did I mention they have sautéed tilapia?? If that doesn't tickle your fancy already (though heavens to betsy, I don't know why it wouldn't...), you must also try their aloko: fried plantains with tamarind yogurt dipping sauce! Come here with a group, and be ready to try some new eats! Heck, you might even just dance! Awesome wall decor, might I add.

Barely off the main drag, but so glad it caught my eye!
author: Garett T.

description:
SIT-REP

I am often traveling in San Francisco for work and pleasure and on this occasion I have the great time of hooking up with my friends and fellow Yelpers, KIM and SUZANNE.  [In fact, you can blame KIM for getting me into YELP in the first place!]

Located in the MISSION District of San Francisco is this awesome find of a restaurant.  [We have to credit Suzanne for steering us in this direction!]

THE FARE

We were treated to a variety of tasty African dishes.  There was COCONUT SHRIMP with a delectable cream sauce.  There was a delicious MAFE Chicken Breast that was broiled with delicious spices.  And there was a LAMB CURRY that had an extremely elegant and delicious bouquet that treated ALL of our senses.

All these dishes were served on a choice of wild rice or couscous.  All of of it was absolutely delicious.  We started the meal with an incredible CRAB & AVOCADO appetizer.  We concluded the meal with a scrumptious chocolate cake and vanilla ice cream treat.

The server staff were extremely pleasant and helpful with our questions and our needs.  I love them.

THE LOWDOWN

If you want a truly unique African dish experience, I heartily recommend this very affordable, very delicious option!
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
Servers are amazingly friendly!! Food is DELICIOUS! And supercheap!  Very interesting for vegetarians, you can have almost everything in a veggie version. I wish I could cook like that!
Since I discovered this place, I go there several times a week.
I already ate the mafe with tofu (WOW! And an extra wow for 9.95$), and tilapia with a mustard/onion sauce.  Also delicious!  With every meal, you can choose whether you prefer rice or couscous, a nice addition!
And each sunday night, there's this girl playing songs with rotating bands.  Beautiful!  Not too loud and disturbing for a dinner, but very beautiful!
author: Joke D.

description:
Late night dancing club/bar:

A verrrrrrrrrrrrry interesting crowd. $5 cover. The music is all reggae type/reminds me of that one song in last Fast in the Furious in Brazil, Dominica Republic songish, Rihanna type reggae music. Small ass venue, they sure squeeze a lot of people in, but jamming! The bathroom was clogged and the attendant couldn't do anything about it. (Gross) Bleeh, lots of sweat... Very interesting place to go to, especially veering off from the usual Asian infested clubs.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Happy hour drinks are amazingly cheap. Try their cocktail "Little Baobab" which cost $4. I hear this tiny mini bar/ restaurant turns into a wild part if you stay late at one of their DJ nights.

I tried their Dibi chicken, it was 5 star (just like their mixed drink). The sauce was just the right spice, chicken tenderness was amazing. Thinking about the dish is making me drool. I also tried my friend's curry like dish and it also was fantastic.

The only issue was that we went with a group of 12+ and the restaurant is only able to split the bill into 3 separate bills. However the food and drinks def top this minor issue and I will keep coming back to Little Baobab every time I come to the bay.
author: Doriancita X.

description:
The pulsating African music, the packed bodies together, the Fat Albert lookailke working the door, and the banana concotion I drank made me fall in love with Little Baobab.

I was enthralled by the gyrating bodies and chaotic happiness that engulfed this place.  I didn't want to leave!  We came across Little Baobab by accident, after wandering around the Mission District during a vacation.  Whenever I visit something that isn't listed in Fodor's, or in the central tourist area (Union Square or the Wharf in this case), I feel that I've come across something really special.

Locals and tourists need to get down here FAST.
author: Angela P.

description:
True to its name, Little Baobab is smaller in space and portion. However, my experience here was much better than at its sister restaurant Baobab Bissap.

The restaurant itself was small, but surprisingly packed for a weeknight. Very casual place. Music playing from the DJ booth. 

Exotic Hummus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rHhuvw1szUJlz6VoeRhASQ?select=oK_T4pjtihx8S8bxj6xuyA): It was more flavorful than regular hummus, but does not live up to its name.

Crevette Coco (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rHhuvw1szUJlz6VoeRhASQ?select=KcS0l5IwY6E-YYwImLZEeQ): Sauteed shrimp in coconut sauce. Love the coconut sauce. So fragrant and delicious. Could've done without the overly salty potatoes on the side.

Mafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rHhuvw1szUJlz6VoeRhASQ?select=oKUd1WfDT_UnhJVbzZfpWA): Chicken breast in peanut sauce. Another delicious dish. The chicken was nicely grilled and smothered with the thick and delicious sauce. Yum!

Baked Salmon (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rHhuvw1szUJlz6VoeRhASQ?select=CX3U4rr7s_WY3w0EA43zCQ): It sounds a bit plain, but that's far from the truth. Baked in spinach leaves, the salmon was perfect. My overall impression of this dish: healthy yet bursting with flavors.

Another great girls dinner! =)
author: Marti L.

description: Just discovered this amazing dance spot in the Mission. Escape the stale Top 40 that blasts in most places and find something fresh with some great Afro-Caribbean beats. My new favorite place to go dancing in the city, with an impressive cocktail list as well.
author: Michael A.

description:
This place is amazing. Whenever different groups of friends want to "try something new" in the Mission, I bring them here for Senegalese food. Initially it seems exotic to first-timers, but they've never been disappointed, and neither have I.

I highly recommend the Aloko (plantains) to start, and the lamb Dibi (grilled lamb, yassa sauce, fried plantains, salad, and a choice of rice or cous cous) as your main course. As for the drinks, I enjoy the Infused Coconut Rum and the Tatu (hibiscus margarita). 

Little Baoab has wonderful staff. They're always friendly (though sometimes I feel they could use more help) and they chat if you seem open to it and the place isn't too packed. 

One of the best things? Little Baoab turns into a dance hall at night, and the music is lively. I went on a dinner date once here, and found myself being pulled into the dance floor by my boyfriend who rarely dances. The music is that good! They often have performances as well--on random visits, I've seen African drummers, flamenco dancers, and more. Love this place!
author: Patricia L.

description: I agree with the other reviewers here.  The food is an interesting diversion from the usual fare and the music experience at night is quite unique.  In a city full of options, this is one I plan to repeat.  The ginger hibiscus cocktail was an interesting experience.  You will have to judge for yourself if it suits your taste.
author: Scarlett O.

description:
Booked table for 10 for my husband's birthday. We had a great time! The whole place seemed to celebrate the birthday, not just our party of 10 people. Great place for dancing. Chill mood, everyone is happy, relaxed and throwing out moves. Not a glam nightclub. 
Great food.. The appetizers were really good and flavorful. Do order the plantains. The food was plated really well too. I wish SF baobab served the yummy wraps Oakland baobab does though, especially Yassa wrap.. yumm. They also have vegetarian and vegan options. 
The staff is really nice and warm, they join in dancing now and then. It's good how you can eat properly and then switch to dancing as they convert some of the dining area to a dance floor. Baobab does need to provide some air, ventilation/ air conditioning though, as it gets suffocating and hot with everyone dancing.
author: Malvika B.

description:
We were a group of 12 people celebrating a couple of birthdays wanting to dance after dinner and drinks, and this club hit the spot!

Calling it a club is kinda like an aberration as it's a tiny restaurant that converts into a dance floor, however, this is part of the charm as everyone just gets packed into the little space to groove to the music and being in a large group of familiar faces made it seem more intimate and fun. The music was awesome, everyone of us danced our hearts off! and as Vandana mentioned in her review there is nothing a woman needs to worry about in this club, you don't have to dress up, you dont have to eye men and play the charade, men will just shower you with attention and these are men that know how to groove, so all you need is an open mind and lots of energy ;)
author: Harsha G.

description: What a brilliant place for a dance! We went just before 10pm on a Saturday (so didn't have to pay the very reasonable 5$ cover charge) but this meant we had a chance to have a drink before the music/dancing started in earnest. The music was brilliant and the addition of a brilliant guy on a bongo drum was fantastic. It gets super super hot and crowded so be prepared! Drinks are reasonable with cocktails at 8$. Coat check was 2$.
author: Anya B.

description:
First off, it truly is disappointing reading the reviews and basically seeing how many people didn't even know the simple fact that Senegal is in Africa. If you're not going to know much about Africa, at least know some of the countries. Speaking of which NO Africa is NOT a country. There are COUNTRIES in that continent. Educate yourself, people. 

Anyways, went for the club night last night. I was hesitant at first because the guy who invited me made it sound like it was an african drumming place or something, like it was just performances going on. While I am all for watching performances, it's Friday night and I wanna get crunk! I wanted to dance club-style with dim lights lol so I'm glad I discovered that the guy just didn't really know what he was talking about (he's not black hahaha).

Good mix of reggae, dancehall, and other African music. I am all for the top 40-ish being mixed in. Top 40 is top 40 for a reason, I for one like hearing popular songs that are played on the radio played in the club. I don't like having to dance in the car only to good hits. That's the thing I hate about most SF clubs; too much EDM, electro and mash-ups when all I really wanna do is twerk like they do in videos! 

Apparently it's $10 after midnight? Should be only $5 still since it closes like hour and half later. Luckily it was worth the $10. Oh and they really should do something about that single use bathroom.
author: Marquis A.

description: Really fun place.  The infused coconut rum was very sweet and refreshing.  For dinner, I ordered Dibi with chicken.  Dibi is their lemon garlic mustard sauce along with plantains and couscous.  It was very tasty! I will definitely come again.
author: Luke R.

description:
Disclaimer: I have never had ANY type of African food before coming here, so I had to rely on purely my virgin taste buds during my visit here to Little Baobab. 

That being said, my taste buds were too busy jumping for joy to care much about any of my personal qualms about trying African food for the first time. I ordered myself the Baobao Gambas and a Pastelle. Both dishes were pretty amazing to be honest, felt like a mix between mexican and indian food. The Pastelle was actually my favorite, since it resembled a dish from my own Filipino culture, an empanada. My only gripe is portion size. I felt like I could have eaten about double what I had ordered.

The decor of the place is fantastic. Mood lighting with dashes and sprites of green, yellow, and red sprinkled throughout. The flags of all the African nations on the ceiling were my favorite touch. It really wouldn't be my scene at all, but I wouldn't mind coming here for one of the dance nights. Seems like a fun time!
author: Sean H.

description:
If you've never been to this place before, this is one of the best dance clubs in the city. This is without doubt my favorite dance club in the entire city.

The entire place is the size of a shoebox, it's about 140° inside, and you're surrounded by giant men all around. If you come here on a Friday or Saturday night, expects to dance to incredible hip-hop music that comes from Senegal and other parts of Africa. Chances are you probably have not heard most of the music they play, and the DJ does a great job of selecting music that's fun and easy to dance to.


If you come here on a Wednesday, be prepared to salsa dance with some incredibly talented dancers. I myself am mediocre at Salsa at best, and I'll admit it's a bit intimidating at times. But if you're a girl, and you love being thrown around the dance floor, then you will love the scene on Wednesday nights.


Don't come here if you're not prepared to be drenched with sweat by the time you leave at 2 o'clock in the morning. I've been here probably 30 times, and I've only had a bad experience once. Check this place out if you never been here before, you won't be disappointed.
author: Corelle N.

description:
Cute venue and decor. The place has an awesome, unique vibe to it. 

I got the sautéed tilapia in a spicy coconut curry. It was eh. Too coconut-y and creamy.
author: Margaret R.

description:
We didn't know what to expect from this joint. I didn't even know where Senegal was in Africa.  After eating there and experiencing Sengalese cuisine, it is in West Africa and one of the primary language is Francais.  C'est Bon! 

We had the seafood coco prawns, I loved the tangy sauce, not too thick and the spiciness texture was just perfect.  My GF had the Dibi Talapia. Her portion was more, mine had like 8 prawns.  I was still hungry after dinner. We ordered a potato appetizer, similar to a hush puppy with a tangy sauce. That was good too. 

We were served by a waitress who smiled a lot and was attentive although it was busy on Valentine's. Another known fact about Senegalese culture, hospitality should be well-reflected in their service. 

As for the dance scene, they took awhile to set up and clear out the tables for the dance floor and wait for people to finish dinner. We left before the  music and dancing. Until next time!  

We would definitely go back.
author: Pho K.

description:
Senegalese food
Served with a fun clubby vibe,
Exotic jungle.

Got Yassa Chicken,
Subtle mustard and lemon.
My taste buds happy.

Try unique cocktails.
Hibiscus, tamarind drinks.
Not too sweet. Lovely.

Dance club is next door.
Bissap where the party at.
Had door cover cost.

Appetizer and
Entree with house cocktail drink
Just twenty dollars.
Order from five to seven.
Must get here early next time
author: Jeanne L.

description: Unlikely I will ever go back. They filled the place at 2x capacity. Bathroom was broken, music twice as loud as necessary.  $10 cover for zero value. I guess People like the music/atmosphere...
author: Don W.

description:
Little Baobab is officially one of my favorite places to go for a night out now! We had a reservation for 8 people at 8:30 on a Saturday night, but we were running half an hour late; the staff was kind enough to hold our reservation for us. When we got there the place was packed, but they set us up in the separate room next door with our own bar, bartender, and dance floor! I've never come across such accommodating or genuinely friendly staff. After we finished dinner we went back to the main restaurant room and enjoyed a night of dancing.

The food was delicious (I got the mafe) and the drinks start at $5; you must try the ginger ale! The music was good and the people even better, come here to have an epic night out.
author: Ada C.

description:
This place is very reminiscent of a small restaurant I had the pleasure of eating at in Aruba. 

Quaint, friendly atmosphere. No frills. And absolutely delicious food. I love love love Afro-Caribbean cuisine, and this place hits it on the nose. The flavors of coconut, curry, delicate plantains, aromatic jasmine rice and tender fish dance around in your mouth.

If you have an addictive nature, you may want to stear clear--the food is that good ;-)
author: Shira O.

description: Everything here is so good, I can't recommend it enough. Think Caribbean African fusion: lots of coconut, rice, fish, and chicken with delicious flavors and spices. Incredible unique cocktails too, and great music. The perfect date night!
author: Katrina H.

description: Oh man, it's been well over a year, and I love the spaciousness of the venue now!  Nice segmentation of the dining area.  Still friendly service, and wonderful food.  My original review stands.  Thanks, Little Baobab.
author: Allison C.

description:
This East African gem is quite a delight, and provides a different scene than what you'd typically find in the Mission. After 10pm, the restaurant becomes a dance floor where you can break it down to a Eritrean beat. Music is obviously different from most places you go to, and makes me feel like I'm in a Sean Paul video, it gets everyone all sensual at some point but it's all part of the vibe.  

Checking in (with your Yelp app) lands you a complimentary, hibiscus house cocktail. 

On a scale from one to dutty wine, I would 100% recommend this to anyone looking for a scene change up without purchasing the airfare.
author: Kat L.

description:
I've got to say, for my first venture into Senegalese cuisine Little Baobab gave an awesome first impression!

My book club met here a couple of weeks ago and had an awesome time. We shared the Aloko (fried plantains) and loved how sweet the plantains were with the accompanying sauce. The pitcher of hibiscus margarita was also PLENTY for four people and really tasty.

I ordered the Riz au Cari with chicken and loved this recipe for curry chicken. The chicken was so tender it fell off the bone, and the spicy curry sauce was well balanced. One of my friends ordered the prawns and they had a lot of flavor to them as well. I also tried both the tofu and chicken mafe and was intrigued by the peanut sauce, which one of our friends who lived in Senegal for a time said was authentic. 

This will definitely be on my radar the next time we are in the Mission and looking for something different.
author: Liz G.

description: Great food and even better ambiance! If you are into Caribbean food along with some live performance; don't mind the squeaking tables and chairs, this is a place you should go. Service may be a little slow. But if you are not in a rush, a great time during dinner is guaranteed!
author: Yina M.

description:
Missed out on the very tasty cocktails this time as we'd been drinking wine all day (er, tasting - don't let that color the review), but we were very happy with our meal, which started with an assortment of appetizers:

Aloko (ripe plantains) - Great, bite-sized!
Sweet Potato Fries - Really oily but really good
Yucca fries - Tasted like fries
Chips and Guacamole - Fresh guac

And for my entree, Riz au Cari - Lamb in Red curry sauce
In a word, hearty! Loved the red curry sauce, loved the hot sauce they gave us on the side, and loved the lamb, though I think some might find it a bit too mutton-y, which was A-OK with me. 

The environment was chill and friendly - a great place to relax with a group after a long, arduous day of consuming alcohol.
author: John M.

description: Always a good time at this place! I love the authenticity. I would recommend going on the early side, as the dance floor does fill up quickly. It also gets very hot, so if you plan on moving (and the music will leave you with no choice ), wear something light. The last Friday of the month, my favorite band plays live! Try and go then if you can!
author: Alexa H.

description:
Little Baobab is Bissap's little brother, just around the corner from the big guy. Very intimate and cool, lots of delicious spices and local music; Senegalese food is a unique mix of African and Island style cooking - your best bet is to shred your inhibitions and ask your server what they recommend. 

You can tell the spice routes cut directly through this place on their way to the Americas as it is the most Eastern point in Africa and the rich flavors of the food bear it out. Go early before the dance music gets turned up and the floor fills with Senegalese regional and dance music.
author: Rob K.

description:
I was here for a friend's birthday party.  The food was not all that great  - I had a hummus appetizer, which was a little different from what you'd expect from a  Mediterranean spot with the addition of some unique spices... I had a spicy lamb dish with spinach, which was okay - the lamb was tender and had some pretty good flavor, but nothing amazing.  The couscous that arrived with it was awful - it really tasted like cardboard.  The one highlight was the drink I ordered - a Passion Fruit/Tamarind/Vodka drink that was great - it had the perfect amount of sweetness.  I also tried their famous banana margarita drink, which was also pretty good.  

The place is divey and if you are looking for a casual evening, this spot is probably fine.  The place turns into a very small "club" at night and they play "world" music including styles popular in Brazil, Mexico and the Caribbean...the music was okay, but the venue is small and dirty.  This is very much a "Mission-type" of divey spot so one should go there with those expectations.  I would not come back for the food, but perhaps for a drink or two before going elsewhere.
author: Ken G.

description:
Bouncers are super dismissive and rude. Refused to break my girlfriend's $20 for the $5 cover even though he had a fist full of cash in his hand.

I've always had a good time dancing here mingling with the international crowd, while sipping on tropical drinks. But this experience left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Meaza S.

description: Great food. Great atmosphere. Fun place to go dancing!!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
In Senegal there is zero confusion about what would be considered the national dish.  It is called Theibu Jen, which means rice with fish, and the locals eat it several times per week at least.  For some reason they only offer it on the weekends or if you order 6 or more plates.  I don't really know how you can even call yourself a senegalese restaurant and not have theibu jen!!!
While there are a few other authentic items available, I did not find the food particularly tasty.  Adequate but not great,  and certainly overpriced.
author: Jess H.

description: Fantastic place to dance!! Cumbia dancing, salsa dancing, anything with the hips! A lot of really cute girls who know how to dance. It gets very crowded and my straightened hair became frizzy in no time. Worth it. Coming again for sure.
author: Joanna C.

description:
Great service
Great food - try the house special fish
Great ambiance
Try the Aloko (fried bananas)
author: Raul P.

description: Had the pastalles and mafe with chicken. Very tasty, chicken super tender, good portions. Cool vibe from the place. Service was pretty slow.
author: Salman A.

description:
One of the best places in SF for tasty drinks and a fun, sweaty dance party. 

The crowd and dance skill level is always so diverse, and everyone is just there to have fun. Its the only place that I have found Zouk music in the city. 
Dancing gets started around 10:30...
author: Genevieve D.

description:
It was great for a dinner date with a nice vibe on a Thursday evening. The food was good and very different from other types of cuisine. The staff were really friendly even though we very slowly progressed through our meal. 

There was some construction going on outside and a fair amount of noise from the bar/other patrons but neither was so bad that we couldn't carry on a nice conversation. The only particularly bad thing was that near the bar it smelled bad because it is clearly a bar where people party hard sometimes and that means vomit (which sadly was not well cleaned up).
author: Stephen S.

description: One of the best pure, unadulterated, "normal" dance clubs in SF. No pretense, dress code or concern - except vibing to jams. The chicks dig it, and the minimal cover is well worth it.
author: Chris B.

description:
This place is the "anti-club".

Don't come here to check out girls, scope out the scene or just sit around. This is the place to come if you like to dance. 

I remember coming here with friend as last minute thing after we left some crappy club that wanted $20. Fuck that.

I've actually been here for the restaurant AND the "club" part afterwards. 

The space is TINY, but the music and people make up for it. 

The cover is usually around $3-$6

Let's be honest - it's mostly music I have never heard of, but I'm cool with that. You can't NOT dance here. The music really moves you, and I am not much of a dancer. 

I love their drinks. They have drinks with tamarind, pomegranate and other fruits that you don't usually see. Best part - they're cheap. I average about $6 per drink here (as opposed to $10 at most places I go to).

It gets hot as hell in there and it cracks me up when people rush over to the fans. 

The people are there to dance. While most places have smarmy guys hitting on anything with a pulse I have to say that when I have been there they guys really just wanted to dance and were pretty respectful. 

There's nothing fancy about this place but it feels like I am in Jamaica somewhere just groovin' and not caring about what others think. It's a remarkably different feeling I get here than any other place in the city. 

Don't forget to grab a bacon dog across the street afterwards :-)
author: Carlos A.

description:
Great drinks, food, atmosphere, and attentive service. I got a reservation through Savored, which gave us 30% off the meal. Sweet deal.

The coconut rum drink was rich and delicious. It can sneak up on you, so be wary! I ordered the coconut tilapia dish with couscous, which was also wonderful. The fried plantains with tamarind sauce was a highlight. You could say I went a little cocoNUTS, because I had the Kokomo at Blackbird later that night. ;) But I digress.

Only one thing irked me - on the menu, coconut rum drinks are listed at $7 a pop. Margaritas and the like were for the most part, also $7 each and $28 for a pitcher. Through this thing I'd like to call logic, since the pitcher price wasn't listed, I deduced that a pitcher of the coconut rum drink would also be $28... it showed up as $65 on the bill. Just for the pitcher.

We spoke with the staff, and they stated that the particular drink is priced that way because it requires more work/components? I'm still baffled, because their regular and top shelf pitchers are $28 and $34, respectively. Anyway, we were charged $34 instead, and still got 30% off as promised.

I'd definitely come back here! Love the live music and food. I just wish they'd be a little more transparent with the drink menu.
author: Sophia T.

description:
one of my girlfriends brought us after dinner at Medjool.
The place is really small and it was just starting to get crowded when we got there.
The bar is pretty small so it was a bit hard to get drinks.  bartenders were cool though.
The DJ was pretty good... African music is hard for me to dance into.
The floor is pretty small.
it's a pretty good place.
author: Learnee L.

description:
This place makes me so happy, the reasons for which are too numerous to enumerate. But here's some:

1) Plantain bananas cooked right - not an oily mess
2) Tropical cocktails with tamarind, hibiscus, passion fruit and ginger
3) Happy Hour (5:30pm-7pm) deal: appetizer, entree and cocktail for $20 ($25 with dessert)
4) Senegalese and other west african music
5) Friendly and quick service during happy hour
6) Worn furniture in a squat, ramshackle building with a warm breeze through the door makes it feel like an escape to an exotic Third World hut
7) Delicious food for vegetarians and non-vegetarians

Dishes I liked:
- Aloko (go easy on the tamarind dipping sauce or it will be too sweet!)
- Avocat Creole (crab stuffed avocado)
- Baobab Gambas
- Chicken Dibi
- Tilapia Dibi
- Banana Flambe

Dishes that sound interesting to try next time:
- Somone - breaded & fried mashed potatoes with tangy avocado sauce
- Ceebu Jen - fish paella

Areas to improve: 
Bathroom doesn't lock but it's small enough that you can hold the door shut while you do your thing

FYI, Baobab replaced Bollyhood Cafe
author: Lum P.

description:
I came here on a date on a Friday night and trying Senegalese food for the first time. At 8:30 pm, the place was pretty crowded. There was only a few tables left but I'm sure it was for reservations. While we were waiting for a table, we sat at the bar for some hibiscus cocktails. It was pretty delicious! Although it can use more alcohol... the drink went down like juice! About halfway through our drinks, we decided to order our entree at the bar. We had the Tilapia in coconut sauce. The dish now comes with white rice which is not Sengalese. We asked for the traditional style which comes with couscous. We drenched the couscous with coconut sauce and ate it with the Tilapia. It was totally delicious! I highly recommend asking for couscous hands down. The 1 entree and 2 cocktails were perfect as we weren't stuffed and no food wasted! Next time I'll try the plantains appetizers.

When we finished, the owner walked us next door to show us the live African band, dance floor, etc. They host dance classes next door. I will definitely be back!

Check out their classes online. They offer Tango, Bachata, Salsa, French Conversation, and a  bunch more!
author: Sandra L.

description:
When my husband has a wonderful time on his birthday, THAT place definitely gets a thumbs up from me. Not because he's tough to please (he's an angel!) but because it means the world to me when he enjoys his birthday.
And Little Baobab did precisely what I wanted: make my husband happy!

This place opens up as a bar/restaurant but moonlights (well, openly) as a dance club after 10pm. I haven't eaten here yet. But let me tell you this, the drinks are solid! (Plus, the bartender with the dreadlocks is really cute :D ) The girls ordered a variation of the margarita + long island iced teas while we patiently waited for the restaurant to wrap up and the DJ to turn it up! The dance floor is really tiny. Ergo, you will be dancing with pretty much everybody that's shaking a leg to the eclectic African/Latin American/Reggae music that the DJ's play.

The good thing about this place - GIRLS, YOU DON'T GOTTA DRESS UP :D
Hallelujah!

I really loved this place. And we will be returning to try out the food :)

PS: My joy knows no bounds as I write this review. Pardon the half-assed nature of my review. My incoherence should convey how much I REALLY REALLY enjoyed my time here!
author: Ranjani S.

description:
Dear Little Baobab..

I have loved you for years.. you made me happy.. you had a good vibe.. you were not pretentious.. I came almost each weekend for a good time and spent my money (though for years you were charging different cover charges for different people.. and i'm not talking about guys v girls.. im glad that is finally in check).. I even liked you before you had any coat check.. (thank you for that by the way)

However.. 
 --- What is up with the ceiling fan this weekend not working?!!?! and what is up with ONE ceiling fan instead of AC or several fans.. i mean you could even have them on the sides of the bars.. lol! It feels like Africa in there.. its too hot.. and it makes me leave early.. plus now you have a new location in Oakland and its STILL so busy.. so i know you are making dinero ($$) please give back to the community and help us help you.. we will come to dance and drink if you can please allow room to breath!

 --- what is the deal with Brazilian dancers now on every saturday.. its annoying.. they just make noise.. they stop me from dancing.. its not west african music anyway.. and no one can see anything anyway!!

 --- where is the african music dissapering?! coupe decale please! more and more.. i feel like there is strange music that is unexpected.. and plus its nice when you end the nights in reggae :) dont stop that!

 --- your bartenders.. well.. they could smile a little.. doesn't hurt. Everyone else is smiling in there.  The guy from Sudan.. he is super sweet.. we barely see him. bring him back!

ps: if people loose items and leave you voicemails, try calling back!
author: Sara S.

description:
4.5 stars

Loved the food, the drinks (yes, the coconut infused rum! give me more, more,  more), and most importantly, the dancing!

Perfect Saturday night adventure starting with dinner. Shared Mafe and Yassa with tilapia, both of which were delicious. Topped off with banana rum flambee for dessert - whatever you do, order this. It's heavenly. 

I notched down a half star because service was harried that evening. Two separate events were to take place inside, and everyone was clearly preoccupied with that. We and the diners at surrounding tables played a mean game of what felt like musical chairs for who would close the door and prevent the cold night air blowing in. 

Took a quick detour after dinner before returning to dance. The floor was small, dark, packed, all smiles - exactly how I like it. Lots of reggae, some mash ups, I only wish there had been more heavy West (or East) African beats. Definitely coming back for more though.

The happy hour specials make for an incredible deal if you can arrive in time. An appetizer, entree, & cocktail for $20, plus only $4 for additional cocktails. Do this.
author: Sushmita M.

description:
What's not to love?! Came here with diverse group of about 6 friends.  We ordered a pitcher of the tsaty goodness coconut drink (highly recommended if you're a coconut fan, it's delicious, and if you're even remotely afraid of spicy food, it will double as your fire extinguisher for the night), guacamole and baobab gambas which were DIVINE, and several dishes to share.  I was the picky eater of the group, as the only meat I'll eat is seafood, so I can't comment on the deliciousness of the other dishes, but the seafood coco (curried tilapia) and the dinner of Baobab Gambas were so.damn.good.  And can I just say, crazy cheap for the portion and tasty factor?! 

Our server(s) worked together to make sure we were being taken care of, and were very friendly to answer any questions we had about th emenu, and were even gracious when we (as is every sevrer's worst nightmare) cautiously asked if we could split the bill.  I know, I know... we should have asked ahead of time... sometimes forthought isn't my strongest virtue, I'm sorry.  I promise to try harder next time.  Cut me some slack, I'm giving you food intel you'll thank me for later.

All in all, the short version of this is, fear not when your friends adventurously suggest African cuisine for dinner, instead let your salivary glands go into overdrive knowing you've read this review and know what you're getting into.  It will be a flavor adventure of you will be grateful to have been a part of.

**Bonus Round: Get stamped before you leave and come back when it turns into a dance club for awesome music and a loveable crowd!
author: W. L.

description:
My friend and I got an aloko appetizer, the seafood coco with shrimp, the maafe with chicken and the yassa with tilapia.

The aloko served as a good appetizer/dessert.

The seafood coco was by far the best dish; the sauce was really creamy and delicious.

The yassa had an interesting mustard flavor profile.

The chicken maafe was good, but nothing special.

Get the coucous with your entrees instead of rice.

I got all the food as takeout from Bissap Baobab because Little Baobob was closed. They are basically the same restaurant since they have the same owner. The bartender who took our takeout order was really friendly and patient with us.

We decided on takeout because while we liked the vibe, the restaurant felt rather stuffy and humid.
author: Sharon H.

description: Baobab is a win for Friday nights out dancing with the girls.  I would not by any means consider this a classy night, when we go there, we don't feel creeped on or harassed. People are laid back. Drinks are brightly colored. The music is up beat. What more can you ask for.
author: Maureen B.

description: Best place to go dancing in SF. This place is so happy! I've never tried the food but I love to come here late night, after midnight. Very original decor inside, great music, drinks are cheap, everyone inside has a big smile across their face :)
author: Alexis S.

description: Somehow I went to this club even though it's not a place I'd normally feel inclined to spend time at. The dance music was interesting and different. It's definitely unique and transports you into a special world. It's a bar with plenty of drinks.
author: Denise C.

description:
Used to love it for dancing, now I love it for food (and dancing!).
Great friendly staff, delish coconut sauce, nice casual atmosphere, always running a good groupon- what more can you ask for?
author: Mana B.

description:
Firt time ever and many more to come
Lov lov this place....
Music is so catching. I have found the perfect place to start or end the week
author: Angelica H.

description:
this place is a gem! not only do they have the best happy hour deals, the food, service and atmosphere is great.

one house cocktail, an appetizer & an entree for $20 or the same with dessert for $25 from 5:30-7 pm daily. the flavor in everything i've tried is spot on. i recommend the dibi chicken, tilapia coco, yucca fries and the banana flambee.

if you're there on the later side, be sure to stick around for the great music and a dance or two!
author: Jae C.

description:
Shared the $25 Baobab Gaiinde deal that comes  with an appetizer, entree, cocktail, and dessert with a friend. So worth it - saved ~$15, which is great!

Attentive, friendly service the second we walked through the door. The ambiance is lovely: somewhat dim lighting, but candles light up every table, while lights on strings line the walls and parts of the ceiling. 

The Tropical Salad was refreshing and delicious. Plenty of feta cheese sprinkled on top of fresh salad leaves and a circle of grapefruit and orange slices on the plate's outer ring. Bursts of flavor, sweet, slightly salty and sour, made it a great appetizer. Only bummer was that I asked for it with shrimp, but maybe they ran out? All good, still very appetizing.

Took a tiny sip of the tamarind margarita, Salaan. Stung instantly and I scrunched up my face at its bitterness, but the aftertaste was alright; it settled into a smoother, sweet flavor. Guess I just like my juice/other basic sweet drinks haha. OJ over here, please!

Chicken Mafe with couscous. YUM. The sauce was just right, not over or under whelming, and the chicken meat just fell right off the bone. That is chicken done right! Came with two large drumsticks and a hearty serving of couscous, which I was surprised to find tons of raisins in - good thing we like raisins! The proportions of couscous and chicken were just right and both tasted great.

Banana Flambee... wow. Anything banana is a plus in my book, but it was warm, chocolatey, rich, and the perfect ending to the meal. There were plenty of banana chunks too, so we were stuffed with dessert goodness. I only wish there was a bigger scoop of ice cream, since we ran out of that instantly, but it was good while it lasted.

Definitely recommend this place with a friend or small group (there was a table of a good 8-10 people, so you will fit!). If you're in the mood to try something different but not way out there, this place fits the bill.
author: Tina Y.

description: So delicious! Definitely something different. We got the groupon and it included way more food than we needed. I've eaten here 4 times and the staff is consistently friendly and energetic. We loved the shrimp so much that they gave us a free order to go! Good just to grab a cocktail at the bar too. Vegetarian option for almost every item on the menu.
author: Lauren A.

description: really fun atmosphere. everyone is dancing and the music is really fun! only thing I don't like is the $10 cover....
author: Celine P.

description:
This is more of a 3 and a half than a flat 3, but only by virtue of the Aloko (fried plantains). Holy crap those plantains. Amazing! 5 stars for those. 

Same goes for the ambiance, as long as you're not looking for something uppity or quiet. You can be involved with the music and loud background or you can alternatively tune it all out pretty easily and have a nice semi-romantic  sense of privacy while you eat. 

However...had bones all over my fish. Everywhere. Probably spend half of my time just digging them all out before I started eating, by which time it was cold of course. Wifey's dish was under-seasoned and a bit dull to the eye to begin with. 

To make up for the below average food, they had a check-in specials and deals that I'm glad I took advantage of, because if I hadn't I would have been pretty disappointed at how much I spent.
author: James K.

description:
Disclaimer: I am reviewing this as a bar/night club, not the restaurant. I have not eaten here.

Mixed opinions on this place, how good/bad it is totally depends on the night and what event is booked.  Wildly different experiences on different nights.  For example, I've gone here a couple of times with friends and had a great time -- great music, everyone dancing, people on top of the benches/chairs, strong drinks being passed over from the bar.  Sooo much fun.  Granted, on these nights, we'd started out elsewhere with a few drinks, so perhaps you have to be in A State to have a great time here.

But I've gone twice without a big group (just with one other female friend) and ... it was not so good.  We realized the drinks are actually not that tasty nor strong after all, the music was a little cornier than we remembered, and we were constantly and aggressively hit on by guys who would just not take no for an answer.   It got to the point that we did not feel comfortable and decided to leave.  

Also, as a "club," this place gets extremely crowded, and there is no coat check nor place to leave your belongings, other than shoving them on or under the benches along the wall.  So ladies, make sure you travel lightly!  I leave my coat on the benches all the time and have never had a problem (other than drycleaning bills from people spilling drinks on my stuff), but my friend did have her jacket stolen here when she left it on the bench while she was dancing.
author: Heidi M.

description: Baobab I miss you.  I've been coming here for years...whenever I wanted to go out dancing I'd come here with friends but as the gentrification in the Mission increased, the vibe in this place has gone down.  There used to be a lot of diversity and people of color getting down/people having fun dancing...now it's changed.  Now it's a bunch of people awkwardly swaying. This is such a bummer.
author: Caro R.

description:
The food was very good! 
The customer service was up to par.

the only thing that I was disappointed in was that it wasn't as exotic tasting as I thought it would be. I LOVED the hibiscus juice. My friend and I shared a batch of fried bananas ( i forgot what it was called) and I had the Mafe with tofu. It was yummy, but definitely something I've already tried before. it was basically a peanut sauce with tofu, some pepers and couscous. The only different about this meal vs any thai place was that it had the couscous and a small amount of some sort of potato. 

I thought I was going in to try something completely different than I have ever tried before but it wasn't. I'll just have to order something different next time :)
author: Ashley C.

description:
Little baobab was a surprise.

Our party was way to big to keep track of what everyone ate so I am going to focus on what I had.

The guacamole: wow! Most of the times I feel like either the guacamole is bland or the tortilla chips just taste like paper. It was perfect! 

Lamb Dibi: the sauce was little bit overpowering (in the sense that it tastes very good but you have no idea of what is in it) but it is the way to have it. It really is a party in your mount.

Banana flambée: My favorite, i didn't care much about the icecream but OHHHHHH the caramelized sugar floating in the rum! I was the only one at the table that didn't go for the chocolate mousse (chocolate ick!) and in the end they were all drooling over my banana.
author: Bea L.

description:
I got here late-ish on a Thursday night, so I'm reviewing it as a dance club, not as a restaurant. This is one of those dedicated, hole-in-the-wall spots where people will dance regardless of how many people are there. As the crowd thinned out, the people with dancey pants took up more space. When it got really thin, drunk people started getting friendly with the floor. 

Drunk Person: "Floor, would you like to dance?"
Floor: "..."
Drunk Person: (making humping movements on the floor)

The music went back and forth between cheesy grooves and infectious grooves. All had a good time.
author: Rob R.

description:
2nd stop for Grubcrawl 9-30-2010

this spot is small seating is limited but if you are with a group of few it is perfect, the food is decent not perfect but for me a lil on the average side.

their servings are heavy if you have a preset menu here is what we got to try

tofu that tasted grilled with hint of a vinegarette (i swear i thought it was cheesecake bits) biting down is not what i expected
couscous was standard lite and flavorful better then other places that i have tried
stayed away from the white rice cuz i have that here at home on a daily basis haha
the peanut sauce with veggies reminded me dead on of a filipino dish called KareKare which is oxtail and tripe boiled til the meat is so tender it falls of the bone and then is added into a peanut type sauce that usually has lettuce, string beans, and slices of eggplant the sauce has some veggies no meat here but it did take me home with every bite I took
there was another tray of chicken skewered tasted lil currish which was good but was dry in the center 
another tray was that of a yellower sauce with onions tried a lil dont know how to describe it, i guess u have to go and try it yourself =)

drinks were awesome several to choose from all were good

I got to sample the Hibiscus Margarita and Banana Drop both refreshing I would definitely go back to try more

food ***
drinks **** awesome
music ***** lay back chill music, islander slow pace reggae beats
service **** folks hear are friendly and don't mind choppin it up with there customers
price preset menu for what we had well work every bite, drink wise also very decent in pricing nothing I saw was over $10
ambiance ***** you got to come in and just take it in, the sound, the look and the smell
author: Clarence A.

description:
We went in with as a party of five. We had to wait a bit to be seated and we were taking awhile to decide on what to get from the menu, it all looked so good.

We ordered a large variety of food, it was all delicious.

However, the service was bad.

We waited for a long time then the manager popped over to ask if we had already gotten our appetizers. "No" we responded.

Then they brought the appetizers.

Another extended period of time past, she popped over again. "Did you guys get your food?"

"No" again.

I mean it's just silly that there's no communication in the kitchen.

She was nice enough to come by and offer us complimentary ginger hot tea for waiting.

Ah and guess what? We waited.

Then the server brought out two teas, and we all looked confused as to who will receive the teas. I think the look of confusion on our part made the waitress realize that she misheard.

The manager finally comes out with the last tea.



**For the Dance club***

I've been here another night. The music is good, but it's so hot, sweaty, and cramped that its hard to move around.
author: Patty C.

description: This is one of those places that I probably would have never tried if it weren't for a deal and I was pleasantly surprised. The place has a cool vibe and the food and drinks were pretty good. The coconut infused rum was so good and the mafe chicken is a must try. They have definitely won me over. Can't wait to go back.
author: Diane M.

description:
You know you don't really like a restaurant when it takes you 2 months to review it. I came here back in October with Jenny C. who read about this place and wanted to try it out. Since I've had limited exposure to African food, I agreed.

After hearing good reviews about the margarita, we got a pitcher of the tamarind and hibiscus margarita. We figured that since it's a combo of the tamarind margarita and the hibiscus margarita, both which are raved about individually, we would enjoy it exponentially. WRONG! It was so gross that I chugged it to save myself from having to taste it. It was like drinking a Long Island without the benefit of getting drunk in the end (okay fine. I turned red but I turn red even with just a beer). 

The food was better. Since Jenny C. and I couldn't mutually agree on a dish to share, we got separates. Jenny C. got some garlic chicken with fried plantains (I think it's called the Dibi). It was okay. Nothing to rave about but to their credit, the chicken was very tender - pretty much fell off the bone. I ordered the Gambas (shrimp in red curry). Though it's usually an appetizer, it filled me up pretty well and much tastier than the Dibi.

As soon as we finished, the DJ came in ready to start the party. The place is so small though that we just decided to leave and ran (literally ran) over to Beauty Bar.
author: Linh V.

description:
I would give 1 star if I could

I hate this place

No toilet paper or paper towel in restrooms so they take u to this sketchy little restroom next door :(

They don't respect reservations

food was okay - chicken was under-cooked so I didn't touch it.  

definitely won't go back
author: XYZ Q.

description: This is our favorite place for going out on Saturdays or Fridays in SF. The DJ is amazing, the music great for dancing and the other people in the bar are generally very nice. A lot of foreigners go to this club, which gives it a nice international touch. The cocktails are great!
author: Chris H.

description:
Eh, it was alright. The fruity drinks were awesome, mixed with house made juices. I tried the tamarind margarita, a personal favorite. This version was very different from the Mexican style, which has stronger flavors, more sweet and more tart. The Kenyan beer though was pretty weak. 

I ordered the Mafe with chicken, which ran about $12 or 13 for two chicken drumsticks. The sauce was alright and the cous cous was pretty good. The peanut sauce was a little weird, but nothing off putting for me. I love exotic flavors, but this was not quite exotic enough. Or maybe just not flavorful enough. My sister and her friend got the Dibi with chicken and lamb respectively ($12-14). This was weird because it tasted like what I thought the Yassa would taste like (i.e., mustard and lemon sauce). The lamb version tasted better, but still was not really my cup of tea.
