All in all, it was an interesting experience, but just not the most exciting flavors in my opinion. I know I love Caribbean food, but maybe I'm just not a fan of West African food? That's weird to say because I am generally a fan of ANY food, but I don't want to blame the restaurant here because I'm sure everything came out the way it was supposed to.
author: Miguel V.

description: I love going here on dates and birthdays and for everything that needs to be a little fancy, but still affordable.  The atmosphere is nice--low, pretty lighting (with enough red to make it romantic-al).  The drinks are delish and so is the food!  I believe I always get the fish with rice and coconut sauce!!
author: Ariel F.

description:
Yep, this place is solid, but I wouldn't grab a stranger on the street by the shoulders, and shout, "You HAVE to go here!" It's good. Stop by if you're in the neighborhood and slightly hungry and looking for coconut rum, because that shit is good. The atmosphere is cool--if a taco truck were a restaurant, it would look like Little Baobab. Also, the waiters and waitresses we had were attentive without being overwhelming. They even tolerated my intoxicated friend's shenanigans (not all do).

The good: coconut rum.
The bad: nothing, really, but nothing super stand-out either.
The notable: the hole in the wall feel. I dig it. You should, too.
author: Amanda B.

description: Great drinks and ambiance.  Awesome on a Thursday night esp if you like reggae music
author: Romita J.

description:
I wanted to like it.. I read rave reviews for a good time.. And it missed the mark. I thought it'd be a good spot to have dinner Thursday, then hang out after for the scene and music. Got here past 9pm and it wasn't crackin. Seemed like most people ate and left.

We got a pitcher of the taramind + hisbiscus margarita. Bad decision. Watered down and just weird. Something artificially concocted and light.

I had the chicken with the garlic & plaintain. Overall decent dish. Salad was limey and refreshing. Plaintains were well fried and oily, too much so for my taste. Chicken was ok. Light sauce. Yeah.. mediocre. Tasted like cafeteria food or someone's basement...
author: Jenny C.

description:
Came here with one of my fave homies on a Thursday night. We initially arrived, set on a night of sobriety, but caved to the hibiscus and ginger margaritas. And dang, they were good. It took adjusting of the taste buds but I ended up really liking the flavor of both... and you can't even taste the alcohol which is awessssomeee.

We started with the Pastelles which was helllla bomb. I had the Yassa w/ the tilapia fillet and he had the Seafood Coco with prawns. Both entrees were delicious. Mmmmmm.. and the best part was the dessert -- Mango Melba -- who knew mangos could taste so good with chocolate sauce?!

Little Baobab becomes a dance club around 10. The DJ played a good mix that night, comprised of mainly reggae. Its a good spot if you're just looking to unwind and not get too cray cray.

The shack-like feeling of the restaurant, the benches, the cramped space, the paintings/photos on the wall, the friendly service, the amazing food, the good music at the end of the night -- makes you feel like you're not even in SF anymore! Definitely a place worth checking out :)
author: I. L.

description:
My review is for the food (and a drink), not the dance club. I was on the fence between 3 and 4 stars, but I decided that my delicious ginger hibiscus martini tipped the scale.

I ordered the salmon with mashed potatoes and spicy spinach. The salmon looked underdone (a bit translucent in the center), but it tasted fine and I'm alive a week later. The mashed potatoes were very rich, almost too creamy. I liked the spicy spinach on top of the potatoes; that was the most unique part of the meal. My boyfriend ordered the coconut shrimp with rice, which was also pretty good but not spectacular.
author: Adam B.

description:
Probably one of the only two sub-Saharan African restaurants in San Francisco with the other being it's sister restaurant down the street.  Extending the city's global palate alone is a praiseworthy feat.  The drinks use a lot of uncommon drink ingredients such as hibiscus further adding to the unique character of the place.  The food gives a nice sampling into flavor combinations you don't find elsewhere.

Plantano: The tamarind yogurt sauce made this dish with its tart, sweet and sour profile.  The plantains could have stood to be cooked softer, but they were decent and the dip made them beyond good.

N'Dole: This was totally worth the trip!  Delicately tender lamb in a savory spinach peanut sauce.  I'm relatively unfamiliar with African cuisine so don't know the exact spices, but the flavor combination is not comparable to any other lamb curry from any other area (India, Pakistan, Caribbean, Middle East, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand) I've had before.  The couscous was a great carb choice since it absorbs the stew much better than rice and it is a nice change in this rice-centric town.

Mango Melba: Disappointing.  The mango bits were hard and not ripe enough.  The ice cream wasn't nearly as good as the artisan shops in the neighborhood and the chocolate sauce tasted cheap.
author: Adam B.

description:
This review is for the club side. It was a decent place. Small and packed when I went. It was hard to get to the bar for a drink but the staff was pretty cool.

Saving grace was the vibe from the people dancing. It was just a have fun while shaking your ass kind of place. Not a lot of prowling or attitude. The DJs mixed very good music that kept people on the floor. We got hot fast but it was fun and we had a good time.
author: Nick B.

description:
Omg.
I have never had African food before but this was the most delicious, perfect mix of sour marinated onions and savory chicken meat! The couscous was fantastic....but the salad and onions were the best part of my dinner. Will definitely come back here again!!
author: Joanne Y.

description:
OFF THE HOOK!

I've been here a handful of times and the dancing is off the chain.

I'm usually anti-cover charge, but lemme tell you that this is the one place in San Francisco where the $5.00 cover charge is well worth it.

It's a tiny little spot in the hood of the Mission.  Underground packed.  World music bumpin.  Everybody's shakin' somethin'.
author: Angella S.

description:
I've been here countless times with friends, and friends who've djed here. It's a really cute, small dance spot. What I love most about this place is it's diversity and really nice owners of this spot. The drinks are pretty good. 

The times I do go here is for their latin, reggae, african music parties. Love it!
author: Rae R.

description:
Though I've recently tangoed with big bro Bissap to celebrate my birthday last month, it was actually Little that broke my Baobab cherry. I came here for the first time over a year ago after paying a visit to the San Francisco Tenant's Union around the corner (I've had monstrous landlord and roommate issues in the past, don't even get me started... but this is beside the point and a review to write another day). Anyway, there's nothin' like a little Senegalese lovin'--in the form of fried plantains and yogurt, sweet curry shrimp kebabs, and $5 cocktails--to nightcap ya after a long, tiring day of housing drama. Or at any point, really!

I finally returned to the scene of my first affair a couple nights ago, when Jen. O and I met here to do some serious catching up over drinks and food. It turned out to be the perfect place for it. We were welcomed at the bar and not rushed as we carefully chose our first round (by the way, Little features all the same delicious cocktails as Bissap and more with a full bar, plus they're 2 or 3 bucks cheaper here!). Jenny went for a tamarind margarita and I did a hibiscus/vodka concoction--apparently hibiscus juice is a popular refreshment in Senegal... it's on the sour side, like cranberry juice. I liked my second choice more, the self-titled Little Baobab cocktail (vodka/passion/lime), and got two of those. Though I was tempted, I didn't order any food this time, but I did notice that the menu is similar yet a bit different from Bissap's. 

We enjoyed a couple of hours in this colorful, laidback spot. The fact that it's off of Mission--just a little, but enough to make a difference--gives it a local yet homey vibe. Now I'm totally stoked to come back sometime for their African and Latin musica and/or live performances. It's culturally-interesting places like this that affirm my love of living in a diverse city!
author: Kate V.

description: Man...before this place redid the inside, it had all the elements of a quality low key jackpot. A spot where you could enjoy the music and indulge in great conversations. It is now full of mainly white folk from the marina. I do not mean to sound racist but the white folk have made the place feel sterile and lacking of soul. I myself am white and the one thing that made this place unique was the diverse crowd. It's a bummer this place has changed.
author: Thomas S.

description: Been to Bissap Baobab, but went to this one for the first time. My tilapia with coconut sauce was good, but the chicken curry my friend ordered was better! They're all reasonably priced. Dancing won't start until after 10, wished it started earlier. They needed to wait for people to finish eating and remove all the tables and chairs. The dance floor was packed shortly after, not an environrment for me to dance.
author: Yoko S.

description: I had their lemon garlic chicken with couscous. Very delicious! Their hibiscus drinks are amazing, too (they even have hibiscus margarita).
author: Trisha D.

description:
This is a review for the restaurant.


3 stars for the funky music exotic drinks and good tasting food. -2 stars for slow service, lack of ambiance, small portions.

I ordered the coconut shrimp. There were probably 8 pieces of regular sized shrimp served on a bed of a grainy type of rice. They replaced the potatoes for a small salad upon my request. The plate itself was very simple yet tasty but it simply wasn't enough food to have alone as a meal.

The ambiance is cafe-like. The tables are wobbly and sticky and the place is really small. 

The drinks were pretty exotic but again really small.

Definitely worth trying out!
author: Kathy S.

description: I love the musics and beats in here, but it is such a small place for dancing.
author: Calvin Nicholei L.

description: Interesting and delicious drinks. A great neighborhood location. The food is phenomenal!
author: Ashley K.

description: read up on Senegalese cuisine before you go. Good food if you know what to order.
author: Amit A.

description: I had no idea what to expect from Baobab.  Its a small shack-like atmosphere with portraits on the walls.  We ordered the Lamb Dibi and the Chicken Yasa.  The lamb was a more exciting dish because it came with fried plantains, and a salad.  The fried plantains were the best i've ever had and made the whole experience worth it.  The lamb and chicken both had similar mustard/yogurt sauces and the meat was tender and succulent.  The drinks menu was great because of the drinks with ginger juice.  I had the gin with grapefruit and ginger juice which added a lot to the meal.  It was a great time, not to mention the African dance hall next store!
author: Lindsay L.

description: Really amazing authentic food. Went here with a friend, shared the fried plantains which were on the sweet side and also got the coconut curry shrimp dish which was filling. I hear the dancing is good too!
author: Kelly F.

description:
My favorite place to dance in SF.  It's an intimate, in-the-know dance party, sexy, sultry, international flavor, and deliciously sweaty.  Electro, hip-hop, samba, afro rythmic, sophisticated and visceral.  Everyone moves.  Mostly straight but can attract a mixed crowd.  Represents the best of San Francisco culture.

If anyone can suggest a comparable spot in LA (don't laugh) please let me know.
author: Mike C.

description: Didn't try the food but I had the pleasure to enjoy drinking and dancing and it was very fun! Such a unique place in the city, I felt like I was back to France weirdly haha no pressure, no girls dressed super bitchy, people just have fun! I will definitely come back :)
author: Carole P.

description: One of the most fun dance bars to go at night. I haven't met a single person who has come here and doesn't love it. Haven't tried the food but i'm sure that's good too.
author: Ali H.

description:
A cute little place to go on a hot night in the city.  The food is Senegalese (picture peanuts, couscous and plantains).  The menu is relatively small, but there are a few vegetarians/vegan options.  I almost always get the Mafe Tofu, with plantains to start.

The big draw for this place is really the margaritas.  There are so many different types, and they drift fairly far from a traditional "margarita".  Who doesn't love a little hibiscus and rum?  Best part: buy it by the pitcher.

Really a great place to hit up on a Friday night with some friends.  Keep the pitchers flowing!
author: Douglas P.

description:
Came here in a group of 6 on a Friday night at 8.45. The place was pretty crowded. Its small with limited seating. Get a reservation and  reach on time to get seated. We had  to wait at the bar till we were seated as we reached late. The ambiance had a cozy and fun vibe.

We ordered : 
1 pitcher hibiscus margarita and a tamarind pitcher - both of which were delicious like never tasted before!!

Entree : 
Gambas - prawns in curry sauce with rice, was yummilicious!
seafood coco - heavenly with the creamy sauce 
dibi - tilapia dish, totally enjoyed

The food and drinks score a perfect 10, everyone enjoyed the heartiest meal. 5 star for food.

However inspite of the great food we had a few complaints. As they started rearranging the dining area at 10 to make the dance floor everything went hay way. They didn't care of the people who were still eating and the service completely disappeared. As we were still eating, tables and chairs were removed, many of our orders just didn't arrive and noone even bothered to inform, for every little thing we had to run after a waiter to catch their attention! WHAT THE HELL!! You cant just throw away the customers who are still dining to start off your dance floor or atleast have some plan of order !!

Somehow we finished our food in a hurry and as a compensation to our complaints we were offered a complimentary pitcher without an apology! Great!! Hence the service deserves just 1 star.

Once the music started the fun began, a complete refreshment to hear some different music unlike other clubs. The music was fantastic and everyone enjoyed. But the space was soo crammed that soon we could hardly stand and had to leave soon. 

Might return some day due to the impression the food made, but still forces to give a second thought for the clumsy service!!
author: Payal B.

description:
Would have given the place 5 stars minus the fact that it took us a while to get seated even though there were a few tables open. The server told us to step aside while waiting for a table...which basically pushed us outside the restaurant in the cold. Other than that, the service to come was very courteous. 

The restaurant itself is very comparative to what a restaurant in West Africa would look like (from my imagination lol). The decor is also very appealing to the eyes - African music in the background, candle lit atmosphere, African murals on the walls. Our waiter was very friendly and made sure that we enjoyed the food, which was very homey in a way.

We started off with the Pastelles, which were oh-my-god good but had us screaming for more after we devoured it (3 of us). Consequently, we shared the Yassa with tilapia and the Chicken with peanut sauce. Get the Yassa - you will not be disappointed. 

Overall, I would definitely come back to this place again. The prices are OK and average compared to the restaurants around. But if you are dying to try something new, come to Little Baobab.
author: David W.

description: The lamb is too tough, ditto for the fish (how is that even possible?).  The only good thing is their sauce, but not good enough to save the day.
author: Kristen S.

description: Fun little funkay place. The food is ok, the drinks are alright. I think I like the atmosphere best here. Not really sure how to describe it. Love it when people are dancing.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Good times everytime!  

One of the only places I still go out dancing, always great vibes on the dance floor. The food is good. The coconut rum is ridic. It's pretty much the only alcoholic beverage I even consume these days.
Staff & owner are always super sweet and helpful.

Food, drink and dance. What more could you ask for?!
author: Mira B.

description: Place is great simply but Supa tastey and island music I'm down fo sho go checkum shootz.
author: Justin C.

description: Excellent food and fun casual atmosphere. A great local find. Drinks were great too. 2nd Saturday of the month great flamenco dancing. The owner was really nice and hands on. Def would come back.
author: Hilary F.

description: I haven't been to the restaurant so this is a review for the after 10pm club/dance floor. The last time I was there was almost a year ago and it was an amazing time. I love African music and it brings me back to when I lived in Botswana! Great music, great dancers, good drinks and good people. It's a bit small but hey we made it work. I need to go back soon although I'm not sure how it is now with all the gentrification going on in the Mission. Hope it's still as fun as it was the last time I was there.
author: Marlo M.

description:
Q.  What do you do when you're looking to get your bhangra fix so you go to Bollyhood Cafe but randomly there's a soccer team party going on and they invite you to crash and then unwisely attempt to get you to play soccer with them because they need girls on their co-ed team and then a random band plays but you feel like you're in an ashram and you would much rather be at a world dance party ear-chair traveling through Europe, Africa, India and the Caribbean with other like-minded happy and sweaty people?

A.  Go to LITTLE BAOBAB.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group on a Saturday night (we came early [around 5:30pm], and were the first ones to be seated in the restaurant). I ordered:

Entree: Seafood Coco w/ tilapia 
OH. MAH. GOODNESS. It was so delicious. Loved every bit of it. 

Dessert: Mango Melba
This was just okay. Ice cream, mangoes, and chocolate syrup. Can't go wrong.

Drinks: assorted cocktails containing ginger (I love my ginger drinks)
All pretty yummy :)

Will definitely be back! 

FYI: cute, small restaurant that got PACKED. quickly.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Pretty stellar food when you can get a table.

Strongly suggest getting the house coconut infused rum while you wait, or at dinner, or after dinner. Pretty much just get the drink.

Not sure how it's scheduled, but the main restaurant is the place to go (the bar/dance club/whatever is attached right next door), and sometimes closes randomly. They do have live music some nights, which provides a pretty fun and lively atmosphere.
author: Will J.

description: Great prices and interesting food! I liked my Dibi sauce (tons of onions) with lamb. Would like to try their chicken. Fried plantains were really good in the gambas sauce.
author: Gina C.

description: This place is closed. I can not get in nor I can contact them via the phone number. Even try making reservation via Open Table. Not able to do. Anyone have updated info on this place? Please advise.
author: Nicholas H.

description: A friend turned me on to this place. I have not tried the food, but the dancing here is amazing. Probably one of the few places in SF that people come to have fun and dance. There is plenty of room and the vibe is great. I try not to tell too many people about this spot because I want to keep it hidden. A little selfish I know...but I love to dance, and places like this are so few in SF. You will have a great time at Little Boabob
author: Anand S.

description: this place is sort of an experience. it's very down to earth and sort of rustic in a sense. no frills whatsoever. the food is different, considering it's the only place that i know of that serves Senegalese food in the city. i always enjoy the coconut shrimp, the yucca fries with guacamole and the sweet plantains with tamarind sauce. in the evening they have reggae music, which is awesome. for people coming from out of town, i would recommend this place for something unique.
author: Regina C.

description:
Senegalese food.  Curries, couscous, and cocktails.
Friday night at 7- Walked up the the front door as another gentleman entered, he held the door open, asked how big our party was, and we were immediately seated and served.  
We had a pitcher of "Rose".  It was super watered down and full of ice but the food was tasty overall.  
I had the "Mefe" with chicken- which was very tender- though I wish it had a bit more spice to it.  My friend had some type of curried lamb- it was good, better than the chicken, but again needed some type of kick to it.
author: Tamara G.

description: I can't say enough good things about this place. I have a pretty solid reputation amongst my friends as someone who always throws a good party. So for my 32nd birthday, I needed to find the perfect venue. I searched for a while and came across this hidden gem. I made a reservation for dinner and drinks for 23 people, and we were given full service. The manager, Marco, gave us a special menu so we wouldn't have to wait long for our food. Everyone LOVED the food and the ambiance. After our bellies were full of delicious food and drinks, the dancing started. This is one of the best dance parties I've been to since college. By the end of the night, we were all tired, sweaty, and happy! Also, Marco is one of the nicest, most professional, and genuine managers of any business I've come across in a long time. He will make sure you have a great night and at a great price. Check this place out!
author: Sheryl M.

description:
Came to meet a co-worker for a drink around 9. Bartender struck up a conversation with us, it was pretty low key. Made me feel like I was in the islands/East Africa. 

After a couple drinks people started pouring in. Next thing I knew the whole place was poppin off. Good music and dancing. Wish I could have stayed, not many places like this in the US.
author: Phillip W.

description:
This is for the dance portion of the place. I have not had food here in ages. But they have air-conditioning which is GREAT! Drinks are solid and the people are VERY friendly. You can dance the night away and have a great time no mater what. Get your cardio on! 

PS - This is not the place for you if you need to have a table to sit or lots of room. It gets VERY packed and you will get pushed on while on the dance floor, so don't get mad if someone steps on your Pumas... just let it slide!
author: Amelia M.

description:
First time here.  Came in before the Bollyhood Elite Event with Siamak S & Jason R. Another place that, if I'm in the neighborhood again, I would definitely come back.

Loved the Ethiopian music videos on the screen.  Welcome change from sports in bars.  

Beer was good and cheap!  Jason R was a gem and plopped the bucks down for the 5 beers we had.  It was happy hour, so we were cheap dates!  

Bartender - a very beautiful woman with great earrings!  I'd give this place 5 stars for her customer service.  

Jason R. says their restaurant, "around the corner," serves really good food.  I haven't eaten there yet, but based on the "after the event" food we got at a tacqueria a few blocks away that Jason R & Siamak S consider "the best," I will be back to try Little Baobab food.

Only lose one star, because I had this really uncomfortable feeling that the building housing this business (and others) was on its last legs.  But that's character, right? I will be back.  I know an actor who would love this place.

Couldn't get my eyes off the music videos on the TV!  But we had to go - Bollyhood was waiting!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I've never heard of this place (tells you how much I frequent the mission) and I was excited because I never had this type of cuisine before. I'm always up for trying something new, especially an incredibly inexpensive place like this.

Although my friend made reservations for 6, the hostess was putting together tables when we got there, as if they didn't know about our reservations. Not sure what they would have done if we had a later dinner. 

We started with their plantains and chips and guacamole - all very good, especially the guac.  I went with the tofu with spicy spinach and gombo stew with couscous as an entree. The food was plentiful, but the dish itself was OK - it had a strong vinegar taste that I wasn't a fan of. My friend had the chicken with peanut sauce and shared a bite with me. Her dish had a very similar flavor to a filipino dish, kare-kare. Now that's something I'm a true fan of! Seriously, you put peanut butter in/on anything and I'm all over it. 

This place turns into a dance club after 10pm. They clear out the tables to make a dance floor. The food may not have been my favorite, but I definitely enjoyed the music afterwards. It just made you want to hang out, groove, and chill all night long! It's a tiny place - I can see how it can get hot and sweaty in there real fast. But I don't think the friendly folks here mind that at all.
author: Kimberly S.

description: The chicken curry I had was spicy and savory. Different from Asian curry and uniquely delicious. The chicken itself was cooked to perfection and my wife's vegetarian dish was good but didn't have the same intensity of flavor. Cocktails were decent. Overall a fun experience plus a great deal booking it through Savored.
author: Rosario V.

description: Little Baobab's staff is super friendly, the mood is always fun, and the food and drinks are amazing.  I love visiting here whenever I am in San Fran.  It's like squeezing in a mini vacation to the Ivory Coast without leaving the country.
author: Jack A.

description:
KARMA AFRIKA on LEAP DAY!

We got here around 7:00 PM and there were about 3 tables open for dinner. There was going to be a little party starting later on and so we went early for dinner. It took the waiter about 15 minutes to allow us to sit down. He didn't know (forgot) about the party later on and seemed to not want to seat us even though we said we wanted to eat dinner here anyway. That was weird. 

Finally we got to sit and order, the waiter made it clear that he wanted us at the 2 person table and not the 4 person table immediately next to us. 

Ten minutes later, the Karma Afrika crew shows up and some want food...well, they sat next to us at the 4 person table. We filled the place up so much they turned people down who wanted to have dinner here. 

I ordered the Tofu Curry with rice. I got the Tofu Curry with cous cous. The carrots undercooked and the other vegetables seemed overcooked. 

I noticed other people leaving who were waiting to order food, they were starving and went someplace else to eat. The service is pretty slow and confusing. They took a while to even take our friends orders. 

Once the party started, we danced, drank yummy cocktails (tasty, sweet, lots of ginger, although sadly weak in alcohol), then started the Afro Raffle. 

The other people working started taking out all the tables one by one. They wanted to take the table we were using for the Raffle prizes and event information.  We had already told them we would clear it after the raffle, since we needed to put the raffle tickets and Karma Afrika stuff there. They were very insistent and before our friend even got back to the table after announcing the winners and handing out prizes, they came at me for the table again. I had to gather everything before they swiped the table. One table, in the front corner of the room.

Music was good, we had fun. 

All they need is a better system for the dinner turn music, bar and dancing.

The place is small. We deal with it.

3.6 stars
author: Lorrie N.

description:
This is my favorite place!!  Everyone is so sweet here, and really great dancers too.  I've never been on a bad night.  There is always good music and good dancers.  (Salsa, African, reggae, etc. = all my favorites).  
The crowd is very mixed ages and ethnicity.  I've been there with every color friend, and they all had a blast!  I'm in my 20's and love it, but it's a place mom could even dig, because it's that well-rounded.  

I especially like the vibe on the dance floor.  It's not like most clubs where if you dance with a guy once, you can't shake him & he thinks you're going home with him..  At Baobab, I can dance with everyone!  I've never had a problem with anyone's girlfriend or date getting mad either.  I mean, you dont have to dance with everyone (my friends spot the finest, most single-looking guy in the room and...).  

The men are always nice and respectful.  You can grind them if you want to, but that's not my style.  I like to keep a little room to show off some moves, and so far, most of the guys I've danced with there have some great moves of their own!  

One time, I did have a problem with a (really drunk) guy be really persistent trying to dance with me.  I gave him half a dance and he was too close for my comfort, so I walked away.  He kept trying to dance with me, until finally (without me asking), some guy I dont know (who was on a date), stopped him and said "hey man, leave her alone, she's my sister".  The drunk guy tried to dance with me one more time, and the sweet man on a date kindly escorted him out (not rough or anything...the drunk guy didn't even resist being guided out the door).  From there, the bouncer didn't let the drunk guy back in.  

But that's the type of place it is:  a total stranger will look out for you.  Everyone is polite there.  It's just an all-around great place, and I haven't ever been to a place that remotely compares to how awesome Baobab is.  Really!

***************
oh!  There is the Baobab restaurant (fabulous food, and a great way to start the night!), then around the corner, there is the dance-club, which most of this review is based on.  I've gone to the restaurant a few times, and I am always very happy with the food.  But watch out if you think you're gonna be dancing later!  The portions are so large, and so delicious.  I almost fell in to a food coma on my way to the club (had to put my leftovers in the car first).  Once I got to the club, I had to sit for a few more minutes before I could hit the dance floor.
author: T T.

description:
I am stoked that they started serving Vegan brunch, sadly it felt like we showed up unannounced at your hippy friends house for breakfast. 
All our coffee had foam in it from soapy mugs. 
All said and done the food is not bad, but it's also not very good. As a vegan in SF, there are far better options.
author: JawkDNA X.

description:
The food and prices are good. They do fried plantains with a yogurt tamarind sauce (which is AWESOME).

The cocktails were mostly juice.

The food came out relatively quickly, but after that, it took forever for the waiter to pick up my credit card and a second eternity to get the card back.
author: Anton S.

description: Amazing unique food. Great drinks. Riduculously awesome staff. Swanky live music. What more do you want?
author: Brian P.

description:
Last night was my first time ever coming to this place and it wasn't for the food but for the music.  After leaving Hog & Rocks and Beauty Bar, the group was looking for something different.  We went into this place hearing reggae music and an open dance floor.  The music was good and the space was good for group hangouts and dancing.  Drinks were on the weaker side and a little sweet.  

Had a good time here but I would evaluate once I come back for the dining experience and probably a more populated night.
author: Carmen C.

description: This place is fantastic! I had been there before for dancing (which is always fun), but never eaten there.  Thought we'd try it since we had heard good things.  Not all of our party was there when I got to the restaurant (actually only I was there out of a party of 6), but the hostess was super nice, re-arranged a couple of things and was able to reserve a spot for us until everyone made it, on a night that was relatively busy.  The food was AMAZING and our server was so nice.  Loved the drinks too!  I got a Salaan, which is a tamarind margarita, so yummy.  So good! Best of all is that the prices are so cheap for the quality and service. I can't wait to go back next time I'm out in the area.
author: Danny C.

description:
I'm a bit mixed on Little Baobab. It has a cool vibe and might be a fun spot for drinks and dancing, but the food really disappointed. The menu consists of a range of "comfort African food" - inventive choices but poor execution. I had the salmon and while the fish itself was alright, the accompanying spicy spinach and potatoes was not edible---really really bland. Quite a few of us didn't finish our plates. It's sad to leave a place hungry when the portions are generous.

I'd go back for drinks though. My group shared a pitcher of Banana juice flavored Margaritas---tasty and unique!

I feel bad giving it 2 stars, as the service was fine and friendly, and the drinks were great, but the food really was not good at all.
author: Dave S.

description: I absolutely loved this bar/restaurant. It has nice character and very friendly people. I had a few rum and coconut specials, which was delicious.
author: Paul M.

description: We had a reservation for a large group but there was super slow service! Then by the time we got our food we had about 20 minutes to eat before they "closed" down for dancing. They rushed us to finish so they could get started but it was their fault the food took forever. We ate dessert while the entire staff/restaurant watched us so they could start dancing. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone!
author: Lindsay H.

description:
Bissap Baobab is a little oasis of warm people, cool cocktails and heart-felt food tucked in a corner of the Mission.  It is a way of traveling without airfare.  
Make sure you start with a house-made cocktail.  They are refreshing and delicious and reasonable, and made with home-made ginger ale.  My favorite is "Rose".  Follow it with some plantains, and try the Mafe or Yassa.  Follow up with a little dancing and you've just travelled to West Africa, sans jet lag. 

Go on your birthday and get a free pitcher of drinks for your and your friends!
author: Karen S.

description:
The place is a bit funky - in a good way - and it reminded us of a treasure one might find by stumbling around on Holiday in the Caribbean.  As fans of Eritrean and Ethiopian, this was a nice change in style.

We had two appetizers, two entrees and two cocktails.  Everything was very well prepared - the chicken was moist and thoroughly cooked, the seasoning was enchanting; the sides were appropriate to the main(). The service was quick and friendly and the cocktails were inventive.

We'll be back.  We'll take friends.
author: Carlo M.

description: The food was fantastic and I loved the lively atmosphere here. Flavors are unique and match the organic feel of the place. Service was slightly slow but overall still good!
author: Valerie H.

description: I have been coming here for 3 years now and love this place. Unlike most other bars/clubs in SF, people actually dance here! And they look happy while dancing too (lots of people try to put on a show of having a good time whereas here ppl are by and large actually having a good time) ! Must be the West African, Latin, and occasionally Indian jams. Cover charge is annoying but no other place like it. I'll be back!
author: Sofia T.

description: The food is really good. Not the cheapest spot, i like the bar and the bartenders. They have really good live music and it's got a really nice atmosphere. The one thing is you never know if its going to be busy or dead.
author: Bantu Z.

description:
I don't think I'll be going back there again. Probably not a great option for vegetarians. While they do have options on the menu, I can't really recommend it based on the flavor.
I ordered the Riz Au Cari w/ Tofu and besides most of the tofu pieces tasting burnt, the curry lacked any flavor. 
I had a chance to try the tamarind margarita and am not sure what the fuss is about.
Service was good, but I was starving and eventually left disappointed.
author: Paolo B.

description: Very disappointed. The appetizers we had included an avocado with tuna and fries. The other was prawns and pita bread. I had the lamb dish and my friend had the coconut seafood entree. Everything was not good at all. Flavors were bland. The food was barely warm. Service at least was really nice and the atmosphere was small and cozy. Would never return again.
author: Diem L.

description:
Perhaps it was my friend, who couldn't stop raving about the Yassa Tilapia on our drive to Little Baobab, that over hyped my first Sengalese experience. In the end I found myself satisfied...but not overly impressed. 

His Yassa Tilapia was indeed delicious but I couldn't help but wonder if I had ordered the dish for myself... would I eventually get bored of the coconut taste? Probably.

I ordered the Dibi Lamb which was just fine but nothing special. 

Definitely have your entrées with couscous. We were not asked our preference and when lackluster jasmine rice came out with our entrées I was thankful that I had requested a side of couscous. 

Somewhat random tip: If, during your Little Baobab experience, you are coughing and sneezing and thus unfortunately unable to have a cocktail...try the ginger tea. It is strong and delicious and will kick that cold onto to the mean streets of the Mission!
author: Sarah Z.

description: Came here for a birthday party and the music was great! Really good beats and fun to dance to! In terms of drinks, the wells were REALLY WEAK. The margaritas must have been premixed. I tried the hibiscus margarita and it was much more flavorful and you could actually taste the tequila. $5 cover for a Saturday- not terrible.
author: Vinitha R.

description:
I really really really like this place. So much so, that I'm thinking of planning my bday dinner here. I just like the down-to-earth vibe, the homemade tasting food that are not shy serving sizes, the music, and oh...i can't forget the homemade coconut rum!!!!! OMG, that stuff is dan-ger-ous! I also like coming here for the dancing, cuz you can wear watever the hell you want, and just let loose. I heart dancehall music. 

 Anyway, this place is dope. Simple as that.
author: Emy s.

description: Guys standing around.. Not into you... Just the reputation of this cheesy ass bar.... Love them and hope this new owner doesn't clooose....
author: Scott Y.

description:
Why so pricey? Not very big portions, nothing particularly great about anything we had. Guac and sweet potato fries really was just that - I don't know why I expected a different take on anything. They mashed up an avocado, put a little lime juice in it, and served about three tablespoons of that with a handful of fries. Took all of three minutes to inhale the whole thing. At a casual pace.

The chicken dish I ordered cost as much as half a chicken at my favorite rotisserie joint in the hood but it didn't even amount to a quarter of a chicken. And it was bland bland bland...
author: Will R.

description:
Oh my lord how fun is this place?

I never ate here. My friends and I came in around 11ish and it was poppin!

$5 cover which I thought was a little silly but I went with it. drinks were I think $5-6 which was reasonable for how strong they were. The ginger drink was AMAZING. 

One thing that stood out while my girlies and I were dancing was no creepers were forcefully trying to grab us and grind on us. Most dance clubs I hate being hounded down by silly billies. Here everyone just had a fun good time with positive vibes. I felt like I was back in St. Martin! Won't lie I got hot and bothered and had to step out a few times. 
Needless to say I made some new friends, danced with a ton of fun people and had a great night. I will definitely be back!

I super want to try the food here- sounds delish!
author: Amanda S.

description:
This is my first time trying Senegalese food and this place did not disappoint! I came here without any idea or expectations of how the food would taste like and enjoyed every bite! 

Orders of the night include:
Mafe Chicken
Seafood coconut (both Tilapia and shrimp)
a pitcher of tamarind margarita
a glass of coconut infused rum

All food orders were soooo good! Both the chicken and tilapia were so tender it practically melts in your mouth. Add in the coconut sauce and you've got a winner dish! Both dishes came with a choice of rice and/or couscous and potatoes. I got the rice and didn't care too much for it. I didn't try the couscous but a friend did and didn't like it. However, that didn't ruin the stars of the dish-the protein!!! 

The biggest disappointment of the night was the tamarind margarita! We practically forced ourselves to finish the pitcher (yea yea I know, what's the torture in drinking, right?) but man oh man was it painful. I guess they used cheaper tequila so that strong tequila fragrance was definitely overwhelming (I added water to my drink- thats how strong it was). On top of that, there was no taste of tamarind what so ever! It was really disappointing. 

Come early if you want to grab a table to eat. Coming early also means avoiding the line. This place turns into a nightclub so it could get crowded.

Last thing, they only have ONE unisex bathroom so if you've got a small bladder, are uncomfortable sharing a bathroom with the opposite sex, be prepared!

Other than that, check out the food!
author: Stacy D.

description: I was soooo looking forward to eating here. My friend made a reservation for a group of us (for a friends birthday) way ahead of time. Well we get there a teeny bit early and let the guy (who says he was the owner) know we were there and he says he'd have our table ready soon. We wait and wait and then he tells us our table was just about ready and that the party was paying the bill right then. We continue to wait and wait...and wait. Then we see a big party come straight off the street and they took them right in and gave them a table!! So if there was a table ready, why in the world are we waiting for damn near a whole hour?!? Their customer service was just ridiculous and obviously they play favorites in that place, so needless to say that will be the last time me and my party EVER try to eat there again. Get it together!
author: Chantay X.

description:
A hesitant 4-stars.

Why hesitant? Mainly because when I came here, I was off my face.
I have memories of strong drinks (which is a bad idea when you're already quite hammered, but they were cheap, I think...), my friend spilling one of her drinks over someone's discarded shoes, dancing like a maniac, and then banging on a drum that magically appeared later on. Definitely a lot of fun, although probably more fun if you're not trying to dance while simultaneously propping yourself up on a nearby wall.
author: Duncan C.

description:
Came here for dinner (rather than club) because Bissap was closed on this Tuesday night.

Delicious spinach salad appetizer.  The lamb and couscous were flavorful but not overpowering.

Space is grungy inside and the tables are oddly cramped and uncomfortable.

My friend tackled the bill before I could get to it, and since I didn't want spill her drink, I don't know if this was expensive or cheap, but I'm trusting her that it was "such a cheap meal!".
author: Ankur P.

description: I love the music and the atmosphere of this place. It reminds me of cozy house parties where everyone is just drunk and dancing on top of each other. The music is nostalgic too, there is the occasional remixes of famous songs of the 90's that I really enjoy. I've never tried their food so I'm reviewing it as a dance club. The drinks are rather limited ( the bar is not so big) and the place is old and beaten up. But it has a magical soul to it that guarantees you will have a good time. love it. And the only reason I'm not giving it 5 star is because their coat check system is a but chaotic.
author: Kayvan M.

description:
Curious time-warp transplant, jungle drums, hibiscus drinks, riots of color, dark eyes peering over vivid cloth screens. Dancing. Drinking. Fried plantain snacks. The little one is better.

http://www.bissapbaobab.com
author: Stellah D.

description:
This was once my very favorite bar in the Mish.  It was based on a few nights in which I was surrounded by my well-intoxicated group of friends, in which men outnumbered women by a small margin. We would get there before cover began (10pm) and dance our wild hearts out until everyone was covered in sweat and happiness. Drinks were strong and flavorful, strangers were friendly and exotic. 

But then I went there with just the ladies.

It was at that point that I realized that there is a fine line between "friendly and exotic" and "foreign and grabby." There are a lot of dancing boners in that room, and they definitely fall into the close and creepy category.

So it saddens me. I love to dance, love to move in rhythm with other vivacious people and feel young and free. But I don't like being surrounded by 3 boners with busy hands and 0 class.
author: Mari C.

description:
I came here as an East Bay resident who doesn't spend enough time in the city finding these great hole in the wall places. Luckily for me, I was on a second date with an SF resident who had been here before and knew how funky and great it was. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I loved the small cozy feeling of the space. The tables are definitely in close quarters with each other and the wait staff aren't overly attentive, but everyone is very friendly and the food is delicious. I had the baked salmon and it was cooked perfectly with a very tasty sauce and mashed potatoes. I stuck with water, but my date had a margarita and noted they were a bit strong (I'll leave that to you to decide if that is good or bad). She also enjoyed her chicken kabobs and cous cous. 

There was a large group there, but based on the size of the place, I would imagine you need to make some sort of reservation to be able to accommodate more than a few people. Prices seemed pretty reasonable. I don't have any real complaints except maybe that the staff could have checked in a bit more to refill waters etc, but all in all, I'd recommend this place.  We did not stay for dancing/late night.
author: Rachelle W.

description: This place is great! Didn't get a chance to try the food but the coconut rum was off the hook!! The DJ was amazing too! Danced the night away to African beats and had a blast. The only negative thing is that there were def some creeps in there but I guess you get that anywhere. I loved the laid back atmosphere and everyone was just there to have a good time. Recommend to anyone in the area!
author: Shay C.

description:
Came here last night to experience the Mission. Wow, this place was like nothing else I have ever experienced!! Everyone there came for the same purpose: to have a good time. That's right, there was no girls trying to be sized up or guys looking for who to take home tonight. Instead it was all about dance, dance, dance. 
I will definitely have to come check this place out again when I am back in the city.
author: Gina W.

description:
Went here Friday night for a little dancing, and I loved it.

It's like stepping into another country where everyone is welcoming and the drinks are sweet.  The music was amazing and got everyone dancing on the floor.  Props to the DJ for playing a wonderful mix of African and Latin beats.  The bar was reasonably priced, so the drinks kept coming!  I had a Rose cocktail--Ginger, Cranberry, and vodka.  Our bartender was quick and friendly with our order.

The dance floor is small and sweaty.  By 12 am it was crackin' with tons of people--a good portion from Senegal itself!  Beautiful people dancing like there's no tomorrow! I was told by my friend that the place used to be smaller.  Whaaat?!?!  I can't believe the place is currently expanded and is STILL super small.

But you know what?  I'm not knockin the place too hard b/c it's small--it's can't help it!  And it even adds to the flavor of the restaurant.  My friend who's from Ethiopia said this place is reminiscent of bars and clubs at home.  I'm thinking this place it's authentic!

Go with friends who love to dance.  This is not a stand around place.  Get up, get on the floor, and let yourself be free.
author: Marissa N.

description: My husband and I visited for the first time to celebrate our anniversary and we raved about this place all the way home. The food was absolutely the best I have had in a long time (that goes for any type of cuisine). The atmosphere was fun and very comfortable. The server was very knowledgeable and we loved the fact that she was Senegalese herself (this helped us to get the whole Senegalese food experience). I ordered the Prix-fix with appetizer, entree and cocktail, while my husband ordered the one with all of that as well as a dessert. Everything we ordered and ate was DELICIOUS! We ordered fried plantains (Aloko), prawns with red cayenne pepper sauce and pita bread, Seafood Coco and Niebe Thies, and finished with Banana Flambe dessert. The tilapia in the seafood coco was so tender, juicy and flavorful. We will definitely come back much more often!
author: Rachel A.

description: My son, niece and I were very pleasantly surprised by our meal here. I highly recommend the coco shrimp. We all enjoyed the plantains too. We will return!
author: Bridget L.

description:
I have no idea what the scene is here at night (though I've heard it's thrilling) but I had a lovely afternoon outside on the sidewalk. My mate and I ordered drinks and took in the scene and I found it delightful.

I got a "Flamboyant" which was one of the best cocktails I've ever had. Hibiscus and mint and you couldn't even taste the vodka. My friend had something with whiskey in it, which I reluctantly tried but it ended up being very tasty.

I'd like to come back at night... but everyone should stop by one Sunday afternoon to cool down and people watch, too!
author: Christina B.

description: Delicious and always a fun time. Love that they have pitchers of cocktails. A great place to bring a group of freinds, eat good food, get wasted, and then dance the night away to sweet reggae jams. Coming back here on Friday to have my girlfriend's bachelorette party!
author: Michelle O.

description:
I loved the atmosphere at this place!!! 
The locals that attend are so much fun, friendly and great dancers. The dance floor is a bit compact, the DJ's took a bit to set up but overall the experience here was unbelievable. I felt like I was in Jamaica or in another part of the world other than SF. The African beats, reggae, hip hop, even some of the latin music gave the feeling of being in the Caribbean or Africa. I had a blast here. 

The drinks were strong but tasteless, and the bartenders didn't know how to make too many drinks, so we stuck to the typical CranVodka, and the long Islands and we were off to a great night! 

I will complain about their security. Both of them were extremely rude and obnoxious guys. (You know who you are! and I told you I would write about your lack of manners) so Please next time, be nice to people and treat females with respect. Thank you!!! 

This place was a blast! I will be coming back for the dancing and lots of eye candy!
author: Marcela R.

description:
Love, love love Little Baobab.

From 6-10pm it's a bar/restaurant with good Senegalese food. Mostly some saucy dish served over rice or couscous. The fried plantain appetizers are sinfully good. The $5 house cocktails are really good, my personal favorite is the Rose, but the flavors center around ginger, tamarind and hibiscus.

After 10 the tables and chairs get moved out of the way and it becomes a small dance club, with DJs that play "world" music. It gets really crowded by 11 on weekends. Cover is $5.

Staff is awesome, bartenders are friendly. Speak french to any of the many Africans that work here to score points (and possibly discounts).
author: Ariel M.

description:
Huge disappointment.  Hadn't been there in 8 years and won't ever be back.  

Negatives:
1) No soap in the bathroom.  Server said they ordered wrong and there was no soap left.  Gross.  Plus there are a zillion nearby stores where they can buy soap.   
2) Tables were sticky.  Like really sticky.  Clothes sticking to the table sticky.  Our server wiped the table down for us but said that's just how they are.
3) Lamb was super tough.  Nearly impossible to cut.  Overcooked or just a cheap cut, not sure.

Flavor was good but the quality was definitely lacking.  This place has gone way down hill.  There are way too many good restaurants in the Mission to waste your time, money, and calories here!
author: Sandy S.

description:
In order of amazingness:

1. Avocat Creole - Halved avocado stuffed with crab - pure amazingness.  The aftertaste of it is amazing.  It tastes like Asian food but has a delayed flavor that tastes like taco seasoning!  It is something that I may have to copy if I have to make an appetizer for functions.

2. Plantano- Fried plantains - great flavor and cooked to perfection.  I didn't realize how much I missed fried bananas!

3. Cari Volaille - chicken curry - very flavorful chicken with a broth almost like oxtail soup - great and filling entree

4. Crevette Coco - shrimp in coconut sauce - very good dish in itself, but it feels like it could have been from any restaurant.  It did not stand out like the other dishes.

There was also excellent service from the one waitress tackling the whole place on a Monday night.  Beer was warm but I just pretended that's how it was supposed to be there.  I will definitely go to Bissap Baobab to compare it to this restaurant.  I would highly advise getting the first two appetizers I mentioned along with the Cari Volaille.

Total tab with the restaurant.com certificate: $19
author: Joey S.

description:
**Changed my review to 5 stars. Baobab has become one of my FAV restaurants, and I take EVERYONE here :)  they just combined Bissap Baobab with Little Baobab and have a bigger dance floor now. I HOPE they move the dance parties to the bigger space!

---

Went here for the first time for HAPPY HOUR on a Thursday night and LOVED it.

Really cute spot with a lot of character. TASTY hibiscus, ginger, and other awesome infused cocktails for really cheap ($5 and $7 drink menu). They are pretty strong, too. Don't let the pretty drink names fool you...or maybe it was my empty stomach.

Either way, really good drinks and tasty food. Ginger Rum Punch was my fav.  The plantains had an amazing dipping sauce.  I'm definitely coming back!
author: Gina R.

description: We went for an office holiday party...where do i start.  The food was cold when it was served.  The Mango and ice cream dessert smelled like a cross between a raw onion and a cheese burger.  Wouldn't credit the bill.  Oh and then next day.....oh dear three of us had lower intestinal disorder.  NEVER AGAIN.  I wanted so badly to like this.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I'm partial to baobobs so I have a bit of a bias. Love the place, from the music to the people, from the rock-bottom prices to the fun atmosphere it affords. When I checked in to Little Baobob on Foursquare, one of the tags associated with the place said "20s crowd" -- it should have also said "dance party" or "room dancing". Dancing here is so much fun, even if the music isn't normally your thing, you can really groove to it. Love the beats.
author: Angie C.

description: I knew about the hype of this place but it's somewhat near where we live and boy did it live up to our expectations. Excellent food. Beautiful dishes really. Great service. Nice people. The only problem I have is the music they play is too loud and annoying but everything else makes this place one of the best in all of SF.
author: Georgia D.

description:
Very eclectic bar in the Mission that has an African flare. If I didn't know any better, I would have thought this is where they filmed those Red Stripe commercial with the Jamaican Rasta in the suit but it is very similar in style. It's a small shack where they play music and people dance, really getting their groove on. It can get a little musty given the size of the place and lack of ventilation. Their drinks are on the small side but they offer some unique concoctions many of which feature ginger. Very interesting place with a one-of-a-kind culture. 

Only turnoff to this place is $5 cover. Easily a 4 star spot if it was free.
author: Ed L.

description: If u like simple hip chic world music signature dishes and one of a kind house blend cocktails, then this is the place for you!
author: April Chelses M.

description: Great menu and low key atmosphere. Great service and very tasty food!
author: Tina F.

description:
Came here with a couple friends last weekend.  We started of by sharing an order each of Aloko and Pasteles (beef).  Both were yum, and I was especially fond of  the Pasteles....they reminded me of empanadas.

I ordered the Yasa which was marinated fish w/ grilled onions in a  lemon garlic mustard sauce with couscous.  It was heavily laden with onion, and the mustard flavor wasn't over-powering.  The couscous was plain.  I've tried the shrimp coconut before and thought it was alright.  I much prefered the Yasa.  So, if I'm ever back, I'd order the Yasa again.
author: Michelle N.

description:
A def go-to when I can't deal with the marina-fication of most of the rest of the mission (that's right valencia street, I'm looking at you). Hibiscus or Tamarind drinks are amazing, but go early and have just one and then stick to beer (cheaper and less chance of it getting destroyed in ensuing dancing revelries). Its big brother, Bissap Baobab, is just around the corner, and well worth checking out for dinner beforehand.

Go to Little Baobab; yes, they have a cover. This is not uncommon, and is worth it to get some quality music that doesn't feature the lyrical stylings of either (1) beyonce or (2) the ting tings.
author: Poonam S.

description: Love the fried plantains and tamarind sauce. Entrees are solid and with good portions. Haven't come here to dance, so can't really comment on that.. One of my favorite dinner places.
author: Ayo R.

description: I haven't had food from here but the drinks are great and cheap.  I love the music they play here. This is my FAVORITE place to party at on the weekends.
author: Amani B.

description: This is one of my favorite places for music and dancing after hours. Yes, as some have noted, it's far from perfect, but always reasonably priced, fun, and often magical. I've been coming here off and on for a long time, and I generally end up having a great time. Usually, it's a great chance to hear music I am not going to hear anywhere else nearby, or dance to some great music that has some rhythm. Worth checking out if you see something interesting!
author: Lalita K.

description:
I was really looking forward to eating at this restaurant as I had been eyeing their vegetarian-friendly menu for quite a while. 

 I tried to go on a Friday night without reservations in a group of five and we had to wait over an hour to get seats. There was limited room at the bar and lounge so had to stand/huddle in a corner of the bar. While we waited, we ordered a few cocktails, which ended up being pre-mixed. They were extremely watered down so I asked the bartender to make it a bit stronger and she agreed; when my friend requested the same thing, however, she poured a little bit of extra mixer into his drink (ew). 

When we eventually sat down, we all found the food to be rather bland and forgettable, the service to be extremely slow, and the restaurant too loud to talk in. 

I have heard subsequently that it is a really fun place to go dancing later in the evening on a Friday or Saturday but I don't recommend it for a dinner with friends on the weekend.
author: Maggie J.

description:
This is a review for only the dance club and drinks.  I have never had dinner at Baobab.

The music is wonderful.  Brilliant soul moving beats and sometimes they play Indian and other world music, too.  

Minus 1 star for the size of the dance floor.  The dance floor is quite small and does get VERY crowded and nearly impossible to move at times, the only drawback.  

The entrance fee is cheap.

The men at the club are respectable and do not attempt the normal "club humping" style dance moves.  

The drinks are also reasonably priced and quite delicious.  Not your normal bar drinks.  If memory serves me well, they have hibiscus and ginger infused cocktails that are quite yummy!

Baobab is my favorite place to dance in the city.
author: Tiny H.

description:
If you want to dance your ass of and can't risk hearing anything like "Gasolina" ever again, Little Baobab is your place.
Cheap, interesting drinks, an eclectic/unpretentious crowd, and the beats to keep you dancing until the break of dawn make this one of my favorite bars in the area.
Come earlier (10 or 11) if you're not looking for a crowd, but if you're the type that enjoys grooving with other fly cats and getting a bit sweaty make sure to arrive a little later.  It can get wild.
author: Jason C.

description:
A couple of my friends have been going here for years and love this place. This is a restaurant that turns into a club after 10.  Parking was a pain and after driving around for like 20 mts trying to find street parking, decided to just bite the bullet and pay $15 for parking. The neighborhood is a little iffy but there are usually a lot of people around so you should be ok. The place is tiny!  I am always looking for new kinds of cuisines and was excited to try Senegalese for the first time. The drinks were not that good. I tried a lot of different ones and the ginger and the orange cocktails were very disappointing. The hibiscus one was decent. The appetizers were good...had something that had bread with dipping sauce with shrimp. Then we had Aloko- plantains with sweet tamarind sauce which was surprisingly good. I had the chicken mafe with rice. This was awesome. Chicken with peanut sauce and spinach. Very tasty. If I was just rating this dish, I would give it 5 stars. 

Now on to the club.  I like African beats and the music was very catchy. It seemed like a combination of Caribbean, House, Meringue and Salsa. You know the awkward moment at any club at the beginning of the evening where no one wants to be the first on the dance floor and people hang around till there are more people on the floor so they can lose themselves in the crowd. Well, I am kinda like that too. Anyways, since the music was really good, we got on the dance floor and were doing our thing. But other than a couple of other people, nobody else was dancing! There are benches on the sides and it seemed like folks were content just sitting and watching us. My date got weirded out after like 5 songs and we ended up leaving. Good food, great music, could have been an awesome time if only the more people got up and danced. Come on people,  get up and DANCE!
author: Sunil R.

description:
By far my favorite place to dance in SF. It draws a diverse and rather good-looking crowd that just likes to GET DOWN. 

Oh and $5 for a solid drink? Yes please. 

Yes, it gets packed. But all the sexiness makes up for it.
author: ciara s.

description:
ok, it's low budget deco.  but it's homely and i like it.  
and the food is amazing.  the drinks too.  the dancing too.  the prices too.
will be back again, soon.
author: Obi W.

description: I remember when Baobab was amazing. ..... but it's changed.  They took away the high tops and changed up the seating. The food is not made with the same amount of love. The salads aren't served with feta and sun-dried tomatoes anymore. The fish seems of poorer quality and they don't use turmeric anymore to season it. They took the raisins out of the rice.  Also, they never have the tuna pastelles when you order them-that's the best thing ever. The yassa sauce still rocks but the love.is.gone.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Went here for an after-dinner drink with a date on a Friday night, and wish I had stayed gotten there earlier for the food! everything looked super yummy, and the restaurant was packed.  Then, come 10 o'clock (or so) the tables were taken out, the lights went low, people were shoo-ed off their bar seats and the music started.

Very energetic, friendly and chill crowd, definitely a pretty diverse scene, and everyone was having a blast.  I definitely recommend you try a hibiscus margarita (or 3) and get your dance on. I'm going back soon for the food!
author: Kristin F.

description: We bought a groupon and dined here on a Tuesday  a couple weeks ago. The food was amazing! My favorite dish was the sauté prawns.  The waitress was very attentive and very friendly. We loved the cocktails and will definitely come back!
author: Jenny J.

description:
I'm holding back 1 star just to hold back some bias for why I like this place. I come here for one thing. To dance. That's it. They have great music. Not just your standard clubbing tunes. They do a great job of mixing the latest and greatest with some great tunes I haven't heard in a while along with some stuff from around the world. The place is small. There's one bathroom. And it's really really really crowded. I can easily see how people can give this place a 1 star and at the same time I can see people giving it 5. 

It all comes down to your attitude and expectation when you come to this place. If you want a place to stand around to drink. Not for you. There's no space and the drinks menu isn't all that impressive. If you just want to dance and come home sweaty. Yours or everybody else's in the club. This is for you.
author: Kien L.

description: Funky little place.  Lots of drink choices, fewer food choices (which was fine with me) but very tasty.  Great atmosphere on a Saturday night with great live music in the back room.  Fun and intimate!
author: Woody M.

description: Friendly staff and kick-ass tropical drinks that make me dream of lying on a beach in Thailand...  I love the pitchers of rum punch,  Always amazed how this place goes from sedate restaurant to banging club.
author: Ali B.

description: This review is only for the wednesday night cuban salsa.  The dj is good, the dance floor is good and the dancers are great. Super casual place, no pretentious ballroom-y dancing...just a lot of juicy Timba beats and booty shaking on a wednesday night!
author: Nilu r.

description:
Came here because of an old-school restaurant.com gift certificate (groupon will probably run them off the interweb soon). 

The certificate was actually for their sister restaurant Bissap Baobab, so I asked when we walked in to make sure it was valid. This guy (Bongo) said it was fine, so we got a table. 

My group shared the plantains (with yummy dipping sauce), as well as three entrees: N'Dole, Mafe, and Cari Yap. All were good, but my favorite was the Mafe, because of its thick peanut sauce. Their interesting margaritas (ginger, hibiscus) are also good and well-balanced.

Our table was a little wonky, but the place had a lively, authentic atmosphere and a good crowd (lots of cute girls). 

The only problem came up when we tried to pay, and our server told us we couldn't use the certificate. After a bit of arguing and a 10-minute wait, they relented.
author: David Z.

description:
Full disclosure: If you're a female and you wanna get some, come here. It's a sure bet, ladies. I have not encountered such an over-the-top aggressive un-discriminating group of dudes since I was in Belize. But if you're game, this is your place. There are plenty of spicy men waiting for you who will be all about it.

Or you could come here with a guy and not have to deal with that dynamic (except if he leaves your side for even a moment to go the bar or bathroom!) But no, really, all that aside, I enjoy baobab. They have some pretty killer cocktails that aren't too expensive. They play (as much as I hate this term) "world music" and reggaeton and stuff, mostly. And people dance instead of just staring at the wall (imagine that at a DANCE club!) 

If I come here, I usually plan to end the night at beauty bar next door, but it can be a good starter place.
author: Shannon R.

description: Wow. Let me start by saying that good things usually happen when I am with this particular friend. How she chose this place, I can't say, but I am so glad she did! This was my first visit, and so I didn't really know what to expect. I liked 3 things on the menu, which told me that I was already going to come back another time. Then I ordered a Little Baobab House Cocktail (which was also our server's favorite drink). We mustve come at just the right time, because 15 min after we were done with dinner, they cleared our table to become a club. Within 30 minutes, the dance floor was full! The energy was incredible. I want to do that again :)
author: Alicia M.

description:
I've walked past here a few times, and finally had the chance to actually go in.  Much like other reviewers have pointed out, the place is pretty homey, with the waiters just chilling at the bar and chatting among themselves.  

Ian H, being a plantain fiend, ordered the Plantano, and when it came, kept making noises of extreme happiness every time he put a piece in his mouth.  20 minutes later, our main dishes came out.  I had the N'dole, which is some sort of lamb in a very heavy peanut/spinach sauce with couscous.  Unfortunately, while the lamb itself was tender, the sauce was overly heavy and salty and overpowered any flavor that the lamb itself had.  The couscous was pretty dry flavorless too.  Meanwhile Ian had the grilled chicken kebab with salad, which he seemed to like, but once again, seemed too dry to me.  

In the end though, at least the food was interesting, and Ian liked it, so a three star review is what it gets!
author: Leon K.

description: Great food and atmosphere. The waiters are nice and this place is right on the strip of mission next to other great restaurants. I end up order two of their coconut rum drink, which has the right amount of coconut and rum, its not over powering.
author: Bonnie D.

description:
I was visiting a friend in San Francisco who happened to live 2 blocks away from the main strip of The Mission. Needless to say, there was a lot to do the few days I was there.

One evening we stopped by Little Baobab due to the fact everything else looked completely packed (it was crazy to see steam flowing out of the bar next door).

Right off the bat, there was a really chill vibe about the place. It was dimly lit and had scattered tables and chairs. It is supposed to have an African theme/style.

We decided to have dinner there and it was awesome. I don't remember what my friend had, but it was some kind of roasted bird and quite tasty. I had the lamb curry and that was awesome as well.

We arrived a little late, so we got to stay as the place transformed from a restaurant to a full-fledged bar as tables were cleared away and a DJ setup while people started dancing.

Once that happened, there was AWESOME drinks that I had never thought could work. A hibiscus cocktail? A tamarind cocktail? Really? Yeah... really. It was all excellent and fun.

I will admit it was very hot and a bit crammed inside... but it was fun. Tasty drinks and everyone shaking furiously to those addictive Afro-Beats... is that really a problem?

Check it out.
author: P.A. P.

description: Went here for a large dinner party (we had a reservation for 20). It definitely seems like a hole in the wall from the outside, but I was pleasantly surprised. The interior decor although very festive and nice, has some bits lacking like the exposed drywall that never got seamed, but it still has a nice ambiance that makes you ignore those parts. Now, as for the food, at our table of 20, everyone loved their dishes. This seems like one of those places where you can't go wrong with what you order. Everything was good, and I loved that tamarind and hibiscus were a bit of a theme (in the drinks too). At 10, they took away the tables and it turned into a dance club, with good music that was a mix of african, latin, reggae, and pop. It kept you moving, and was an all around good time. Our group danced for about 2 hours and left just past midnight, where we saw people waiting to get in outside, and it seemed like they may have to pay a cover if you hadn't been there for dinner before hand. Only negative: the bathroom door doesn't lock... which makes you pretty nervous and it's best to go with a friend so they can watch the door to make sure no once barges in on you. Also- there was a sign that you can't flush the toilet paper, so you had to throw it in the garbage container next to the toilet... NOT appealing. All in all, I'll definitely recommend it to people, but next time I go, I'm using my bathroom at home right before and avoiding theirs at all costs. But the food, ambiance, and good service make up for it in spades. Go try it!
author: Adriana W.

description:
Hands down one of the best little places in the city to take a friend from 
out of town or just enjoy a wonderful meal. Great food, unique atmosphere, good music, and reasonable prices make this place one of
my favorites!  You will love it!
author: Andrea B.

description:
Went on a Friday night for dinner - food and drink was great. Very busy, I would have liked my water refilled more often (a lot more often), but I can understand with the crowd they had. Tried the Kenyan beer and was pretty damn impressed! 

We started with the Aloko, or fried plantains with tamarind sauce. I could not get enough of the sauce, so good! The plantains were unlike others I've had, they were not crispy and french fry-like, they were slightly mushy, but not in a bad way, and I think I would have rather had them for dessert. My dinner-mate was not impressed with the plantains. 

For our entrees, I had the Tiep Dien (red snapper), and it was great. The rice was delicious, and the sauce that was over the fish was YUM! There was some sort of root-like vegetable thing that was on the plate that I didnt care for so much, but it was easy enough to push it aside! My mate tried the Dibi and was confident that he'd gotten the better plate. 

Was too stuffed for dessert! Will have to come back again!
author: Aryn Y.

description:
Best music in town.  Don't dress in layers here because, inside this happenin' place, it gets downright tropical.

Freeze your ass off on the way over, but seriously, wear a silk shirt or a soccer jersey (guys) because it gets hot hot hot inside.  Girls, wear your mini-skirts and show some leg, dammit.  If you have nice gams, Baobab is a great place to show them off.

Even functionally, ça marche.  When it's hot, wear less clothing! :)

Just a suggestion to SF girls: Dress like the hot feminine girls in NYC, LA, London, Hong Kong and Paris for once!   More skirts, less blue jeans please.  San Francisco has too many girls-wearing-jeans-to-go-out for my liking, but whatever.  I digress.

Marco plays the best stuff, and all the hits I recognized from Paris and Marseille can be heard in, of all places, San Francisco, CA!!

Did I mention that it's hot and humid inside?  Okay, good!

Go to Baobab and dance the night away, buy lots of drinks, tip your bartender, and be careful not to damage the "Le footballer" painting on the wall that I hope Marco will sell to me someday! :)
author: Justin C.

description:
Note this review is for dinner only. The food was fairly good and their happy hour, Mon-Thur is a definite bargain - $20 for any appetizer, entree, dessert and a well cocktail or beer! Hard to beat that! However, the restaurant missed the mark for me in many other ways.

I came here with my husband just a little before 7 and we were the only ones there. The server was very sweet but SLOW. It took us about 15 mins to just to get our beers. Also, the funky smell of the space was a bit overwhelming for me and unfortunately took away from the tastiness of the food. 

I might give Little Baobab another try one day to go show off my dance moves but I think I'll skip dinner next time.
author: Foodie K.

description: I came here for the first time in 2009 on a really bad date. The food made up for the company so much so that I returned by my lonesome and with friends on many occasions. I ALWAYS get the coconut curry tilapia (I think that's what it's called)-soo good! Drinkwise you can't go wrong with the coconut rum.
author: Christina S.

description: What a fabulous find in the mission! So quirky! So unique! So San Francisco!! The cocktail menu was very tempting and I literally couldn't decide as everything sounded intriguing! We settled on a pitcher of lil baobab...vodka,tamarind and passion fruit! Can you say YUMMY! Then moved on to 4 appetizers...fried mashed potatoes,shrimp in creole sauce,fried plantains and the beef pastelles( my favorite!!!) my entree was the yassa...so full of flavor!!the meat falling off the bone(chicken) in a delicious mustard sauce with onions. My only complaint...the entree portion was small. (2 drumsticks is NOT an entree) They have a prix fixe menu before 7pm which is a great deal! Definatly going back for such a sassy restaurant in the sassy part of town!!
author: Joaquin G.

description: Went here on a Saturday night with two girlfriends. I was really looking forward to it because I'm so sick of damn top 40's boring music and I'd heard so many good things about the awesome beats here. The bouncer outside let the three of us in for $10 which was really sweet. We got there at 10:30 and the dancing didn't really pick up till 11. It got super packed but it didn't really matter. We had the best time just grooving to the music. Some guys are a bit pushy, but they'll lay off quick if you politely scoot away. On the plus side they CAN DANCE...GOOD. We danced non stop till about 1:30 and relucantly had to go. Can't believe I never came here before, but will definitely be back.
author: Sandra M.

description: Well-attended Cuban salsa night on Wednesdays. Ample-enough dance floor. $5 cover.
author: Inigo M.

description: Enjoyed a fantastic dinner here the other night. Need to go for the dancing sometime.
author: Michael T.

description:
Yeah, an update of a perfect review...with another perfect review may seem silly to you, but I just love it THAT much!!

I have two more things for you Baobab:

GET AIR CONDITIONING.....please :)  I'd even be willing to pay more in cover to help sponsor this seemingly obvious idea

Hibiscus Margarita was strong and exotic, just like I like my men ;)
author: Jessica J.

description: I am so glad we tried this place. My husband's ginger pineapple juice was a fresh treat, and I really liked my hibiscus drink, too. Neither was too sweet, just refreshing.
