Decor is humble, and we almost left because it seemed dumpy. Our table wobbled and the furniture is like free stuff. But, our server was so nice, and the food was fresh and tasty. I ordered a red curry lamb stew with couscous, and it was a winner. The Afro-pop music was fun, too.
author: Idena S.

description: Small place, not impressive, ridiculous $5 cover, poor drinks. Connected to Bollyhood, much cooler place, little classier, better music (live) and better dancers and much better drinks. They would not let us bring our drinks from one side to the other... kinda ghetto, then we realized that the drinks on the Bollyhood side were much better anyways. Lots of hipsters. Still looking for a better African music hangout.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Loved the cozy and comfy vibe.  It felt like I was transported to another world outside of the city, and that there should be sandy coves and splashing dolphins outside the door, instead of piss-stained trash cans and bus stops.  
The food and drinks were yummy, satisfying, and cheap.  I suppose it would have been nice to have more selections to choose from, but whatev.
The hummus was delish.
The chocolate cake a la mode was to die for, seriously.  I even made some annoying coos of pleasure with every bite.  We could not have been more pleased.
Also, the friendly service was over the top awesome.
author: Lacy T.

description:
Saturday night, friend's birthday dinner, new destination in the Mission that has awesome yelp reviews...wooootah!  Psych. What a let down.

I write this review as 1 member of 5, out of a group of 10, that were completely dissatisfied with this place (math is hard, half of us liked it, half of us didn't).  Service was slow and spotty.  Our reservation was for 8:00 pm and we didn't get our food until 9:45 pm.  Mind you, the place turns into a dance club at 10:00 pm (and not a minute later) so by 10:01 pm dinner was forcefully over (no major disappointment as I was not really planning on eating my tofu mush anyways).  Drinks are delicious, but prepare to feel more sober then you arrived after finishing a couple (I will suggest that this might have to do with the extreme amount of sugar, oh, and the fact they have no alcohol in them).

UGH. The dancing.  Don't even get me started on the dancing.  Now, I will preface this with: I am not much of a dancer.  But after a few (real) drinks, decent beats, and an inviting crowd, I can get down with the best of them.  Let's just say, no bueno.  I haven't been gropped this badly since my unfortunate decision to head to Tijuana for my 18th birthday.  All I needed was a whistle and someone pouring tequila down my throat.

I would have given it "0" stars, but like I said, half my friends did dig this place.  I will leave you with this:  Don't go hungry.  Don't go sober.  And don't go without some sort of proper stun gun to get the 45-year-old lurper off your backside.
author: Kristin C.

description:
Went here for happy hour on a Wednesday. Great vibe. Took advantage of the cheap happy hour deal of 1 cocktail or beer, 1 appetizer, 1 entree, and 1 dessert all for $20 (between 6-730pm). Can't beat that! The food was tasty and everyone enjoyed the evening.

Hibiscus margaritas (Tatus) were off the hook. I'm not a connoisseur of alcohol, but it was enough to get your buzz on. It's a creepa! Good music, but the real music/dancing doesn't start til 10pm. 

Will definitely be back.
author: Carolyn J.

description:
I came here for dinner last night and it was great.  I got the chicken skewers and they were super tasty.  I particularly loved the gombo.  mmmm.  They had good service and were quick in spite of it being crowded and working in a tiny kitchen.  

It's definitely a place I would go to again! :)
author: F K.

description:
I've been here a couple times with one of my friends... both times were pretty fun.  They play some fun music and there are lots of people dancing.  Great place for dancing.  Girls, beware you will get hit on, but who doesn't need an ego boost every now and then?  Really a fun little place.

My only complaint is that the last time I came here, they had a big cooler of water in the corner, which was awesome after dancing my ass off.  This time, no water, had to buy a bottle.
author: Samantha B.

description:
We went there for dinner and had a groupon for appetizer, entree and cocktails. The food was great, it was not only supper yummy it was also presented super cute! The couscous and rice came in heart shape and I would have never expected the place to be that good, since it is kind of hidden. 

We had the shrimp coconut curry, which was only a little bit too sweet for me, (since i don't like sweet as much) ,so for everybody else it is probably fine:))but the shrimp and couscous were great. We also had the plantains as appetizer and the beef filled pastries and they were great. My boyfriend had yassa with lamb and loved it!

Definitely going back there!
The cocktails were great too, I had a hibiscus margarita and it was great!
author: Marie F.

description:
I randomly went here one night with my boyfriend at the time's friend and her roommate. 

The club is pretty small, but the bouncers/door staff do a good job of keeping the number of people inside to a certain number so it never feels too crowded. I really liked that feature of this bar/club.

Everyone on the dance floor was having a fun time dancing the night away without the annoying bummed into feeling that you get a lot at some other clubs. 

I'd come again for a special event or if brought by another friend.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Let me give you the REAL breakdown regarding this club:

1) White girls who love African/Jamaican/etc. guys and music,  love this place.
2) The place is tiny, the dance floor is smaller than small (hold 15 people)
3) Crowd is mostly Black guys and a few white girls (most are not even attractive), but the Black, African, Jamaican guys are all over them.
4) This is another case of below average girls getting lots of attention.

This place is only fun if you are white girl  (like I mentioned above) or a African/Jamaican/Black guy who will dance with anything.  Real Talk!
author: One Black Mans POV.. ..

description:
5 stars for Wednesday nights salsa.

I had H-E-L-L-A Fun! I had such a great time here! good Music with DJ Walt Digz on Wednesdays! Through all the salsa music, he even threw in some bachata and that put an extra big smile on my face! Don't be afraid to ask a dude to dance, worst case scenario, he doesn't know how to.

$4 bottled beers.
 and I loved LOVED their hibiscus/ginger drink. If you take a look around a lot of people were holding that brown plastic cup with a straw.
1 bathroom for everyone. lots of places to sit (along the wall or window). 
$3 cover =)
author: Maureen M.

description:
A guaranteed good time. It's pretty seedy, dark, and cramped; perfect for Jamaican dancehall riddims, reggae, soca and other Caribbean sounds.   It can get too crowded [and will] but so long as you bring your buffer gals, it's all lovely.  

There's a very diverse crowd and you'll see all sorts of characters. Some of said characters might try to rub up against you repeatedly under the guise of trying to squeeze through the masses but a swift elbow to the ribs should take care of it. Otherwise, you'll definitely have ample opportunity to work out your tensions and joys out on the dance floor. 

Try not to bring a jacket or purse because there's really no room for it and it'll likely wind up drenched in sweat and spilled drinks.  There's a regular there who wears a fanny pack.  He is trying to act like there's absolutely nothing hideous about it, so you could easily join him in that wildly futile affair.

Good times.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
I ABSOLUTELY LOVE the music here.  Ecletic, diverse, international or bedonkshakeable (as Jessica T. so eloquently put it)...whatever you want to call it.  The DJ is there to make you move and he's quite good at what he does.

And the cover is only $5!  ($3 if you get there early enough).  What a bargain!  And on top of that they have a coat check which is uber important for us older folks who no longer think it's cute to sacrifice freezing to death in order to be cute (and half naked).  And half naked is actually the appropriate attire for this club.  Not because Little Baobab has a sleazy vibe or anything, but because around midnight on a Saturday night, it gets packed and hot as hell inside.  I actually had to leave the dancefloor a couple of times because I couldn't breathe... 

But I refuse to dock this place one star for my claustrophobic experience.  To avoid the same fate, get here early or come on a Friday night or weekday to avoid the crazy crowd.
author: LaSha G.

description:
I wish I could give this place 3.5 ... oh wait.. I am giving it 3.5 :) 

The food was pretty good ... a few minus' for 
A. not having serving spoons. or sharp knives..  
B. Serving us cold fried platinos (they should be scorching inside ) if it's fried and cold .. it's been pre-prepared ... 
C.well.. there is no C.... all in all it was a good experience and the prices are reasonable .. I want to come back when it's jumpin on a Friday and people are dancing and sweating the place up.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I love the idea of Little Baobab, but the food was just okay. Came here with Steph P., and Sooj O., before the free Native Guns show at The Elbo Room. 

We started with the fried plantains. It was good, although Steph and I were longing for a little sugar sprinkled on top, but the tamarind dipping sauce eventually grew on us. The meat in our entrees (lamb and chicken) was overcooked, so the meat was tough. The tofu curry was very mild and lacking flavor, but maybe that's just how it supposed to taste. I will say that the couscous was excellent, very light and fluffy, and probably the best I've ever had.

It's a bit cramped inside, but it wasn't crowded on a Monday night, so it wasn't that big of a deal. I think I want to try this restaurant's big brother, Bissap Baobab, to see if the food is any better over there, but I'd rather explore the rest of the Mission first.
author: Arnold G.

description:
Wife and I headed to Little Baobab to celebrate my wife's college friend turning in her Dissertation for her PhD. She's wanted to go to Little Baobab to dance the night away. So off to SF and the Mission District we went to celebrate. 

We got to Little Baobab around 11PM. The best way to describe it is a shack playing really loud music you can hear down the block. There was no line to get in but there was a $5 cover. We paid the cover and walked in and holy sardine city, this place was packed. And by packed I mean you barely enough room to move in the place. If the fire Marshall came, this place was definitely be over the person capacity and they would probably fine the place. 

I managed to get us to a spot where we can leave our jackets and try to squeeze into the dance floor. My wife and her friend went to the bar to get drinks (I figured being girls they had a better chance of getting served than I would) and they managed to squeeze their way to get drinks. Low and behold in a crowded bar, 5 minutes later, they had our drinks. I have to say the prices for beer on tap here is pretty cheap. I think my wife said for all the drinks they paid under $10. Pretty good price for beer on tap on a Friday Night. 

So off to dancing they went. As I said before the place was crowded, and it seemed like they let even more people in. I guess their policy is if you got $5 bucks, they're going to let you need. At one point it was so packed in there we could hardly move, let alone dance. The other problem, was the music was so loud. I think my wife and her friend said it was a combination of Reggatone, Caribbean, and Afrocentric Music, to me and my poor ears, it was just loud thumping music that made my ears rings all the way home to the East Bay. 

Also 2 disturbing things here, it's a gropefeast and they guys here are extremely aggressive and don't get no for an answer. My wife on more than one occasion when someone tried to cut in on us pointed to her ring on her finger and pointed to me and they would turn around and see me and I would nod and jerk my head and they got the clue. Her friend wasn't as fortunate and had to be a little bit more aggressive and just flat out rejects the guy and point to us. Other other thing is both my wife and her friend said on a couple of occasions they got groped by someone. Hell even I got my ass grabbed a coupled of times. Not sure if it was on purpose or by accident because it was so packed in there, none the less, it didn't make either one of the girls truly comfortable in Little Baobob. 

As to rating, I guess if I was in my 20's, into really loud music, and didn't have any issues with personal space, Little Baobab would be a fun place to come hand out at. But being in my 30's and married, I left all that behind me and for me Little Baobab is nothing but a place that is way too small, that plays way too loud of music, with way to many people trying to get a cheap feel on one an other. Not my way of spending a Friday Night and 2 stars for Little Baobab as a night club.
author: Chris C.

description:
I hadn't been in Little Baobob since a drunken birthday a couple of years ago. We ducked in for a couple of drinks before the Elite event at Bollyhood. 

The happy hour deals were incredible. 5 beers for $11.25. "Uh, I got this round."

It's a great spot, and apparently they're starting to serve up fast Senegalese eats. Sounds awesome.

They were nice enough to let me use the bathroom, after Bollyhood made the mistake of over-serving with only one toilet.
author: Jason R.

description: This place in TEENY. Literally a two tiered room. Room. BUT, the music is the best, reggaeton, dancehall, soca, yaruban beats, i heard magic system here the first time. It is perfect dance music. And people, please only come if you are going to dance or at least feel the music. Don't be creepy or awkward and try to stand and look cool, no room. Cocktails are good too, ginger, hibiscus and strong. Only come if you want to get grimey w/it...this is a small place for a small city, so please no haters.
author: Lily G.

description:
After living in this city for almost a year and trying to convince my friends every. single. weekend. to try Little Baobab with me, we FINALLY went. And it was quite possibly the BEST night of my life.

A little self disclosure: I lived in South Africa for 7 months, traveled the region and then went back to the most rockin' continent on this planet to chill in Ghana for awhile. I'm obsessed with Africa. Get me talking about my travels and I will NOT stop. So to find a little piece of authentic Africa here in San Francisco is like a dream come true.

We got there semi-early (10pm or so) on a Thursday so we didn't pay cover and the place wasn't very crowded. We instantly clicked with the bartenders (yummmy hibiscis drinks, but a little too sweet) and we started the dance party the second the DJ started spinning. He played awesome beats from Africa, reggae and a little hip-hop mixed in. From the decor to the clientele to the music, I felt like I was back in West Africa. The most authentic detail of this place? Over eager African men with amazing dance skills hitting on every girl in the place. But I couldn't complain because when someone can move that good you can forgive them for creeping all up on you. 

I intend to be a regular so if anyone wants to join me for some awesome dancing to great music, hot & friendly bartenders and a taste of Africa, I'll see you there!
author: Lauren B.

description:
I mean, i guess.

Went late on a Thursday night to hang out with some friends who couldn't stop talking about it.  Don't get it.  It's smaller then my friend Maggie Turdkinson's studio apartment, and let me tell you, Mags has a tiny apartment.  Her Boston terrier Rex has to live in a planter box outside.  Crazy little rascal, that Rex.  Attacked a cat once.

The ginger drink made me cry a little bit, somewhere between Titanic "I hope I find love like that" crying and Police Acadamy 4 "when will this pain cease" crying.  Closer to the latter.  

The dancing was pretty good.  Credit where it's due.

Just make sure you pee at home.
author: Mike A.

description:
Hmmm....reading about all the dancing at night makes me think this place might be better for drinks and for dancing than for food.  I've been looking for a low-key place with interesting music.

However, this review is for the food.  Last time I was at Little Baobab was over a year ago for dinner, and I guess it didn't make a huge impact on me cuisine-wise as I haven't returned despite being right in the neighborhood.

I returned when getting a phone call from Arnold G. saying that he was there with Steph P. for dinner and would I like to join them.  They are such good company that I will join them anywhere.

I give them kudos for frying the tofu right for the Cari Tofu dish.  It had that slight crispy exterior that I feel is perfect for pan-fried tofu.  However, the sauce was too unassuming and lacked spices.

The Chicken Mafe...eh.  Chicken was tough.  As Arnold G. pointed out, white meat chicken is not the easiest to cook.  I do feel, though, that any restaurant serving white breast chicken should learn not to overcook the breast.  Also, oddly, the chicken breast was a large chicken breast filet rather than chicken chunks.  For a dish where so much is about the sauce, I feel that the chicken filet is a disservice.  One wants maximum sauce-sopping opportunities. The sauce was okay, but I've made better chicken in peanut butter sauce myself (look up the Gourmet recipe for chicken and okra in peanut butter sauce on Epicurious...it's excellent.  Just remember to keep stirring so that it doesn't burn).  I always hate that feeling of paying for food in a restaurant that I can cook better myself.  What can I say...I am a penny-pincher that way.

The Lamb N'Dala (I am using Steph's reviews here to recall the names of the dishes...which I've promptly forgotten) was the best of the three dishes we got.  It was the most assertive and complex of the sauces.  However, the lamb cubes would have benefitted from being braised for a long time in an oven on low heat.

Plaintain...nothing special.  Something you can pan-fry quickly yourself  if you remember to get really ripe plaintains.

Price was cheap, roughly $14 per person.  But I can do better at Chutney or Pakwan, get more tender meats and spicier sauces.  I know it seems weird to be comparing Indian restaurants to a Sengalese restaurant, but the sauces have many similiarities.  I think next time I will skip the novelty of the Sengalese food, go to Pakwan, and head over this way for the dancing.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed this place (think I reviewed Bissap a while ago and then forgot its sister restaurant).

The atmosphere at Little Baobab is festive and colorful.  While Bissap Baobab around the corner has a fuller menu and more square footage, Little Baobob has a cozy, exotic DJ bar vibe.  I recommend the avocado + crab crevette as an appetizer, and either the peanut-sauce mafe tofu(or chicken) or the coconut shrimp or tilapia curry with cous cous as entrees.

If you come later in the evening, they clear out the tables and put on the hip hop/world/fusion beats.  Sometimes the cover is $5 so heads up, those of you who don't like to pay covers...
author: Sid D.

description:
Five stars for...

* the coconut liqueur stuff (an LB specialty, just ask for "the special coconut stuff"), damn, that knocked me out
* the island music scene (sometimes)
* the fact you can dance salsa to anything world music (wish I was a salsa dancer)
* the rough-and-tumble floor
* the $5 margaritas (yum)
* the casual atmosphere, trust me, you can dress however you please

This ain't LA, is it...thank god...:)
author: Abendigo R.

description: Wow.  I just went here last night for a birthday party.  I have never eaten Senegalese food so I'm not sure if it is authentic but it was so tasty.  I had the Gambas for appetizer and had the tilapia for main dish.  The gambas were in a sauce that was so flavorful our table ordered 3 rounds of pita just to keep dipping bread into the sauce.  The tilapia was tender and simple with a light salad and rice.  Yes, the salad was warm from being on the same plate but I like that it was included.  I don't know if it was the rum drink talking but even with the uneven, cramped tables and high noise level, I loved this place.  I will definitely go back for dinner and music.
author: Soo C.

description:
I'm semi notorious among my friends for--when I set my mind to it--embarrassing face sucking with bar randos. If I'm in that zone, and you cross my path and are moderately attractive, meaning taller than me (I'm 5'2) and retaining most of your teeth, we just might end up face rasslin in the middle of the dance floor to the sounds of Akon. 

LIl Baobab is my standby when I set out to accomplish this. The music, as everyone else has said, is FAB. The guys, when you are 8 Trax vodka tonics deep, are HAWT. And Say what you will about the crowding and all that, but I have NEVER EVER had a bad time here.
author: Annie G.

description: Like many others we came here for my friend's birthday.  The owner, Marco, was very nice and welcoming to us from the moment we first came into the restaurant.  It's rare to feel really so appreciated at a restaurant and Marco was checking up on us and other tables to make sure everyone was good.  He even gave us a free pitcher and dessert.  Will definitely be back again!
author: Sara H.

description:
Like a Senegalese group sauna. This place is sexy and cathartic if you're there in the right mood with the right people. And boy, were we.

-1 star for the chikan factor. Fellas, we're here to vibe, not play bootyguard.
author: Tom L.

description:
PLUS - Consistent good times since the day it opened - from my birthday feast here 7.5 years ago to some brown man jiving this past Thanksgiving weekend.

MINUS - Consistently saving female friends from aggressive  predatory vampires roaming the dancefloor in search of easy coochie coochie. 

PLUS: The music is awesome. Dancehall, African, Arabic, salsa. Great vibes emanating from the DJ's laptop. 

MINUS: The heat sucks. Especially when you try to take your water outside to cool off for 5 minutes but you learn that you can't because the bouncer has closed up that 2 foot fenced off patio for the night. 

PLUS: The drinks made with ginger, tamarind, or hibiscus are all great.

MINUS: I can't think of any others. Little Baobab thus ends up with a positive surplus.

Highly recommended to folks looking for something different than the usual bar/club scene. This is your little microcosm of internationalism right here. I may no longer live in walking distance, but I'll be back as often as I can.

4 stars.
author: Mr K.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. The crowd is so diverse, and the music is amazing! Drinks are super cheap as well. No complaints about this place, besides its $5 cover (still very cheap though).
author: Amanda V.

description:
In a neighborhood where people strive so hard for the authentic by wearing skinny jeans and neckerchiefs, it is refreshing to find a place that does not have to try at all.  Once you walk in, you have the distinct feeling that you have walked into a club in Dakar.

If you're looking for a something a bit different, check this place out.  The DJs play a great selection of African/Caribbean/Latin music that makes it impossible to stand still.  They pack 'em in here, and it gets really hot and sweaty, but as someone else said, it never feels icky.  In fact, it adds to the ambiance.

Even though I only go here every few months, somehow some of the the guys who work here remember me and address me in French.  I don't expect that doormen would ever take much interest in another dude trying to get into their place, let alone make friendly conversation, but these guys do.  And it is a really nice change.  

Advise to guys.  Hang on to your dates with BOTH hands.
author: James M.

description:
This place is great, but way too crowded on weekends (unless that's what you're looking for)

The drinks are amazing. Fruity, but not sweet or gloopy. 

So, living in the city long enough you understand that anything worth doing is kept relatively underground. Wednesday night salsa is one of those "secrets". Most of the dancers seemed as if they were regulars as they changed partners after almost every song. So fun to watch! Everyone there was there to have fun. All the girls were wearing flats--that's how you know they mean business. Super friendly, too. Will be back.
author: J-Meoww W.

description:
It is what it is, and that's is A-OK. Drinks are cheap and the music is always predictably African/house dance mix.

Be warned:
It's a dinky place, you will sweat and one way or another you will get someone else's sweat on you. DOnt like that- save your five bucks and go to everywhere else (where no one really dances).
Did I mention teh drink are cheap and the music predictable? 
It's a good things as Martha would say!

and NO, I'm not looking at you, Beauty Bar. You're the same, but just shittier cause no one can ever move and... and I'm just not that into you!
author: Jonas D.

description:
Have you ever had food from Senegal? Me neither. But Little Baobab has me hooked. 

At first walking into the place I was a little bit weary... the kitchen is small (like the size of a bathroom small) and there was only one server working... all signs pointing to the likely possibility of having a not so great experience. 

However once I received my hibiscus margarita my mind was COMPLETELY changed. 

Even better was the food. The spices and seasonings used to cook the chicken dish I ordered were out of this world yummy. I practically licked my plate clean. Classy, eh? But it was just so good. 
So, SO good.
author: Homechicken P.

description: My boo and I came here to have drinks, dinner and more drinks with two very good friends. We made a reservation in advance so there was no waiting around and our waitress was friendly and efficient. The drinks and food was exactly what our moods and taste buds were searching for that night. And then the music got good and it became official. I loved this place. Hands down one of my favorites.
author: Pracheta T.

description:
You know this is one of those places when I walk in no matter what it reminds me of a hut-bar any where in a major slum city in Africa (trust me I was born there) where the homes are built from mud and the furniture is sparse but the crowd is absolutely divine. 

Every time I have gone here since it's first opening I have had a great time leaving with enough laughter and liquor in my belly. The ginger and vodka w/ cran is of course my standard at Little Baobab. 

I remember one night meeting 2 guys from Morocco (one of whom I will call Mr Touchy) and here we are chatting it up about our families , life back home in the mother land , about the fact that Mr Touchy  has  a girlfriend ...blah blah blah blah... (like I give a hoot...while of course am giving goo goo GA GA eyes) and having drinks which led to last call and we ended up sharing a cab home. Of course with anyone a bit inebriated the sexes can get confused (Oh please...another excuse) and of course next thing you know dude is rubbing my legs and am like "YO ... u got a girlfriend what's up with that?... not that I mind... (should have been minding my own business and could have been invited up for a night cap or it could have turned into a knee cap considering the job to be done).

... so anyways weeks go by and Bambi is at the O'Farrell and Mason Garage getting the rental and who do I spot Mr Touchy and his dude date (holding hands) ... so much for his Gf and so much for my weak ass Gay  radar... well u win some and you lose some... 

But for sure good times will be had at Little Baobab alone or with friends.
author: Teddy d.

description:
Nigerian Hottie: "You're a tease, Michelle."
Me: "Huh?"
Nigerian Hottie: "Are you a dancer?"
Me: "Yes."
Nigerian Hottie: "Oh, that explains it."

I LOVE Afro-Fusion Thursday nights.  Viscerally stimulating beats, hibiscus martinis, $3 cover with a plentitude of flavah.  Mmm...it does a body and soul good.
author: michelle s.

description:
Great for dinner...then the tables are cleared for dancing.

The food is excellent and definitely affordable for the quality. Everything that my party of 4 had was good.  Thursday and Fridays great music, eclectic crowd and dancing.  Although place is very small, there is a bit of seating and strong drinks !
author: Katie L.

description:
I fought Adam over coming here and it turns out I was wrong. This place is awesome. Unlike others here, I really liked the food (though the plantains were slightly overdone, but the main dishes were excellent, perfectly spiced and plenty to go around) and the girlie drinks were great. Sitting outside on a warm summer night made me want to go to Senegal.

If I could add a sixth star for the hot, sweet guy who served us, I would. Sometimes I really am wrong about things.
author: Allison L.

description:
I like Little Baobab before it gets super crowded. Head here early for an intimate little dinner with friends before they clear out the little tables for dancing to DJ music. The ginger-infused cocktails are amazingly intoxicating (yes, pun intended). They are unique and delicious. The food is just as good as at Bissap Baobab. If you have more than four peeps in your group, get there early so that everyone can be seated as there is not much seating there. 

When the DJ starts, this place gets packed, _packed_, fast. Now you understand why all the chairs and tables are taken away. The dancing is pretty good until there's no room to even sway side to side and some inconsiderate couple decides they want to take up the floor doing wild swing moves. I have to take a star away due to the crowd mob effect.
author: Jen A.

description: Love the dipping sauce with the fried plantain. Love the sauce with the Gambas. Yassa is off the hook. My favorite is the mafe. Definitely GOOD EATS!  ENJOY!
author: Dave And Teenz Q.

description: After the whole plastic-ring-in-the-Mafe-Tofu debacle, I was a little gun-shy to go back to Little Baobab. Rest assured, all is good in the world between us now. My last meal there was excellent, inexpensive and plastic-free. Phew! I was so sad after my last review. I look forward to dining and drinking there again soon!
author: Susie D.

description:
Truly a challenging salsa dance floor, if I do say so myself.

And, far be it from me to complain, but a lot of "technically" illegal groping and grinding goes on on the dance floor--and off (there being v little actual boundary between the dance floor and the standing room).

Nonetheless, and perhaps because my housemate works the door on the weekends, I heart this place, and go way more than I should.

Hence the 4th star.

Put that in your ginger-hibiscus cocktail and stir it.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
THE ONLY REASON I CROSS THE BRIDGE TO SF!!! I LOVE this place. Its such a charming little oasis in the midst of all of the "chic" cold pretentious SF clubs. 
Tamarind and Whiskey? hell YEAH!
author: Suzanne D.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Friday night for a friend's birthday and stayed for the dancing afterward.  They graciously accomodated our party of about 20 despite telling them only the day beforehand that we were coming.  They sat us outside, and luckily it was a beautiful September night, warm enough to sit outside without a coat!

We started with a pitcher of their "Rose" cocktail.  If I remember correctly it is vodka mixed with cranberry and ginger.  I liked it so much it was all I drank the rest of the night, though others in my party branched out and tried the other drinks, all of which were made with FRESH fruit juice.

The food was decent.  The appetizers were great, but my entree of shrimp kebabs was disappointing.  To start, try the sauteed shrimp and the fried bananas. 

After dinner, when they clear away the tables for the dance club, the place picked up.  They gave us stamps so we wouldn't have to pay the cover, and when we were finished with dinner we headed inside, as you can't have any alcohol outside after 10.  It was really fun, as the music is different from anything I'd been to in SF, and I felt like I could dance with my friends without having to worry about being hit on by sketchy guys.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Their $20 happy hour dinner deal is a steal! $20 for a cocktail, appetizer, entree, and a dessert per person. My roommate and I decided to get something different from each other so we could sample as many menu items as possible.  So between two of us, we had the avocat creole (stuffed avocado with spicy crab and rice-delicious!!!) and the baobab gambas for appetizer (shrimps in a spicy, yumm broth). For our entrees, we had the Crevette Coco, a plate of shrimps with your choice of couscous or rice covered in coconut milk cream sauce (kinda similar to thai curry..this was my favorite dish of the night), and the N'Dole, a huge plate of spicy lamb in a peanuty spicy sauce with couscous or rice. For dessert, we got one of each of the 2 selections they had: the warm chocolate cake and the mango melba, which is just vanila ice cream over mango and covered with caramel/chocolate sauce. For our cocktails, we got the the Flamboyant (hibiscus lime vodka) and the Little Baobab cocktail, my favorite!! It had hints of passion fruit and tamarind.  The flavors melded perfectly! I got an extra one cus it was so good and it gave me a lovely buzz :)

This was the second time I came here.  The first time I came, I decided to go vegetarian and ordered the Mafe Tofu.  It was good, but I heard the Chicken Mafe is much better.  

All in all, my experience here was lovely.  Our server was a cute young man who was in training still, but we thought he did a fabulous job! Super friendly staff, great food and drinks, exotic music, and a cute little intimate space.  Great for dates!  I hear they have dancing and a dj at night, so I must check that out one day.  I hear it's really fun!  I recommend going on Monday nights so you can get a little taste of everything.  For $20, you can really get the Senegalese food experience and a lot of it too.  I came out with a big buddha belly. YumYum!
author: Kimba V.

description:
This review is strictly for the Little Baobab on Saturday late-night, which should not be allowed unless you have lost a bet to a cruel foe or are caught up in a web of friends and don't know the people in charge well enough to talk them out of it. Black light: bad idea. Getting knocked around by sticky people doing the Butterfly while waiting for the homeless gas-station bathroom: bad idea. Standing anywhere near the dance floor: bad idea. Why? You will get bumped and ground by sweat-slicked predators hoping you'll fall for the whole "Woo! I'm on a tropical vacation!" vibe and give up an easy one night stand. 

The drinks are still delicious, especially the tamarind one, but you can go have a nice meal at the big Baobab around the bend. But apparently it's not so bad here if you come early for happy hour.
author: Katrina D.

description:
solid spot. I've been there a few times and I always have a blast. The music is on point and I feel really good vibes every time I go. I dance, I smile, I cry, and I get my belly shaking in all directions. I don't know what it is. 

Also, I suggest dancing (or posting up) right below the vent near the DJ. You won't get too hot and you will be able to catch a whiff of the bacon wrapped hot dog action going on outside the place...
author: Tony R.

description:
Little Baobab is an awesome little hole in the wall club that plays "world music"- reggaeton, salsa, afrobeats, & other good shit. The cover is cheap- only $5, which you cant beat with a bat. The place gets so crowded that you end up dancing with strangers on accident, but I think that's part of this place's allure. I came here a few saturday nights ago with my sister & her entourage to meet my girls from college. Despite the spot not being very big at all, I kept losing my peoples because of the place being so dark and crowded. 

My only complaint is the same complaint I have with all san francisco locations: lack of parking. I think we ended up parking somewhere on valencia six blocks away. My college friend warned me, "you have to wear comfortable shoes because you are going to be taking a jesus walk & you only come to baobab to dance. There's no room to stand."

Great advice that I recommend the ladies to follow- do not wear heels the night you decide to go to baobab!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Little Baobab was a refreshing change in attitude from SoMA clubs that I've been to.  Many of these SoMA clubs, in my opinion, have all the Hollywood pretentiousness but none of the hawtness.  I've been to a few other clubs in SF, and found that the ghetto element is present no matter where you go.  Little Baobab certain did provided the certain expected ghetto element, but it was mixed with interesting music, cheap drinks, and mixed crowd.  In a little shoebox space.  It can get crowded.  

There was a $5 cover, and after that, the beers are $3, and the special margaritas were $5.  Parking may be a challenge, but park on parallel streets to mission and you'll be fine.  Come here for the cheap drinks and interesting music.  Don't come here to seek luxury.
author: Leo C.

description:
I have only been here once, so there's room for revisions in this review.  We went to LIttle Baobab on a Tuesday night, mostly cuz I was curious about the food already, but also because of many of the good yelp reviews.  Apparently Tuesday night's not a big dancin' night or at least not early on...  But the music was fun.  and loud.

I thought the food was pretty darn good.  In fact, the first thing I thought of when I woke up the next day was how bummed I was to have left my leftovers there...  :(   My favorite thing, though, which I highly highly recommend is the shrimp gambo appetizer.  I couldn't get enough of the sauce.  I asked for more bread and could have even asked for a third round of bread.  My friend was making fun of me as I barely touched my entree but couldn't get enough of this appetizer.  mmm.  I want it right now.  and it's only 10am.
author: Kerry L.

description:
WOW WOW WOW --- it's all I can say about Little Baobab. I am so used to places with house and trance that I've missed out on places like this one with world music that rocked! I could have danced for hours in there...

Yeah, some really creepy peeps can be found, but no place is secure from that, so don't let that ruin your evening. I can't wait to go there again --- what a great night!
author: Katja S.

description:
I will say Little Baobab is my home away from home. I am from Jamaica and since I have moved to California I have not been able to recreate that familiar feeling of the islands.  I have been to Little Boabab four weekends in a row and absolutely love it.  I am pretty much against admission to clubs. I think after age of 26 years old you pretty much stop paying to get into places. If you have to pay then you know the crowd is too young.  The admission cost is only $5.00 so I don't mind.  The cocktails there are scrumptious but do not MIX because you will get sick. I normally stick with the Tamarind, Ginger, and Whiskey drink. I can only handle two of them, strong and good.  They are reasonably priced and well worth the $$. 

The music is amazing!!!! I love the reggae, roots, and African beats. They make my body respond in ways that I can't describe... ha ha ha ha! The only fall back is how damn CROWDED it is. Every one is shoulder to shoulder and it is HOT as in heat!  I normally do not like crowded places but like I said it reminds me of back home.  The sweaty crowded experience contributes to the African pulsating rhythms of  UNITY.  A very diverse crowd, which I love.  All races, all classes, all together having a good time. This is not your stand around and talk kind of place if you are not ready to move your body then stay home.
author: Yanicke W.

description:
I actually prefer Little Baobab over its big brother Bissip Baobob a block away...Little Baobob is a little more intimate and rustic, and isn't nearly as noisy and crowded with hipsters.  Everything I've ordered so far has been GREAT and I the funky cocktails are cool too. I've never found this place too crowded, but I think I've mostly come early or on weeknights as its close to my pad.  I've heard on weekends both Baobobs can have a pretty long wait or you need reservations.

 Its hard to compare Sengelese food to any other cuisinse, but I love it and its very unique.  Rich, spicy but not hot, earthy...I need a Baobob fix at least once a month.
author: Peter S.

description:
If you've ever wanted to know what it feels like to be the most sought-after girl in the room, visit Little Baobab on a Saturday night. Men will be all up in your stuff no matter what shape, size, or color you are -- it's kind of flattering, but you have to be in the mood for that much attention (at least I do).

It's hot, it's sweaty, it's tiny, and it's always packed. The crowd is diverse, the music funky, and the drinks delicious. Avoid the bathroom if you can.
author: Vandana M.

description: We came here our first night in san francisco on recommendation from the nordstrom concierge women. Good recommendation!! We had the best time here. When we first arrived there was this awesome band just jamming and a bunch of hippies. Then a dj came and played some awesome dancing music. I felt like I was in a huge house party and not at a club or a bar. Awesome time,  Icould have stayed here all night!
author: Amanda K.

description:
After close to a year of walking past this place and sighing wistfully (because my friends aren't generally comfortable eating and paying for much else than burritos), I finally came in last night. I am so happy I finally  did, because the food was absolutely delicious. My friend and I ordered the plantains to start with, and he had the lamb with couscous and I had the coconut seafood dish with couscous. We each had tasty fruity cocktails and finished off the meal with yogurt with nutmeg, raisins and couscous. We spent the entire length of the dinner marveling at how amazing our food tasted and offering each other more tastes.

The wait staff was very attentive and polite, and they offered to make my coconut dish with fish AND shrimp. This seems like a great place to bring a date. Most dishes are about $12.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Terenga Bass Sessions. Have you truly gone and left?
Was here to check out the Terenga Bass Sessions, which I heard have since said their good-byes and are no longer holding their Thursday jam sessions. To hear this amazing mix of hip-hop, world music, and various jumbles of genres thrown together by an emcee, DJ, and other supporting artists was totally worth the $3 cover and $5-7ish hibiscus drink at the bar. Cozy, small, dark, and sexy, Little Baobab had to be the perfect venue to check out something cool without the hipster thumb nose of pretentiousness. Despite there being no Terenga-ing, I would definitely want to come back--this place, though small in size, is so unique and it's vibe ever fresh and chic.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This is where I drank all of thos hibiscus margaritas.  They were only $5 apiece!  And they were GREAT!

I wanted to try the food here, but by the time I decided I wanted to eat, they were shutting down the kitchen and moving the tables away for salsa dancing.  It started getting quite packed so I decided it was time to go since I knew I wouldn't be dancing.

I'll be back - if for nothing other than the good, cheap booze!
author: MoMo D.

description: When my dad jokingly suggested Senegalese food for dinner, I decided to call his bluff, and lo and behold Yelp turned up Little Baobab. Oddly enough, I'd been before, on a Saturday night when the beats were pumping, which isn't exactly my parents' scene. But undaunted, I followed through, and we showed up just after they opened their doors on a Wednesday evening, in time to share a tasty happy hour cocktail - score! Our waitress was friendly, patient and helpful, and helped us select a couple entrees and appetizers to share. While waiting, we admired the chill music (more chill than I'd remembered, likely due to the difference in my timing) and the clever decor. The food was great - not too heavy, very flavorful, and certainly the best-tasting Senegalese food I've ever had. We may go again.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I've been going to Little Baobab for a long time, for the food, but mainly for the dancing and nightlife.  It's the best little hole in the wall dance joint in the city.  They used to not have a cover, but then it'd get so crowded you couldn't move.  5 bucks is what they charge now, but that's still cheap.  It still gets crowded as hell though; but that's part of the charm.  If you don't mind rubbing elbows and knees with your fellow dancers then this is the place for you.

They play great music, mainly world, with a strong African emphasis, and the people are fantastic.  It's very multi-cultural and international, different people from everywhere and all walks of life, and the vibe is upbeat and non-aggressive.  Often people dance by themselves.

It's gotta be one of the funnest places to dance and have a good time.
author: Ramon C.

description:
Last weekend, my lovely friend hosted her birthday dinner here.  Let me just say, I wasn't sure what to expect of a restaurant where the closest ATM can only be reached through a gate, but it was fantastic!  We got there, sat around for a while waiting for our friends, and didn't get pressure from our  beautiful server to get orders going.  AND, because it was my friend's b-day (and we had more than 6 people), we got a FREE pitcher of margaritas.  Let me just say, those are dangerous margaritas!  

Anyway, we had a lot of questions about the menu, and everything was explained to us in a lot of detail so we could decide if the dish was right for us.  You can tell that the people who work here really care about the quality of the food.  After we ate a fantastic meal (try the hummus w/ pita--it's super super fresh!, and the N'Dole--kind of a spicy lamb stew), they put aside the tables, and the dancing commenced.  

I had such a good time considering I was crammed in such a small space, and even though I spent an incredible amount of money on margaritas (I think they must put something in the Hibiscus kind that makes you keep ordering more until you spend all of your money), it was a really good deal.  My only regret--the last margarita (I suppose it's always that way, right?).  We were all feeling it the next day, and let me say, it was not fun!  I'm going to stick to beer from now on.

But, for a reasonable price, you will eat a fantastic meal, be surrounded by beautiful (but down to earth) people, and you can get your dance on for hours!
author: Aim B.

description:
A beautiful, refreshing reminder that delicious food exists for under $100 a plate in our fair town. We started with the stuffed avocado with shrimp and succumbed to their fun hibiscus cocktails (no wine here, ah well). And entrees: I had not had mafe since a Senegalese friend made it for me a decade ago. It makes you grateful not to have a nut allergy, I'll tell you what! The lamb was the real highlight though. We got the dishes with couscous, which would have been better in my opinion if it didn't have little pieces of corn and lima beans in it (so something my mom would do--"Look, little frozen veggie bites in your starch, makes it practically healthy!").

Despite the excellent fare, I'm guessing the majority of the patrons come here b/c of the perfect female specimen of a cinnamony Senegalese woman who works there.

And if the mafe and the goddess server aren't enough to soothe your soul, the immortal Bob Marley crooning in the background should take care of the rest. Every little things gonna be alright, jah.
author: Gretchen T.

description: Good food, though over priced for what it was. Servings were small, and the prices were high for the amount of actual meat in the dishes. We had a high bill for four and I was expecting it to be so much more. It also took a long time to get service, and they forgot two things that we ordered. You shouldn't have to chase after someone for something that you are paying for. A little disappointing....
author: Sean Q.

description:
I came here on a Friday night.  They charge $5 cover, it's very small and we were packed like sardines in a can....LOL
I can see why the guys would love this place they can get to rub up against you and it's not their fault !!!
Forget this being a meat market , this is the Slaughter house!! Not a place for the faint of heart ...can't say much about the drinks could not get close enough to the bar to order one....
Oh yeah, they play really kick ass music !
author: Ydania O.

description:
I'm sorry - we've been loyal patrons of little Baobab for years - live right nearby. Maybe it was just an off-night. But we were bringing a friend here who worked in Senegal in the peace corps and ... all 'round it was disappointing. 

I'm chill with the service usually. But tonight, I don't know, way too many mistakes going on and not enough "mea culpa." I don't mind waiting a long time; I like that, in fact, but several times waiting for a drink (and that's important) or not getting it all. We were served the meal with nary a fork in sight. The Franziskaner was out and, of the dessserts, only the cake was available.

And the food wasn't what it had been. And the restroom ... well, you couldn't flush the toilet so they'd removed the top of the bowl and customers had to do it manually.

I'm sad. I've loved this place in the past, really. Has something changed? Is it tough 'cause of the economy?

I'll go again, but with a big ol' caveat and I won't bring guests. I'll go dancing there ... that's still gotta be great, right?
author: maureen f.

description:
This was my first review of this place. My second wasn't so glowing. 


I would actually give Little Baobap 4 to 4 1/2 stars but I had a certificate from Trubates worth $40 for $25 so I rounded it to 5. They have a great happy hour deal from 6 to 7:30 where you get an appetizer, entrée, a dessert and a drink for $20. We each started with the tropical salad that was incredible. I'm not a big fan of salad but I enjoyed every bite. For the entrée I had the N'Dole. It was very good but the lamb was just a bit tough. It was very tasty and the couscous was also very good. My friend had the crevette coco. She said it was delicious. For dessert we both had the warm chocolate cake. It was small but very good. Everything was presented beautifully. I almost didn't want to eat the cake because it was so well crafted.  All an all I would recommend this place to anyone. Discount or not this place is worth a try.

On my second visit to Little Baobap things didn't start well. The server spilled water right on my lap. Thats fine, mistakes happen. No big deal. Then the food came and I was un-impressed. I got the fish and it just didn't have any flavor. The hummus plate however was very good. I would recommend that. I don't like hummus but enjoyed this.  I also enjoyed the mango ice cream, again very good. Then the bill came, first it was the wrong bill, then the server brought the correct one but the happy hour price hadn't been applied. It was then corrected. I guess I would expect that my portion of the meal would be comped because of the water in my lap but it wasn't. I was offered a free dessert however when the happy hour deal is applied it includes a dessert anyway. I will not hesitate returning here. I have been here three times and have always enjoyed it. The server was very friendly every time I have been here. You should defiantly try this place.
author: Isaac S.

description: Go here for the drinks, which are different: lots of tamarind and ginger in them.  Well done.  The food is decent, and we loved the special dessert that night of crepes with Nutella.
author: Sumomo O.

description:
This place is one of my LOVES in the city!  Good food, friendly service, great nighttime fun... what more could I ask for all in one place????  

Day time food is good and is super fun tasting senegalese food.  The owner is from senegal and owns Bissap Baobab around the corner and Bollyhood next door.  The shrimp entree with coconut sauce is my fav!  Add hibiscus juice or any unique cocktail and you're happy for the day/night!

Then when it transitions to nighttime, get ready to listen to fun west african music and meet real people looking to have a good time.  The place is a little small and of course all the cool kids want to get in, so it's super packed!  Cover is usually $3 and drinks are $7ish i think?  it's definitely a good place to start your weekends!
author: Cristina L.

description:
Best caipirinha that I've ever had! Granted, I've never been to Brazil, but the cachaça they used was indeed top notch. I ordered the Afro Caipirinha, which included (my choice) of fresh tamarind juice in addition to the standard ingredients - the sticky, unique sweetness of tamarind really complements the flavour  profile of the drink.

The bartender was quite friendly, and they had some excellent music in the background. My girl got the hibiscus margarita (@ $5)- also quite excellent, but I am glad I had my choice. 

I will definitely return for their happy hour - goes from 5:30-7:30, with $2.50 house cocktails!
author: Brett H.

description:
Venue - Small
Food - Some of it wonderful, other dishes just ok.
Drinks - Not enough variety 
People who work there - some friendly, some not so friendly
People who go there - Lots of fun!
Music - THE BEST if you like world music 

I love to dance here!
author: January B.

description: Loud with funky dance beats, a crowded bar, and interesting drink concoctions, including a hibiscus margarita. They keps on throwing us in the bar, from the front, first b/c of glass bottles, and then liquor. This proved to be annoying. Also, there is a little cover, which is not offensive.
author: Andrew K.

description: I've only been here to dance. The place is very small and divey. I like the reggae music and chill people here. Would like to go back some time soon!
author: Diana Y.

description: Man, the food was delicious. Everything I ordered I savored and loved. I got the platanos which was great. For the main dish I got the Crevette Coco(sauteed shrimps in coconut sauce served with rice and roasted potatoes) and mmm... it was damn tasty. I need to come here again and have their amazing food and try more of their great drinks!
author: Caroline N.

description:
I went here on a Thursday night and I thought the vibe here was great. It felt like a small houseparty with a GREAT DJ spinning some awesome reggae (both unheard tunes as well as the typical crowd pleasers). Little Baobap is located in a very quaint area of the Mission on 19th & Mission, so you could easily miss the bar if you do not have a street address. My best description of the space is like a beach shack that you would find in Goa, India where people go to basically to dance the night away. You can show up in sneakers, t-shirts, beanies, and still not receive doorman attitude! The $3 cover to hear some fantastic beats is well worth it - and you know that a place is still hot when people of all ethnicities are dancing it up to the same music. Go to Baobap if you are willing to dance - not to visit a meatmarket. Sitting on the sidelines drinking a beer is not going to cut it here...

I can't wait to check out the music on the other nights because this place is known for their eclectic music selections. I think the best way to do Baobap is to bring a group of 6-8 ppl. who are ready to move.

Update: I went here on a Friday night with about 11 people and I had one of the best nights ever in SF. The Afro-French music was sick, and all the people were having a great time. I think I must have sweated off about 2 lbs in the hot bar. Sogie has to be THE DJ that has the best taste in international music that I have seen yet! This is definitely my place to keep visiting again and again. My only wish is that the bar was slightly bigger now that it has gotten so popular.
author: Nirav K.

description: Yummy food, comfy casual atmosphere and a bargain!  What's not to like?
author: Russell D.

description:
Tastey food, friendly waiter, great ambience, & short wait-time (for a table and our food).

I went here on a Saturday night.  I was a little hesitant because I never tried African food before, but I was delightfully surprised at how good their food was once they served our avocado appetizer.

Our waiter was very friendly (and cute).  The food came to us quickly and we even managed to receive a free martini on the house.  The menu was very simple with both meat and veggie entrees and the pricing was perfect--not expensive and appetizers go from the $7-15 range.

When I got my shrimp kebabs with the couscous I literally had a food orgasm.  It was soooo tastey.  And as a fan of reggae, dancehall, and old-school hip-hop, I really enjoyed the music the dj was spinning in the background.

I need to go back because I have yet to taste the other intriguing cocktails listed on their drink menu.
author: nicole f.

description: This place is wonderful.  The shrimp coconut dish will knock your socks off.  Their tamarind margarita is fantastic.  The staff is friendly and flexible.  This is the kind of place where I feel comfortable enough to sit and relax for a little while, not just eat and run. Senegalese is where it's at--and actually, I like their food and homey atmosphere better than regular Baobab around the corner, which is saying something.  Little Baobab, thank you for several delightful evenings.
author: Sydney H.

description:
We went to Little Baobob totally on a lark - we were on the way to a concert at the Red Poppy Art House, and decided to stop somewhere close by for dinner. It was pretty early, so it was in restaurant rather than club mode.

The food was great. I had these really well made plaintains, and their shrimp dish with coconut cream. Yummy. The rum and ginger punch was great too. We were by far the oldsters in the crowd, but it didn't bother us much. 

Nice place, great food. I'll be going back, for sure.
author: Maxwell P.

description:
Little Baobab used to be right up there on my "favorite restaurants in the neighborhood" list, but i just don't know anymore.  they recently made minor changes to the menu, which in my opinion made things way less tasty.  The curry that i love most (cari vollaile) now comes without yam or potato.  Previously the menu said it came with yam and potato, but on occasion it didn't and i would count the days when i was sadly surprised by the lack of potatoey goodness on my plate as bad little baobab days.  Also, the chicken used to come cut up into little pieces that were nicely placed on top of the curry, for easy mixing in and capturing of flavor.  On my most recent visit the chicken was just a big dull single chicken piece.  Why do I care so much about these things?  I don't know, but this is my review so I'm allowed to.

Now it's probably best if we don't even talk about the service at this place.  Because it's good about one out of every five times, and when it's bad it's very very even pushover sharon doesn't want to leave a tip bad.  

And the music is too loud when you're trying to eat.

but, on the plus side,  it IS an incredibly cute place with really unique food that you can't find elsewhere (or at least i haven't been able to).  and it IS very very near to  my house.  and it never fails to impress visitors.
author: Sharon M.

description: pretty tasty cocktails, and fun music, too bad there is a cover to dance. Also no matter your sex or orientation you are gonna get grinded upon...
author: Jared Z.

description: African drums replace the Mission's normal Ozzy tracks and you've got a cool counter-cultural dive bar with live music and/ or DJ.  The food is solid, the prices fair.  I like it more than most if only because the mix of people is happily more diverse than the usual hipster mix.  A great footnote:  dj music at night, live african music often in their space next door.
author: Patrick B.

description: I LOVE THIS CLUB! Drinks are amazing, the dance floor is fun and unpretentious. Good, clean dancing fun!
author: Anne Marie M.

description:
A great place to go for an enjoyable dinner. They are the smaller, more fun and cozy, sibling of Bissap Baobab, which is around the corner. Good African (Senegalese?) food and great cocktails. I love the plantains. 
My guy friends say the waitresses are hot. I've heard that there is good live music and dancing but I haven't been there when that was happening.
I would take a date here.
author: Cyrelle D.

description:
If you love dancing, come here. If you're tired of dancing to the same 5 songs, come here. If you enjoy tasty cocktails, come here. If you love it when everyone in the room dances, come here. If you love when men and women both dance, come here. 

I had such a great time when I went I can't wait to go back. The cocktails were delicious (as was the bartender). I had the caipirinha which was on the sweeter side but I loved it. And followed up with tamarind margaritas mmmm.

Now the main event, the dancing. The music was great and perfect to get you moving. People were dancing everywhere and anywhere they could. 

The cover's pretty cheap. It does get hot once inside, although I did see a man in a sweater vest and button up shirt so maybe it's not hot enough for some. 

Can't wait to go back!!
author: prachi v.

description:
Dancing and more dancing!!  Salsa wednesday at Baobab is my new favorite locale!  Everyone is super chill, friendly and fun. The bartenders were nice and the Hibiscus drinks were tangy tasty.  

It gets cramped quickly but if you feel claustrophobic you can walk out to the faux-patio in the front.  

The music varies daily so pick your poison and bust-a-move!!!
author: Jay H.

description:
You know I dread going to Latin/African music clubs normally. Honestly, it is because when I get there, I go from super rhythmically talented amongst my peers, to the girl with two left feet. But tonight at Little Baobab I had a random stranger come up to me and tell me "You must be part African, because Asian girls don't dance like that." Then he proceeded to tell other strangers of this new found enigma, as I kinda smiled and was embarrassed. And no, it was not a pick up line because... he did not dance with me. 

The night started with reggae, which is too slow for my tastes, but the moved onto some African hip hop/Latin tracks. It was just nice to get out and release some stress. Also great were the guys we went with, who were there in a pinch to help get rid of seedy contenders.

It was really fun and flattering for a night. But I really miss my rap/hip hop.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Let's start with five stars and work our way down.  

5 - half star for waitress also being the bartender so wasn't really around at all.  

4.5 - minus 1 star for them taking our money and not offering the change. They tipped themselves over 20%, which is fine if the food or service was great.  

3.5 - minus half star for not letting us have our one little chair in the corner to keep our purses/coats on.  

So that's the 3 stars.  The staff was really nice and food was good, although needed salt and there was none to be found and no waitress around to ask.  OH, and the guacamole was disgusting!  I think they made it with really old avocados.  There were three of us and we all couldn't take a second bite! So I guess that gives them 2.5 stars.  

Once the music/dancing started there was a very electic mix of parties, including about 5 jock guys in cuttoffs and flip flops beside us who weren't dancing which was sort of weird.
author: Maddie B.

description:
I was doing it bhangra style and looking good at Little Baobab's Bollywood Night a few Thursdays ago. Now, to be fair,  I am a novice bhangra shaker, but I think my middle eastern hip moves saved me, along with a friend's instructions, but damn did I have a great time.
Great cheap drinks, decent cover (wait, I don't recall paying a cover!), and  best of all, great Indian jams spun by the best white bollywood DJ's outside of India!  I haven't had this much fun dancing freely in a long long long time...
I can't vouch for the food served here, but I'm sure  its good...I plan to return to feast and shake what my mama  gave me...
author: BoraBora T.

description:
A spontaneous after dinner drinks with the girls turns into entering this inconspicuous bar/club.  We actually stopped to ask the bouncer and DJ two simple questions: (1) Is there a cover? (2) Is it crowded? (we were determined to keep our sweaters and scarves on)  Of course we had just interrupted a high level conversation about "how can Americans have a hard time surviving in their homeland when foreigners come and are able to survive?".  That conversation lasted for a good 30 min before we even asked the 2 questions.  Regardless, we loved the friendliness and were convinced the temperature inside was perfect.  It was 11pm and early enough where it was.

The drinks are well priced and everyone around was super friendly.  Good music and always a mixed crowd.  You never know who you're going to get on whatever night.    Benches on the side, smoking patio in the front and one bathroom by the DJ.  Still, a fun place in the Mission to hang when you just want to dance and have a good time.
author: Christina C.

description: I really love this place and can't remember how many times I've been here. The food is great and perfect for sharing too. I've tried their other signature drinks but the hibiscus margarita is my fave and should be ordered by the pitcher! The only less than 5 stars thing I can say about Little Baobob is their up-keep of important things- like the bathroom. The last time we visited, there was no toilet seat. Dude, send an employee to Home Depot or the nearest hardware store but don't open your otherwise fabulous restaurant without a friggin seat on the toilet! We'll still go back here though! And hopefully get to pee in style too!
author: Jen G.

description:
We were about to go to beauty bar that one friday night, but the music sounded way more interesting at little baobab. We walked into this little tiny packed room.. and ended up having a blast! The two DJ's were spinning some great soca music (kevin little et all) and also mixed in some bhangra! 

I haven't eaten here but give the place 4 starts for the music and the interesting drinks.
author: Kin J.

description: Dance parties all day in this place. It's not the biggest, but the music and atmosphere is great. On a slightly related note, if you're a 100 pound female boozed up on whiskey, don't punch the bouncer in the face when he won't let your friend in, he'll laugh at you and kick you out, I was lucky enough to witness the hilarious scene first hand.
author: Matt F.

description:
I was so intrigued by the idea of an African restaurant and dance club, but the food didn't impress me.

Awesome atmosphere though, which is much appreciated when you're waiting an hour for a table, filled with cool plants, "exotic" decorations, and bartenders will to serve you elaborate alcoholic concoctions.
author: Maia B.

description:
Go for the drinks...eat some darn good food...and enjoy the laid back atmosphere with really fun, friendly staff.  Senegal 4 EVA.  

(Bissap Baobab also kicks ass.)
author: Leigh-Anne L.

description:
I came here with a few friends on a Monday night, expecting to imbibe some cocktails of an exotic Senegalese variety, and to get down to some grooves of a similar nature.  We were denied the latter; for some reason there was no DJ, and we were asked to leave at 10pm (the kitchen's closing time).  Though we felt rather shortchanged, the rest of the experience helped to compensate for our idle hips.  Our first pitcher, the ginger margarita, was dangerously delicious.  The second pitcher was a pinkish cocktail named something flowery, but it was basically straight whiskey with a touch of some sweet nectar.  Good thing we weren't drinking on empty stomachs -- a tofu curry dish, curried coconut shrimp, and a crab-and-avocado salad were well-seasoned and pleasing to the eye.

Service by the sole, easygoing bartender was decent, but made infinitely better just by overhearing his West African French.  Five + stars next time if he whispers sweet nothings in my ear.
author: Siv L.

description: The Friday night dance is worth the $5 they charge you to get in. They serve strong, cheap drinks in plastic cups with crushed ice. The DJ mostly spins reggae, samba, some dubstep. The place is a hole in the wall, and doesn't seem very clean. Then again, I only go when it's dark. I've been meaning to try the food....They have fans in the place so at least when it's super packed you feel a little cool breeze on the dance floor.
author: Michelle W.

description:
This place is sooooooooo small, but its still a very fun place to get some cheap drinks and dance to some good music. The bartender was very nice and he gave mea nice strong mojito for $7 and a hibiscus margarita to my friend for $5. They play a lot of different music i.e. reggae, soca, merengue, and soukous. 

You can wear whatever you want and luckily they have a coat check. I'll definitely be back.
author: Corey C.

description:
This bar has a GREATTT dance floor. This is an awesome place to take all your girlfriends for a long night of dancing.
Honestly, there are a lot of big, black, buff and way sexyyy men that wanna get down and tell you that you're beautiful. Ohh, good times.
author: Pearl M.

description:
Love it. 

It is small, super hot and sometimes you can barely dance, but I love it! the music is awesome, super cheap and nice staff. 

Love it.
author: Anabelle B.

description: Came here with a friend who's been here once or twice and had a good time.  This place apparently is a restaurant that converts to a dance "club" after 10pm or so (not sure exactly what time) - We came when they were moving the tables and chairs.  It has a fun vibe, great music and people literally come here to just dance.  You'll find some people drinking at the bar (which is not that big) but most people are on the dance floor getting down. The place is kind of small with limited seating which is against the wall by the window so there's a lot of people mashed together but still seemed like everyone was having a good time.  People are friendly and diverse, the drinks are pricey for the type of place it is - looks like a dive bar but with club prices.
author: Mookie L.

description: Will I come back here, probably not.  I had been wanting to go here for ages and finally convinced a few girlfriends to come out for a night of dancing.  We walked in at a decent time and place was packed!  It's such a small restaurant that turns into a club that we couldn't find any room to get to the bar.  Forget about dancing!  We talked to some cool people but due to the size of it, we just couldn't hang for more than a drink.  The music they play here is AWESOME!  Worth checking it out to get a fresh
author: Ms B.

description:
What can I say about Little Baobab?  It's the San Francisco west African Cheers, where everyone knows your name - well, the management does if you go often and bargain for a lower cover charge. That wasn't me, it was my friends, really...  

Anyways, it's what you would expect in San Francisco - good DJs, great music, a pint-size dance floor and a diverse crowd.  Prepare yourself to dance - there is no room for wallflowers here.  Squeeze in and enjoy yourself!

Also, a little known fact is this smaller (and original?) branch of the Baobab serves dinner. If you dine here close to closing, you can stay as the tables are put away and gain entrance to the dance party for free!  A friend of mine did that for her birthday with great success a couple of years ago. 

I would give it five stars but I have to say I have been a little disappointed by the quality of some of the drinks and food on occasion.  However, the wait staff have tried to correct problems when brought to their attention.  

As much as you might try, one you go you will be pulled back.  And yes, like Cheers you will be welcomed back even after a long hiatus.
author: Kenya W.

description:
COLLECTIVE HIGH... from the deliciously different, inescapeably moveable reggae, reggaeton, dancehall and east indian beats to the delightfully CHEAP and STRONG exotic liquid mood enhancers, little baobab is an awesome venue for showing off your ragamuffin dance moves that you have perfected since you discovered bob marley and the wailers' "exodus."

PERFECT VACATION from getting all glammed up in your BCBG's where you end up at a "nicer" place and pay $15 for parking, $20 at the door and $15 for your drink and tip. For all that, it cost me $10 for the cab, nothing to get in, and $5 for my drink at little baobab... well, actually somebody bought me a drink, but you get my drift. 

MUST WEAR LAYERS. it's a really small place, and gets really hot (hello? plus YOU look really hot as you peel them off while shaking your hips...) 

MUST IMBIBE: hibiscus lime vodka.

MUST BRING: tissues. one unisex bathroom sometimes runs out of paper! no worries about the line though, you can still shake it with others while standing in line. you can even form a train. a love train... people all over the world... join hands...
author: Sharonrose B.

description: We rolled in here after dinner. When we walked in there were still people eating dinner so there wasn't a whole lot of space to stand. Not even 10 minutes later, they move the tables outside, shut the curtains, locked down the doors and turned the whole place into a par-tay! The music was awesome; I could not stand still. Also loved the drinks we got - Hibiscus Margarita and Ginger Margarita. Definitely want to head back here.
author: Lauren J.

description: We went here once on Friday night (6/17/11). It was small, which I like. The bartender was nice. My mixed drink was nice - Sorange (orange juice, vodka, ginger $7). The music was not my style - latin, reggae etc. People were of all ages/types. It was a fun little place, but I wasn't in the mood for it. There was a cover charge of $5.
author: Fi K.

description:
-excellent atmosphere
-very diverse, 25 and up crowd
-there were 2 djs: one obviously sucked, but the other was really good
-but enjoyed the reggae music :)
-live drummer accompanied the music, which is a plus on the dance floor
-great service at the bar, the sangria was pretty good and all of the drinks aren't overpriced
author: Rob N.

description:
Drinks and dancing. The music is fantastic and the crowd has such a good energy. 

Tiny, hot and cramped... who knew?
author: Adam L.

description:
Love it! Great music, great crowd, great dancing and great drinks. It loses a point for the DJ with the terrible transitions, but other than that, it was fantastic. 

The place is a small restaurant by day, but they clear out all the tables and chairs to make room for dancing by night. I can't wait to come back and try the food one of these days. Note that they close the kitchen around 9:15 pm.

It is a super small space, and around midnight, it got way too crowded for my taste, but from about 10-12, the music and dancing were fantastic.

I'd never heard about 95% of the songs, but they were all good for dancing. There were several people in the crowd who were exceptionally talented dancers and fun to watch.

Definitely not your normal SF club environment - it's pretty casual, and I doubt there's any dress code. If there is, dreadlocks probably help you get around it!
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
Hot, sweaty, too crowded, close bumpin to SICK THICK FAT afrobeat and funky soul breaks and stuff.

Solid.

Crowded tho.

But solid.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Well My buddy and I was in City calling up our friends trying to find out whats cracking in SF. So One of our friends said 
"Hey go to Little Baobob its Always cracking"
So we went to check it out. The Cover was only 5 bucks and God it was small but you know what?! lol It was cracking a lot of hot chickas lol and the drinks were SuuuuuuUUUpper cheap. I wasn't used to dancing in this fast pace music but some girl was nice enough to teach me some steps haha.
At the end of the night everyone was sweaty due to the cramp place but hey lol I had fun. I recommend this place if they are tired or just wanna try something new type of club Just try to keep up with the music. haha
author: John A.

description:
EDIT 5/06: If this is what the Peace Corp is like, I'm ready to ship out.  Hot music, hot people, in a (literally) hot shack of a club.    
--
Apparently Tuesday nights are not the time to go to Little Baobab.  Without dancing or music, Little Baobab just seems sort of dirty.  If you are planning on eating (and not dancing) I'd recommend heading over to Bissap for a cleaner version of the same thing.  Also, while my hibiscus margarita was really yummy, my food was not so good.  My lamb looked much, much more like little lumps of charcoal than anything meat.  

As much as I didn't particularly enjoy my dining experience, I am extremely intrigued by the dancing and will definitely be back.
author: Katie S.

description:
Best bar to dance at in the city. Period.

Great beats, amazingly diverse crowd, awesome tiny dance floor forcing contact with others.
author: Krissy M.

description:
Thanks to Helen for introducing me to this place.  We went on a Saturday night and it was not too crowded when we got there but quickly filled up.  We danced to R&B, soul, funk, hip hop and my favorite, reggae/ dancehall.  I know I loved this place because I started dancing the minute I got there and didn't stop until we left without any drinks.   Now, that's amazing.

The place was tiny and had a diverse crowd that seemed to just be there to dance and that was great.  The decor was very much like an old house I used to live in where my roommate and I would throw parties so it felt like home.  

It can get claustrophobic and the second DJ who was there for the world music part of the night didn't seem to transition between songs too well but all in all, I had a great night and Little Baobab is my favorite place for a Saturday night.
author: Seong P.

description:
Every time I've been to Little Baobab, I've been the DD and still had fun.  This is a HUGE compliment for any bar.  Anyone knows that being sober, in a crowded room with lots of dumb beligerant 20-somethings is definitely not the set-up for a good night.  Not to mention that the "club" is virtually a tiny room and an even smaller bar with virtually nowhere to sit.  

However, with its yummy and reasonably priced drinks, amazing musical choices, and chill vibe, Little Baobab single-handedly fixes all of those problems.
