(NOTE:  There was one time when I went and the usual DJ must've been MIA because this DJ had NO IDEA how to blend beats together.  In between every song, there was an awkward pause as each of us repositioned ourselves accordingly to the beat of the song.)  Not to mention the crowd is, more often than not, laid back, relatively attractive, knows how to dance and not just grind their genitals on each other.  

Little Baobab is one of my favorite places to go out because it's chill, dirt cheap, there are no Forever 21 skeezies and popped-collared "brahs" rubbing up on each other, and the music is amazing.  If you prefer bass-humping and girls who like to wear headbands as miniskirts, I would guess that this place is not for you.
author: Grace K.

description:
Went there this past Saturday night with my close friend. The food was awesome. Recommended starter: The Plantain! It was cooked just right, the caramelized banana was crispy but not too crispy. Even the sweetness was just right. The food is great, I had a chicken curry that was seasoned just right. It was perfect. Price wasn't that bad at all either. 

My only minus one was when the restaurant turned to a dance floor, the guys just abruptly took the tables without prepping us....but the waitress was very nice and courteous enough to acknowledge that.
author: Yo S.

description:
This place has one hecka good happy hour. Surprised not too many come here for $2.50 pints or bottles of beer before 7:30. The cocktails sound amazing but will have to try them out next time. I stuck with a cup of ginger tea since I wasn't feeling too well. But what did make me feel better was the coconut shrimp dish I had, with shrimps and potato wedges half dipped into a plate of mildly spiced coconut milk, and a scoop of coconut rice in the middle. Yum. I'd come back to try out their other dishes.

Didn't stay for the nightlife, but we passed by on the way home and there was a line outside the door with bass bumping against the walls. Seems to be a popular place at night.
author: Zell C.

description:
I have found myself here quite a few times with friends, and I would never have thought to mention it as one of my favorite places.  Similar to how I would never think to say that "Amadeus" is one of my favorite movies but, weirdly enough, it is the movie I generally turn to when I need to just watch a movie.  So, other than "The Big Lebowski," I think it's the movie I've seen the most.  Little Baobab is my "Amadeus," and I didn't realize this until I found myself suggesting this place to an out of town guest of mine the other night.

The service can be a bit lackadaisical but whatever, like YOU'VE got any place else to be tonight.  The food is yummy - tofus and meatses in various sauces, and I always get my tofu with a side of couscous.  And plaintains.  YUM.  I like Little Baobab for ambiance a bit more than Big Brother Baobab, but granted I've only gotten drunk at BBB, not eaten there.  The drinks are just as good at Little Baobab, and ordering a deliciously fruity and stiff cocktail by the pitcher is always a good idea.  Yes, GOOD idea.
author: Ashley B.

description:
To the managers of this joint: IT'S CALLED A FAN. 

But let's put that aside for now.

If you're hungering for the company of a bunch of returned Peace Corps volunteers, or missing a skeezy bar in some tropical locale in the developing world, then this is your place! The music was bumping, the people were great, but it was very very hot in there.

And, likewise at its big brother, the drinks here are sloppily thrown together and are too sweet.
author: Sahra H.

description:
I love the music here on Friday and Saturdays, the international mix of Indian, french rap, and everything in between is great to shake it to.
The cover is super-cheap ($3) and the drinks are inventive and delicious, especially the ginger ones!

My friends and I go here when we need a change of pace from pop or house music, but we try to come in pairs/couples to avoid the groping by the overflow of single men that goes on most of the night.
Overall, the culture clash is easy to take when the beats are so good!
author: Jessica P.

description: Went here with my friend! The place is too small but u can still shake ur asses!! People here are friendly. Drinks are strong. loved it here!
author: E-lie P.

description: This place really is something special. The $20 happy hour deal is an amazing value, from the unique cocktails to the live music this spot definitely transports you to another place. We'll definitely be back.
author: M L.

description:
Little Baobab = reliably danceable.

Why is this important?  Because there's nothing worse than wanting to get down on a Saturday in San Francisco without a car.  What it boils down to is one shot (unless your date/friends/whoever is a trooper/drunk/gullible) and that one shot needs to be right.

As said previously, Little Baobab is small, hot, and cramped.  The DJ's selections are hot and cold: sometimes ol' boy is on the money, sometimes (between the less-than-graceful crossfade and the hopeless attempt at beat syncronization) you'll have to work twice as hard to keep your groove . . . provided you dance to the groove.

Actually, here's a PSA for all you Little Baobab regulars: please, PLEASE dance in the groove.  If you actually have to stop and think on whether or not you danced in the groove, YOU DIDN'T DANCE IN THE GROOVE.  Your sharp elbows, heavy feet, and awkward bodies make it hard on those who can sufficiently control more than 30% of their body mass.

Little Baobab is one of the cooler spots to go to in SF.  Great to dance.  Great, diverse (diversity = important!) crowd.  Great also if you're looking to be proposed to by a random Senegalese man, ladies, as mentioned earlier.
author: Coleman K.

description:
i used to like the food there (2 years ago) until the cock roaches took over the kitchen. I kid you not...I'll take my chicken minus the roaches..puhlease!
As far as the night scene and dancing..it is great for coked up, sexually confused guys.
author: City G.

description:
Mmkay before this past Wednesday night, I would have given this joint 5 stars, straight across.  The music ALWAYS makes me dance and the drinks are great. HOWEVER when it comes to the bouncers, or the bouncer that worked this past Wednesday night, what a fucken rip off man.  
So me and my homie4lyfe where bar hoppin looking for a place to boogie down.  Turns out it was a 2 dollar cover, no big deal.
My homie told the doorman:  "You guys charging during a weekday?"
Bouncer *nods*
Me: "No problem I got you man, the music sounds better here than fuckin Beauty Bar".  
I handed the dude 4 bucks and all of a sudden the cover was now 6 dollars for both of us.  
I'm not a cheap ass, 3 dollors no big deal, but how you gonna raise the price just like that? 
QUE ESCANDALO! 
We left talkin shit.  
Mr. Bouncer what's yer problem!?
author: Roxane P.

description: Don't even think of coming here and not having the homemade coconut rum!  It is delicious!
author: Lisa M.

description: Love love love!  Great place, good vibe, really feels like one of a kind in San Francisco!
author: Lauren S.

description: Good cheap food! Great happy hour with yummy tropical drinks and fried plantains for $1.00!! Always hott beats, and dancing a bit later.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Went to this place as my wife and i love Ethiopian food & we thought this was an Ethiopian place. When we found out it wasn't we decided to stay as it looked like it might be a great place anyway.
The place is very small and intimate, with a cafe/club feel. The food was good, but not great. 
My wife had the coconut shrimp where the sauce was great, but the shrimp were overcooked & not juicy. i had the lamb in sauce over couscous which was perfectly cooked, but the sauce wasn't very flavorful. 
We also ordered an appetizer, as we had a restaurant.com coupon, and we ordered the crab meat with avocado. This was very good, but small. That is true to the shrimp plate as well. My lamb wasn't huge, but good sized.
We ordered the chocolate cake for dessert and it was great! They even went next door to get me a cup of coffee!
When they learned it was our anniversary, our waitress brought us some free wine to celebrate! Very nice gesture, even though i hate wine. Still, very sweet!
One reason i'm giving only 3 stars, is that the place is tiny & was so very loud as two parties of about 8 each made it almost unbearable to stay. If one group hadn't left before we were served our entrees, we would have left.
Recommended.
author: Dan J.

description:
my date and I arrived at 12, which on the mission is when people are starting to catch thier buzz. Alas at this place they start much earlier....This place is a sardine can with some really stinky fish. Really creepy guys, I had to rescue some poor girls from some really scary looking guy.  

The good the special drinks small compaired to other bars in the mission were d-lish. The music was amazing. Sadly there was no where to dance. The crowd was so friendly, bartenders were fast and super friendly. 

My final word, go there but be prepared to be a sardine.
author: Desiree Y.

description:
This is the place where you can enjoy Senegalese, Jamaican and Caribbean reggae and even Colombian Champeta (wait what is that...go there and ask for a song. ;-) )

I really enjoyed the ambiance the music, the tropical cocktails and the good vibe. All of that make this bar a very special spot in the city. 5 bucks cover that I much rather pay than going to other fancy places where you just go to show up!!!

If you like Reggae, Reggeaton, Champeta, Trini music.....this is your house!!!!!
author: Juan Camilo R.

description:
This place is incredibly fun! My friend Jessica brought me here during St. Patty's day and we danced, danced, danced to Latin-Afro beat music until we were - er, glowing. The regulars here just go right up to you and ask if you want to dance, sorta like at a salsa club. I had seven dancing partners that night!
Their lychee and other tropical fruit drinks are amazing, too. I wish we had a place like this in Austin.
author: Clarisa R.

description:
Solid.  I've been here at least a dozen times and feel its always been a 4-5 star experience/place to go.  The food, if you go early, is quite tasty and easy on the wallet.  I've tried almost everything on the menu and honestly liked it all.  While its not 5 start service or plating or even ingredients...its just down right good.

As for the other part...you have to hit this place when they open up the dance floor.  The DJs spin quality beats from West Africa, the Caribbean, latin sources, and even North American artists.  Everyone is here to have a good time and just bounce around.  It gets crazy humid so wear clothes accordingly.  The cover is also usually only $2-3.  Most of the time it is nothing.

Getting drinks would be the only drawback.  While pushing the envelope of the fire code maximum occupancy there rarely is enough bartender help to quickly serve you.  The signature drinks are OK and I have found that they are more a novelty.  However, you're probably not here to get your drink on...you've ended up here...so leisurely drinking the rest of the night suits the service you'll get.
author: Chris D.

description: First of all I should point out that Senegal is west Africa and so it is west African not East African food east African food - such as Ethiopian food is very different The first time I went here was absolutely amazing service, my server ended up I found out in the subsequent times to be the bartender who took his time to be my server I definitely did appreciate his service, and the owner who is his uncle told me that he really enjoyed serving me and so that is excellent I must admit it's a little hard to say anything negative about this place because I've actually met the owner and he is quite nice and affable a very good person. The specialty about the food is only really the sauce because the food across the plates seem pretty standard also another thing that is worth noting is the dishes are quite small and for $12 a dish or $13 a dish I think that they should really serve more food, sometimes I feel that this is only about snack size, it was quite a small bowl of soup whiff not that  many shrimp when I had the shrimp stew also the service was decent the two subsequent times I went, and nothing to compare to the first time at all also the boxes aren't the greatest quality, as at one point when I bought three boxes of food while all the boxes and all the food became one saucy pancake and this was all before the boxes got a little crushed from moving around, because they were merely paper the sources were already leaking from Box to box I also think it was here that I fell off of a chair, because the chair that is at the back room of this establishment isn't as sturdy
author: Rachel N.

description:
Not for the faint hearted thats for sure. One of my favorites spots to hide, be hidden and just get a grove on. Not all the time can you hear zouk and son at the same place. It's super and small and drinks can be super and watered down- depends who is pouring and when. Always bet you can get a red stripe though.

I've taken a few people here from out of town - new york and chicago and they love it! I've had the food here and at the larger restaurant - pretty good but not as authentic as they could make it. I think if they did maybe they're afraid it won't be as loyal of a following - not sure. The plantains and basically any shrimp dish is yummy.  It's a super place to practice any kind of language - though its a francophone venue, there are folks from everywhere - spain to ghana and from bangladesh to cape verde.
author: Tyese C.

description:
DISCLOSURE - 4 Stars for the food... 3 overall if you include service.

Friday night, running late, passed by, looked cute, walked in.  
PoiBoi and friends joined us.  
He's right, it's dark in here, small and you sit really close to other parties... but it's SF and eh, get used to it.  

We were seated quickly and our server came up to take our orders.  She's pretty, but for some reason she has that "i'm pissed off" look etched into her face!  She'd be prettier if she smiled... or at least fake it so i can enjoy our dinner...  geez.

We ordered two appetizers, first it was hummus with salad - but before PoiBoi and friend come we nearly eat all of it!  

Luckily PB orders the shrimp, OMG it was sooo good.  (or am i already buzzed??) I ordered the Flamboyant - a vodka with some sorta tangy stuff.  it was at first too tangy, but after a drink, two or three it's my now new friend for the night.  My second drink too a little while to come, we were nearly ready to go by the time it showed it. 

Dinner - Chicken Kabobs with rice.  Very good, i'm very full after one kabob.  Tasty for sure.
My friend ordered the coconut shrimp, wow, that IS so good.  Even the lamb is good and i'm not a lamb fan at all.

While we were finishing up it looked like they were transitioning to a club??  strange.  felt slightly rushed since people were sitting around the side of the "dancefloor" like it was spectator eating or something.  

Bill overall was about $150 for 5 people including 5 drinks, 2 beers, 2 appetizers.  Average SF dinner price.  I bet this place on a weekend lunch would be fabulous... but on a weekend night, you gotta get there early for food or later for dancing or whatever they put on.
author: Ella B.

description: Cute little place, reminds me of places in Latin America, colored walls, colorful paintings, very cosy. The chicken salad was tasty and tried the Plat Pays - halibut and shrimp sauteed in lemon pepper sauce with a side of rice. Oh-so-yummy.....Little baobab cocktail drink was delectable too! On another occassion, tried the Crevette Coco - sauteed shrimp in coconut sauce which was amazing as well.
author: Yan M.

description:
LOVE Little Baobab. This is my favorite dance/hangout spot in the city when I want to hear some good African / Hip Hop / R&B. The music is awesome and I love the causal and real atmosphere. It's a small room and the music is incredible. The decor is very simple and it definitely reminds me of Senegal. 

The drinks are awesome - Banana Drop is my favorite and they have a variety of other unique drinks using ginger and hibiscus. They have some good beer selections on tap as well. Prices are super reasonable and good sizes. 

If you love dancing and good music with awesome drinks, then you have to come and check out this place!
author: Gladys C.

description:
I think I would give this place a better rating if the crowd had been different when I went (some chick had a birthday or a going away party or something and it was like Marina in the Mission night, blar).  

All in all, this is a great location--the music is fantastic and eclectic (varying daily--wednesday is reggaeton night!!) and the staff is pretty laid back.  The drinks are fresh and yummy (I tried the "Rose," which is a ginger-cran-vodka pleaser, and the "Flamboyant," which is a hibiscus-tamarind-vodka diddy), but they only had one bartender the night that I went, which wasn't enough for the crowd.

Yeah, it's small, it's hot, but it's a rad place and one of the few places to offer Afro-funk and reggaeton music, so I dig it.
author: Justine H.

description: This place is one of my favorite spots in the city.  Its small, but intimate.  I love the hibiscus margaritas!  As far as food goes, Baobab's Gambas is fantastic, it's sauteed shrimp in a garlic-y chili sauce.
author: Madison K.

description: Definitely a great place for a large group dinner.  They have long tables fit for a party of any size.  I had the riz au cari (red curry sauce with chicken and assorted vegetables)-- pretty tasty Senegalese food.  I'd have to say what made the experience for me though was the music.  Pop songs with reggae beats in the background?  Little Baobab, you won me over with those tunes.  The place turns into a dance club post-dinner hours.  What great dance music.  I'll be back!
author: Alice Y.

description:
The waiters look like regular customers, and the chairs are fold-up plastic things, but the ambiance is comfortable and funky. Its like your offbeat friends' apartment in college- but with really good food and no Natural Ice beer anywhere. It's got French influence with a heavy seafood selection. Great flavors- but spicy so beware!-- and super reasonable prices. Actually, even the Guacamole is aces. Cheap pitchers of beer on tap and creative cocktails, man. I totally love it here. 

Oh but if you're really tall or really fat, you can't use the bathroom. The toilet room is so small that if you're more than I 5'5'' and/or 140 pounds, you'll never fit between the toilet and the wall. Just warning you.
author: Esther K.

description:
It was a little confusing at first which one was the nightclub-Little Baobab or Bissap Baobab and if they shared similar menus. One thing was for sure-they both didn't open for dinner until 6pm. The setting is really nice and the food delicious. My friend had the vegetarian curry and I tried some of hers and I had the coconut shrimp thing w/ rice. Both was very nicely presently and very rich. Very rich. The portions aren't huge, but they're filling. And very rich. I think I might have gotten a little sick from mine because I was constipated and my stomach from unsettled after mine. It tasted so good though.

The service could be better. Our waitress in the green dress seemed too cool for school and I got the impression that she was rolling her eyes at our every request but she didn't give us any lip. It's a small kitchen and the Mexican cooks were really friendly and nice-more so than the waitress actually.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Awesome and refreshing.  I loved the cheap, unique drinks ($5 hibiscus margaritas!), the catchy world music (mostly afro pop, hip hop, Indian dance, and dancehall), and the fact that everyone was dancing.

I have mixed feelings about the crowd: good-looking and respectful, but just too dense and full of single guys on the prowl.  I'll have to go back on a weeknight when there's more room to dance.
author: Karin H.

description:
Little Baobab takes you out of the city.   Probably great if you got dumped by someone, you know... to escape the familiar.  
Even on a chilly night, this place warms up because its about the size of a bathroom at a big dance club.  But the close quarters aleviate pretense and allow people to let loose.  The music always has a tropical feel.  It's like your in a red stripe commercial... Hooray Beer.  
Only this place is Senegalese (thats west african- i.e. great music) and instead of hooray beer, its Hooray Hibiscus/Ginger/Tamarind With Vodka or Rum.  For $5!!! 
get in before 9 or 10 to get a better cover. 
The restaurant around the corner is good too.
author: Christian W.

description:
This restaurant is quite a find!  The drinks here are AMAZING (especially the ginger-infused drinks) and the food is delicious.  

Appetizer -- My group tried the plantains and the hummus.  Both were delicious.  I especially enjoyed how the plantains were a good size (not too big, not too small) and they were slightly crisp at the edges.

Entree -- I tried the shrimp skewers with vegetable stew.  Dish also includes rice and a salad.  I absolutely loved the stew -- great mix of vegetables, not heavy or salty at all (a common issue with some stews).  The salad house vinaigrette dressing was also very unique -- fruity with a bit of a tang.  My only complaint is that the shrimp were a bit on the small side. 

Service -- A little slow, but it's no big deal.  They're a small restaurant, so I cut them some slack on that. 

However, the prices here are excellent, and it's a great value.  I would definitely come again!
author: Robyn F.

description:
Little Baobab is a small restaurant that turns into a nightclub after 10pm.  They clear out the tables and stools - even with you still on it - at 10pm, like clockwork, and start the music.  I love the atmosphere here.  You can come in early for drinks and appetizers at the bar or sit down for dinner.  It's small and intimate.  I've stayed long enough to see them turn it into a nightclub, but wasn't able to stay for some dancing.  I get the vibe that this would be a fun place to get your dance on and will definitely be back to do so!

The food and drinks were an orgasm in my mouth.  They serve West African Senegalese food.  I keep telling myself to try something new, but I always go back for more Mafe with chicken over couscous.  Peanut sauce, couscous, chicken that falls off the bones - what more could I ask for!  I always lick my plate clean and wish there was more, even though the portions are reasonably sized and I do leave satisfied.

Definitely order one of their cocktails.  They have things like ginger, orange, whiskey or hibiscus margaritas.  The tamarind margarita tastes like a regular margarita, but it's still delicious!  I take all of my out of town friends here and they all love it too.
author: Lynda N.

description:
Had one of the best nights dancing at Little Baobob's. Everyone seemed to be there for one reason only: to dance! There was no pretentious feeling you get at other dance clubs in the city and you could actually dance with just about anyone without feeling like a piece of meat or worrying about the person following you around the rest of the night (girls you know what I'm talking about). This place is quite small, hence the word "little" in the name, but if you can handle having a sweaty night, this place is definitely worth it. Great drinks, great crowd, great dance music (afro/cuban/dancehall/reggae/reggaeton). Couldn't have asked for more from this place.

On a side note....the restaurant across the street (Bissap Baobab) has some pretty tasty food, tho the service can be quite slow.
author: Desiree H.

description:
Be prepared for some serious GROPING.

A $5 cover when we came in late Saturday night (11pm), but it was well worth it. The bartenders were friendly and fast and the DJ's were simply amazing. The beats they were playing were perfect for dancing.

Wear comfortable dancing shoes and minimal clothing; it gets HOT and sweaty in BAOBOB. But damn, it sure is fun.
author: Laura D.

description: We came here to eat, not dance, which was possibly our first problem.  I'd been to the regular Baobab many years ago and remember being much more impressed with the food.  My dish here was fairly bland, but too spicy at the same time, if that's possible.  I do have to give the drinks an extra star.  Next time we'll have to come for the dancing, not the food.
author: Laura S.

description:
This is a sweet little place - shabby, colorful, convenient, and cheap. The cocktails were so cheap, I thought they were made with soju at first, but no, they use real hard stuff. I didn't have any because I'm on a "no drinking during the week" thing, but I totally wanted to because they sounded so good. Also you can order them by the pitcher (sp? I'm losing my ability to function w/o spellcheck!) which makes them even cheaper. But we stuck to the food.

The food is not as awesome as the place. That said, it's still pretty decent. They have a range of salad, appetizers, and real deserts, which is hard to get all in one place. I was a little unhappy with my shrimp in coconut sauce because it's basically a mound of white starch with white sauce surrounded by shrimp. There were no vegetables in it, and the sauce (which is mostly coconut milk) tasted slightly sweet. I'm used to veggies and tanginess, so I felt weird after eating it. It tasted good though. I spent a lot of time mashing the rice in the coconut milk and eating it because it tasted good but it was a little like eating a bowl of cookie dough -fun while you're doing it, and later you think maybe that it wasn't such a good idea and you'd better not do it again. I'd ordered mine without potatoes (because I hate them) so maybe that was the problem. 

My buddy had the chicken with peanut sauce and that was pretty good. The grilled chicked was served on a bed of sauteed veggies and peanut sauce with a side of couscous that had bits of peas and carrots and stuff all through it. Next time I'm totally having that. 

And I'm coming back with friends, because of the cocktails :)
author: Amy T.

description: LOVE it!  Relaxed, authentic, homey atmosphere.  Great servers, and fantastic food.  What more do you want?  This place instantly got added to my regular go-tos.
author: david p.

description:
this place ruined my birthday!!! i had reservations for 9:00pm. my party waited for 1 hour and they never sat us!!! 

a party of 8 came spoke french to a guy that worked there and they were seated right away. i asked to speak to the owner and some guy said i can talk to him. i told him they ruined my birthday, we waited for 1 hour and he even sat a group larger than my group. 

guess what he told me??? "you have to wait" 

We left and ate a another place and had great service. 

Little Baobab will never have any of my family's business ever again!!!  

do not go to this place unless you want to experience poor customer service and total disrespect!!!
author: Ysamin B.

description:
im not an official foodie, nor a cook. but ive eaten enough places to know what to look for and what to expect. 

little baobab was my second "first date" (out of 3) with the grub crawl group. (www.grubcrawl.com) and lets just say this one, has some maturing to do! ;)

the food at little baobab looks a lot like home cooking. doesnt mean its awful, its just not stuffy and uber-refined, which for me is a plus. its very homey and "down to earth. " 
the food itself had its ups and downs. the chicken skewers were a lil dry, but went well with the peanut curry sauce. the couscous didnt sell me at all and the fried plantains (or  maduros as we nicarguans would say) were perfectly cut and cooked. im still curious to try other items on the menu, however, and ordered as a plate. we ate buffet style...which is hard to do with a large group in a small venue.

the hibiscus margarita was OMG good, not just good, and i dont say that too often about mixed drinks.

the ambiance, the colorful art work, and the music make me want to come back here as well. the staff was friendly and had a great sense of humor.

in all, little baobab is like the date u would give a second chance(because u cant turn down, down to earth), hoping that the next time he shows up a little more presentable and put together and a comb has run a few times across his hair. ;)

onto the last stop...
author: Bee B.

description:
I like this place for a good dinner or a Saturday night DJ Chief Boima dance dance revolution time.  If its your Birthday and you go with a group of 6+ you get a free pitcher of a house drink!  Make sure to bring id cause thats the only way you gonna get it!
Stop by on a Saturday night for some serious dancing whenever DJ Chief Boima is spinning.  He can spin a serious set.  And regardless of when you go the drinks are on point.  Watch out cause they sneak up on you!
author: Theresa V.

description:
This place is tiny!  BUT this tiny place offers a chance to escape America and experience the true meaning of life.  MUSIC.  If you like world music OR want to step into an atmosphere where everybody is smiling and happy to be squeezed together while the DJ is playing music that sounds like you should be partying on a small tropical island OR getting frisky in a populated city somewhere in Africa than you must go here.

In the words of Fela Kuti, "MUSIC IS THE WEAPON".
author: Justin C.

description:
Is it rude or politically incorrect to say I felt like I was in Africa when I was here?

Hopefully that comes out good, because this place was fun fun fun! My friends and I came here last night and it was packeddddd. The music was awesome (I would much rather dance to music like this instead of that crap hip hop they play in Downtown San Jose clubs), and the people there were friendly. It was about 10 degrees hotter, tiny, and perfect for when you're drunk and looking for some fun sweaty dancing with friends. =) Don't bring your guy friends here. Only come with the girls.

07.30.2010 - Update about the Food

I came here about a week ago for dinner. I had no idea they served food here! I've just gone to Bissap Baobab! Anyway, I got the salmon baked in spinach and it was a very well cooked salmon (as in they did a good job). The outside was completed crispy while the inside was still juicy and tender. MmmM! Saltiness was perfect, mashed potatoes were normal. I was just mainly impressed with the fish.

I'd come back for the food if I were in the mood for Senegalese food. Very decently priced, but portions may be a little small for boys that are big eaters (my guy friend said he didn't get enough food). If you're coming with a large group, make reservations! The place is small--surprisingly smaller than you think! I really don't know how they fit all those people in there when it becomes a dance club!
author: Angela H.

description:
After my experience with Bissap Baobab, which was underwhleming and unimpressive (really, a lot), I was actually sort of excited to try this place.  I'm not sure why exactly.  Again, I've heard raves about this place.  And there are  loads of good reviews.  I think I just really wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt.

So last night (on a Monday) my beau and I were in need of heel-kicking-up, and some libations.  I thought, Gee, Little Baobab would be perfect.  All the glory of those very tasty drinks without the wretched service and horrific wait.  That will teach me.  We arrived to find the place closed on Monday night at 9:30pm.  There were people inside.  And they just stared out the windows, from behind the locked doors.  Holding my delicious beverage hostage.  It was not to be.

So sad.  I mean, who isn't open on Monday night?
author: Christy T.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in the city.  Seriously.  I made reservations for my birthday this year and the staff went out of their way to accommodate me and my 12 guests!  Super smooth service, amazing atmosphere and friendly people everywhere!  And the food?  Tantalizing!  I think Little Baobab is highly underrated and needs as much love as they give!  Check this place out!
author: Storm A.

description: This place is incredibly shady. I know 6 people who have had their phones stolen at this bar in the last few weeks.  I would highly recommend NOT going to Little Baobab if you want to keep all of your belongings.
author: Lizzy A.

description:
Want to see your friends gyrate and move their bodies in ways you've never seen?  Then go here.  Dance your ass off, drink lots of yummy drinks, and feel like you love life, because as you dance without any inhibitions you will realize that you do.  Others say it gets too crowded, but I went with a group of ten people and we got there at 10 pm on a Saturday and left at about 12:30 am and everyone told me that they actually enjoyed feeling like they had space to dance.

Must be open to different kinds of music, don't come here if all you want to hear is the latest Rhianna song or that awesome new Sean Kingston song.  Hey, I admittedly like dancing to those songs (I know, don't worry I've had therapy)...but this is not the place if that's all you want to hear.

Oh, and it's cheap! Yea, $3...or if you have lots of peeps they will help you out.  It's kind of like sliding scale payment for therapy (see, I told you that I went)
author: Katie O.

description:
I liked this place and will be back.
Cons: no soap in the bathroom! Gets too crowded;  they have got to stop letting people in after a certain point!
Pros: good lamb dish, good avocado appetizer, good shrimp dish. Great music, friendly people, reasanable priced.The drinks are ok, but a little too sweet (banana margarita) or a little too weak (tamarind margarita). Nice atmosphere.
author: Kay s.

description:
If there was a 10 star option, Little Baobab would earn it!! 
You spend the summer working, living, breathing, learning and experiencing Tanzania and you want to rekindle that spark so far away from your second (or third, or fourth made home) where do you go? Here of course! My admiration for this place comes from all the reminiscing it had me do and yet there were a bunch of others that were loving their night here as well. 
Standard service perks that make this place even more amazing: 
-Like a dufus, for the first time in my life, I forget my ID, and yet, I was allowed to enjoy my night inside 
-The workers and clientele have a not from around here vibe that I am naturally drawn to 
-The bartender is super lax, friendly and awesome: 1. We ordered Soju and Pineapple (They were out of a few other concoctions) and as we sipped them down, he poured the extra for us! 2. Our favorite song was playing and after we took a shot we went to go dance without paying yet. The bartender took us as honest and said "Don't worry about it" with a smile when we went back to pay and apologized. 
-Drinks were really reasonable: mixed: $7, shots and beer $4-5 each, even in SF! 
-The DJ played P SQUARED! Do ME! Yessss....! He also played music form the Congo that we saw performed LIVE in TZ! It took us back in the best ways possible. While he didn't have Beanie Man and some others, he did suggest bringing it to play next time! The music is unique, cultural, and great! 
-The crowd is very international. Traditional men dance circles that just make you think..."They are so born knowing this" and "I have no cue how they do it!" 
-They have a self serve water station! The bar lines weren't so crazy this night...but what an awesome idea! 
-Even the DJ came to dance! This place is chill, relaxed and fun. If you're not sweating by then end then you're just not into it I guess...too bad for you. 

-Bathrooms not equipped with typical soap but dish soap will do the trick. 

This establishment has moved a couple doors down to a bigger location...plenty of room to dance now. Its called Bollyhood Inc, I think.
author: Ashley B.

description: They have a $3 beer happy hour until 7:30 that includes Fat tire, Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Pilsner, and some weissabeir. The waitress/bartender was helpful and cute. The food looked good, I didn't eat. I'd say the main problems are that the acoustics are terrible to the point that it's difficult to carry on a conversation, and they keep it freezing cold in there.
author: Manny F.

description:
you guys still have it. 

we ate there and then loved the music so we stayed through! bombinist beats, sickest little mc. I will be back for thursdays!
author: Amber K.

description:
For me and my crew, there's one place to fuel up before an extended romp through the bars of the Mission district: Little Baobob. Lets just go down the list, shall we?

Drinks: There are all kinds of insaine specialty cocktails here that my crew and I treasure. They are both flowery and deadly. 

Food: So I order the Chicken Mafi evey time we go here. I know for a fact that rest of thier menu is just as delicious (I've snatched my fair share of bites from friends' plates), but the Mafi sauce just kills me everytime. The guys here are always happy to give us extra sauce when we ask for it. Chicken Mafi: Know it, love it, eat it.

Atmosphere: It's hot, it's sexy, and there's always a great vibe going down.

Do not go to Little Baobab expecting to find unhappy people. It's just not going to happen.
author: Josh R.

description: Great dancing. hot, steamy, small but cozy. Try the tamarind or ginger margaritas - delicious, cheap and full of things other than corn syrup :)
author: Jordan S.

description:
there wasn't anything outstanding with this place. the ambiance was okay but the food was 2 stars at best. my roommates and i decided to check this place out and we couldn't really eat anything. i am not a picky eater at all; in fact, people usually give me their leftovers because i am a garbage disposal. but i have to say even i had trouble finishing everything on my place. one of my roommates just flat out didn't touch her food at all after the first bite. what got me the most was that they also didn't offer much of a selection of real west african food. 

oh well :(
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
I am rating this little gem from a bar perspective. I didn't get the food, so look for food reviews somewhere else!

Why do I heart this place? 

1) I don't have to scream my head off to talk with my friends
2) Delicious drinks at a phenomenal price (try the melon one, they make fresh batches throughout the night)
3) The bartenders were so sweet! (or maybe because it was still early in the night...)
author: Lisa W.

description:
I have not been here since my initial review. I went last night and had a great time. I think the dancefloor was bigger than before and for that, I bump them up to 5 stars.  It was good to be with folks just killin' it on the dancefloor and not being to cool for school.


This place is a trip. I like it. Unlike all the other scenester places, this place seems to stay the same. If I'm hammered and in that neighborhood, I'll poke my head in.
Pros:
-catch it on week night and you'll get a cool date place. By the time you're done with dinner, the DJ might have a small dance floor going.
-Fruity cocktails a man can drink and still call himself a man.
-Service is always attentive.
-They had Red Stripe before those silly commercials.
-The only time raggaeton makes any sense.
-I came once during x-mas vacation when a bunch of Senegalese dudes travel back home and I was once again the token black guy in an SF club. I had a killer time but my date didn't appreciate girls hitting on me;)
-People actually dance there.
-The food is great. It's like Cha Cha meets Massawa, but lighter.
Cons:
-Saturday night may be tough to get in. It's tight and sweaty, but some folks dig that. I really feel like I'm not in the states anymore.
-Best to leave your coat in the car. (when you're a guy with a woman, your job is to stow all gear). You just have to put in on a bench in a corner underneath some other stuff, say a hell mary and dance with one eye on it at all times. I broke some joker off trying to walk out with a friend's purse (punk).
-If your a white girl, watch out. The  Senegalese cats will try to fulfill your vacation dreams of  getting nasty with a "exotic" man.
-As mentioned above, if you're  a white girl some Senegalese dude will try to make you his 2nd or 3rd wife. I have a couple of friends to attest to this;)

I think everyone needs to check it out at least once.
author: Bill M.

description: To prove to you, my Yelp audience, that I am more than a joyless shrew who doesn't enjoy fun, I write this review of Little Baobab, a place I enjoyed very much until it turned into a human oven and I got trapped between a lady looking for her sweater and a couple bumping and grinding (anyone remember that R. Kelly song?). In any case, when there was more than a few inches in which to move, this is a really fun place in which to shake your ass to some delightful island tunes. And also drink FIVE DOLLAR ginger margaritas. I love that the curtains are drawn shut so a) no one can see you, tape it on their cell phone and put it on youtube, and b) you don't remember that you're at 20th and Mission. I hate covers, but the 3 dollars to enter this little place is worth it. So see? I don't hate everything. Just most things.
author: Maria D.

description: I've never shaken my ass so hard.  I went to Little Baobab for a birthday celebration with a group.  When we showed up, it was pretty empty, so I thought, okay... we'll start the party.  ($3 cover on Friday and $5-$7 delicious drink specials.) Then, slowly, the place filled up to capacity.  This didn't stop anyone from getting down to incredibly danceable grooves.  It gets hot; the line to the bathroom can be long, but you'll sweat out all that alcohol anyway shaking all that junk out of your trunk.  And, evidently, white as I am...I can get crunk. I also can collect phone numbers without remembering doing so. The messages left on my machine were hilarious the next day.
author: Shelley T.

description:
This place is different.  It is different than any bar I have been to in a long time.  It reminded me of being in Mexico or Puerto Rico.  All we needed was a beach nearby and not a stinky closet to make it work completely.  When my friends and I first arrived the crowd was still warming up.  There were people on the edges of the floor still getting comfortable with the idea of dancing.  Not too long after our arrival the people started arriving.  And boy was it packed!  All races were there and in what seemed to be a very genuine way.  I was surprised because-even in places that seem diverse like the mission-usually the crowd is regulated to a bunch of white well read folks or hipsters or something like that.  Rarely do you get Hispanics and African Americans and Asians.  It was refreshing.  Honestly-a bit of a seeming paradise in a way.  It is a bit of a meat market pick up scene where some macho like guys sort of surround some of the dancing women on the floor.  
And=counter to the tropical vibe-because the space is so run down and you can see the chefs in the background washing dishes and the ground feels unfinished, the ceiling sorta falling apart and the makeshift bar on the side-it kind of just feels like a high school party.  Like some guy had his basement for the weekend while his parents were away so invited every one and their brother over to dance.  And dance you do and dance you will.  You pretty much have no choice.  Because if you are in the room you have to move with the collective sweaty mass of people or you will be left out, literally left outside.  
I had a great time here on Saturday night and I highly recommend this place for  a good time with friends.  
I did not eat there and honestly would be somewhat afraid to based on some of the horror stories involving roaches and such in past reviews.  The place just doesn't strike me as incredibly clean.  I mean, I like my dancing dirty but not my food.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Little Baobab, is a quaint, low-key, electic (the decor evokes the product of leaving a pre-schooler in a room w/ paint and some unfinished furniture) alternative when its older sibling just around the corner (Bissap Baobab) happens to be closed on Mondays.  When Kuya Arnold G. and I got there, we were told that they had Happy Hour specials of $3 pints and half off for all well-drinks. Would've been nice if my kidneys were at 100%. We ordered the fried plaintains w/ tamarind yogurt sauce (sweet and tart, though it really didn't seem yogurty in consistency), which were just what my growling stomach needed as we waited for Unni Sooj O. to stop by. (No, I'm not having ethnic cultural identity issues). 

Now, I had never had Senegalese/West African food before, so I was glad that we were all family-style friendly eaters. It seemed that the menu was on the short side and many of the dishes sounded the same....some kind of meat (lamb, chicken, tofu) w/ either sauteed spinach or mushrooms on a bed of couscous or rice. Well, we tried to diversify and had Cari Tofu (a thin, translucent curry sauce, but very different from any other curry spice blend that I've ever had. you think curry and expect something a little more piquant), Chicken Mafe (peanut sauce served w/ the fluffiest, most buttery couscous I've had in a while), and the Lamb N'Dala (well, it was N'something - lamb w/ a thick brown spinach sauce). I'd say the lamb was the best dish we had. Though it was an experience of new foods, I wasn't particularly impresed w/ the uniformly subdued flavors. Plus, all the meat was overcooked. Chew. Chew. Chew. Chew. Chew. Big gulp. 

It's a really small place, so you'd think the waitress/hostess would be a little bit more in tune with the service. Wrong. She looked like she was going to pass out/fall asleep from trying to be so hip. I'd be really curious what this place is like when it's more "Night Life" than "Restaurant." Something tells me that food isn't its strength.
author: Steph P.

description:
this is a review for late night Little Baobab (the club):

this place smelled like gym socks wrapped in bacon with the bacon hot dog cart sizzling outside and sweaty bodies rubbing into you everywhere - GRODY!

teenagers were groping and making out on the dance floor like finalists for a big red commercial - DOUBLE GRODY!

if i wanted to be transported back to "the worst of my high school years, " i definitely would not be paying the $5 cover they charged that night to do it.
author: Josie M.

description:
so so crowded with people dancing their asses off to some pretty sweet afrojams. i paid $5 to get in and another $5 for a strangely good whiskey-orange-ginger drink.

bass kind of crapped out halfway through the night. it was discouraging, but then someone busted out a bigass drum to make up for it. nice.
author: Ronny K.

description: We swarmed Little Baobab like locusts prior to the Yelp event at Bollyhood. Little Baobab satiated our thirst without blinking an eye at the growing and anxious crowd.
author: Kevo M.

description:
what a great vacation from your normal mission scenester bar!

the convenience of the mission can be a curse as well as a blessing.  there are so many bars here, that it is hard to justify jumping on a bus or hailing a cab someplace else.  but so many of the bars are the same, sometimes i can't remember if i went to cassanova or delirium or what.

but little baobab is the mission's hidden jewel.  i managed to talk some friends into going here last night for what was supposed to be "french and african hip hop."  it wasn't, it was reggae and old school hip hop, but what does it matter?  everyone here is dancing.  i can't remember the last time i went someplace where EVERYONE was.  even my too cool scenester friends found themselves shakin it.

and thats why i say its a vacation from the mission.  the place is so packed there is no time to worry about what other people are doing or thinking.  there is only room to dance.

and we did
author: Steve S.

description: Best Hibiscus Margaritas ever! This crazy little dive is like going to a house party in someones garage and the crowd is so eclectic, it's really hard to not have fun here.  I have never tried the food because we usually come here to warm up for a long night of dancing. The dance floor is a blast and the music is great but I think a prerequisite of DJing here is not being able to mix. I try hard so hard not to laugh when the next song comes on as they make the most horrible beats at the transitions. Have a few hibiscus margaritas and the crazy bassakwards beats all add to the charm of Little Baobab.
author: Lisa J.

description: This place was off tha hook last night!  Little Baobab is a fabulously dark, dingy, cramped, little sweatbox rockin the reggae, reggaeton, soca, and old school hip-hop.  It fondly reminded me of the hole in the wall Caribbean clubs back in NYC (minus the roaches).  The crowd -diverse, the vibe -chill, and the whole place was all about getting their groove/grind on.  I will definitely go back.
author: Angela N.

description: Little is the operative word in this clubs name, it is small, and on a Saturday night absolutly frikin packed to the gills, but i've heard from others tat thursdays are a good time to go. Anyway this place is somewhere to dance, the music is eclectic, as is the crowd and the atmosphere is really good, everyone seems to be here for a good time. Even showing up there at midnight on a saturday, the cover was like $4, the red stripe $3, and we got a spot on the dance floor, but there was a lot of jostling.
author: Karl L.

description: Cool tiny, tiny little club off of misson on 19th. Its right around the corner from the associated restaurant- bissap boabab so dont get confused with it. Its real islandy feel, great hibiscus and ginger drinks! 5$ too and they got some fruity cocktails. The bathroom is decent too, they spin a real mix usually of calypso, african, reggae, hip hop, latin world music. Real diverse. It was kinda funny though, the dj put on apache by the incredible bongo band(classic hip hop break) and I was about to bust into my bboy moves(omar) the other dj wispered in his ear and he abruptly cut into a different track. aww another night for my showcase. but it was free before 11 and I think its only 5$ after that. Cool place, diverse crowd, whiteys africans, latinos. some asians. it was cool.
author: Jhoe G.

description: Best African dance music in the city, hands down.  I love dancing here with my eyes closed, because if I open them I realize that people, many of them sweaty and of the male variety, are moving around very, very close to me.  So I don't go here when I'm feeling claustrophobic, but I do when I really need a good, loud soundtrack to my life.
author: Rhea S.

description:
Everybody was going into Bollyhood. So I thought, "how can it hurt me if it looks so good?" Apparently it does hurt. The wallet. You think "Well, $10 cover charge is no big." It is for a cheap rat like me. 
I love Samba music to the point where it's unhealthy at times. But $10? For a Favela-themed party? No.
So my friend and I decided to go to the Beauty Bar at the corner, as there was no cover charge there. It was OK, American music with people bobbing their head here and there. But I called it quits when I tripped over one of those space-helmet hair dryers. 
So we decided to leave and check out Little Baobab. $5 cover charge. It was doable. As soon as we open the door, I was simply drawn in by this energy that was buzzing around. I can't explain it, but it just produced a fever to dance. And that's what I like about Little Baobab. Everyone is there to dance. Not sway, not bob, not holding your drink while you dance in a circle with a pile of purses in the middle and check out the meat market produce of the night, but DANCE! And by Jove if you don't dance you will just be trampled. It was mostly Calypso/Soca with a little Reggaeton sprinkled in here and there to keep it diverse. I was never a fan of Calypso music, but it just sucks you into this tornado of happiness and bliss.
Sure the air was dense with sweat, which would have really bothered me, had it not been for the fact that there were fans on throughout. They could do without the random black lights, as they tend to make the eyes of that creeper at the corner (who has been staring you down) glow. And then you can't look away because it's just so bizarre, so he takes it as a positive hint and smiles, which makes his whole set of teeth glow white. It's like Aladdin's Genie came to life and wants your soul. But I digress.
author: Eloïse A.

description: Am I the only one who wasn't totally impressed with this place?  I came here for a night of dancing with some friends and the music was kind of hard to dance to...It sounded like some kind of island music to me.  The room we danced in was dark and way too crowded which led to profuse sweating within a few minutes.  It was small, cramped, and hard to see the people you were dancing next to.  Maybe it just wasn't my kind of music or scene.  And the bathroom was absolutely atrocious...No toilet seat and the one roll of toilet paper had fallen into the toilet.  Eek!  I must say, the drinks were pretty good, though.  I think I ordered the 'Baobab special' or something like that which was sweet, fruity, and totally refreshing while also totally intoxicating.  Check this place out if you want to experience a different kind of nightclub...but I can't say it's one of my favorites.
author: Jacqueline B.

description: This place is amazing, I love everything I've ever gotten but my favorite is the Seafood CoCo. YUM!
author: Peggy G.

description:
ive never eaten here.

ive been through a couple times when the dancing was going.

here is why there are two stars up there:

1) the night scene is kinda cool

2) while working on a cooking show pilot here, a large roach ran out from under a rag in the kitchen

so yeah. dont eat here.
author: Darrell L.

description:
it was a friend's bday and he had reservations at cha cha cha's on mission but of course we were late since we were all on asian time.  we got sick of waiting (and we were on a tight schedule) so we went over to this tiny place around the corner.  bissap baobob is right next to cha cha chas but it was just as crowded so we went to the sister restaurant little baobob.  only one of us knew the place but it came highly recommended by her. and it wasn't an upset at all! 

i've never had senegalanese food before but it was great! most of the dishes i can't even pronounced but everyone there loved their dishes. i had the shrimp in this coconut sauce and rice. the sauce was AMAZING. my friends and i tried to like it all up literally! it was slightly rich due to the coconut but had a hint of spice which gave a harmonious balance of spicy smoothness of heaven. drinks were also good. we had pitchers of the tamarind drink and the hibiscus but i was partial to the hibiscus. and everyone shared fried plantane appetizers

the place is very small but staff and service was very accomodating for our large group. it's definitely more of an intimate place and it's very casual.  apparently late nights there it's a hoppin' salsa scene where all these great dancers come out.  

only thing i'd say is that some portions are bigger than others depending on what you get. but it's definitely one person a plate it's not that big in portions but you are able to get full off of it.
author: Kim D.

description: Love the atmosphere, music, and people. Something different. Drinks are reasonably priced. Worth the 5 dollar cover. Overall a friendly place!!
author: Allison W.

description: This place goes out of the ordinary typical club you go to every now and then and takes you to a different experience. You'll find reggae music, African music, Indian, salsa all with a guaranteed good time. The DJ begins Monday through Saturday from 10 to 2. From about 8 to 10 you can have a little snack from their extensive Senegalese cuisine. They have allot of different drinks such as drinks made with ginger, hibiscus and allot of other unusual stuff. Make sure you bring a light jacket if you drive there because the place gets packed like you wouldn't believe. Once you're in there dancing within inches from many others in a relatively small place, all you want to do is strip yourself off of anything you're wearing.
author: emmanuel g. g.

description: I had fun at this place, but it was weird. They let WAY TOO MANY people in. And they charge a $5 cover. They must be breaking some major fire codes and profiting off it. Kinda annoying. Impossible to use the bathroom here. The ginger spritzer cocktail thing is excellent. Dancing here was ok...you have to dance, you have no choice b/c it is so small. As soon as you enter, you are on the dance floor. I think the lack of space makes the crowd overly aggressive. Maybe try it on a non-weekend night. Too chaotic on saturday night for me.
author: Allisoto P.

description: Okay...Based on the food alone this place is at least a 4. I only reduced the rating to 3 because it not necessarily the cutest place in the world and the menu was really simple (like only 3 entrees to choice from). It has a lot of character and a nice lil neighborhood feel. The waitress/bartender was very attentive and able to handle a pretty full house by herself. I had a shrimp appetizer that was SO good..kinda spicy...kinda sweet. My friend had the chicken curry - that was pretty good too. We got there early so we were able to park right in front but parking appeared to be tough when we left a couple of hours later. I had the hibiscus margarita - which was so yummy. My friend had ginger tea which was pretty good too. I think this is a great spot to go to if your hanging with local friends to have a good bite, no pressure, good drinks.
author: Raven D.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city...I've been going here for years and every time I am more and more pleased with it. It's a tiny hole in the wall, and if you're not really looking for it, it's very easy to miss. The food is Senegalese, so there's a lot of curry and peanut concoctions on the menu, but everything is delicious. I've never had a bad thing off of the menu. And everything is cheap, including the drinks. Have a tamarind margarita...my personal fav!!! And if you're there past 10 on the weekends, your fold out table and chair will be ripped out from underneath you, the music will bump up as the entire place turns into a mini dance club. It's  awesome!!
author: Chloe D.

description: I love everything about this place. This is the kind of place I love to find when I travel to an exotic location and yet its right here in SF in the Mission! I feel like Im on vacation every time I come here. Marco is the friendliest host and told me last night "You need to come back every weekend, this is your home".  Wow, I've never had such warm hospitality. The house specialty coconut infused rum is so creamy and delicious and definitely made with love! The bartenders are very charming and helpful as well. Come for the delicious food and stay for the dancing. Beware ladies of the men who are very aggressive and will grab your hand to dance before they even make eye contact with you. But hey its all part of the experience just be firm with them. The DJs play the best music ( reggaeton, dancehall, african, hiphop, pop) and you will dance and be sweaty, just revel in it!
author: Robin J.

description: The cover is $5 on Saturdays which is the dancing night.  The "Rose" is tasty and only $5 dollars and will get you faded.  The music is more reggaeton/dance stuff.  A lot of bumping and grinding and slow winding.  People can dance on tables and benches if you want.  Good DJ's usually.
author: Eric M.

description: This has become my go-to dance spot in the city.  Always great music, great energy from everyone in the place, and gotta love their hibiscus margarita.  My only gripe is that it is pretty small, and it gets really packed on the weekends.  And the more packed it gets, the hotter it gets.  So if you really plan on dancing the night away, I would suggest braving the windy SF weather outside, and just go dressed ready to dance.
author: Kaileen M.

description:
danced the fucking night away here last saturday.  or, tried to, until i was forcibly dragged away by my hipster friends to the valenica corridor bla blabla.  i didn't want to leave, and judging by the annoying things that subsequently happened at delirium, i shouldn't have.  


this place is sooooooooo much fun and the ginger margarita and the sangria are soooooooooooo tasty.  the music was a great change from the shitty 80s tunes you are usually subjected to on the weekends in the mission, and despite the fact that it was packed beyond capacity, i only had to wait a minute or two to get a drink.  i can't wait to go back this weekend.
author: calamity d.

description:
Fun little club spot.  Good inexpensive drinks, music was good (reggi the night I was there), and not a really pretentious attitude.  Just about everyone was up and dancing, but no one was grinding in a sleazy way.

Bonus--I went with a group of 8 girls, the cover was supposed to be $5, but they 'weren't charging right now' when we came in.
author: L F.

description: Unassuming, friendly, good music, decent drinks at decent prices.  Small space encouraging body contact (no complaints from me!).  One bathroom, not so convenient.  Peed in the street (sorry, Mission, but you wre sorta asking for it).  This is a fun little joint for later in the night.  Might come back to try the well-revied Senegalese grub.
author: Eric S.

description:
This place fell far short of my expectations mostly because of service. A group of friends and I were out in the mission looking for a group that could comfortably handle our 12-15 size group when a friendly guy waved at us and invited us to sit. This was where it all started to go wrong. 
We were at the bar trying to awkwardly fit, when we saw some empty tables. We all filed in and were happy to finally get a spot for everyone when we were suddenly told we were only welcome to sit for "5 more minutes" by a member of the staff. We decided to at least finish our current round before discussing our next move, when no kidding, a minute later, another staff member comes and tells us we will need to move in 5 minutes. A little annoyed, we continued on with our drinks and conversation, when a minute later (not quite the five minutes we were expecting) we were told we would have to get up NOW. We still had drinks in hand! So a friend stood up to tell some of us out of ear shot what was going on, and his chair was taken from underneath him, without warning or apology. Slowly tables were taken right from under our arms, and we were not offered alternative seating. 
Disgusted, I pulled the man aside who had been taking the chairs and told him how I felt about their choice to force us so quickly from our seats. He offered a sorry, but said it is "the rules" and quickly went back inside to take more tables from still seated friends finishing their drinks. 
Now to be fair, I didn't try the food, but it didn't look awful. We never got a chance to get further than our single round of drinks, and that it probably as close as I'll get to their food. In a neighborhood filled with great food and atmosphere, I wouldn't risk the embarrassment of going through this again.
author: Kelly B.

description: Went in for after-work drinks with co workers and fell in love with this Senegalese bar. Tried the appetizers and would highly recommed the plantains with yogurt-tamarind dip. Even the guacamole was pretty darn tasty. The hibiscus margarita and coconut infused rum cocktail are a definite crowd pleaser but more so that the food and drinks is the bonafide, West African vibe at this spot .  The music was spot on and the candles and cozy decor made me feel as if I was at a bar in Dakar, Accra or Freetown.....at least as close as one can get being in San Francisco which is essentially devoid of any West African influences. Friendly service, good food, good drinks, great music....that's what eating out is all about!
author: Ijay J.

description:
Went to Little Baobab Saturday with a big group of friends for dinner which surprisingly wasnt an issue considering the restaurants smallish interior. 

Food was de-lish and not $$....we shared some apps (platanos were ta die) and my entree of chicken was awesome. Order any cocktail with the ginger liquor! Yum....

We had been told that it literally turned from dinner to dance party in a matter of minutes, and that it did. Tables were cleared and the DJ started it up.....and there were no awkward middle school dance moments. Thank you strong baobab cocktials.

Definitely a great spot to bring out of town guests to show them how cool you are. Definitely comin back.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Where else can you enjoy the real feel of a West African cafe?  Hole-in-the-wall but appropriate decor, there is high life music playing in the background, staff is friendly and funky.  Yummy sauces on the entrees and very unique beverage choices including hibiscus, mango, and ginger juices and cocktails.  I travelled down from North Beach twice this week.
author: Chris N.

description: My wife and I (who moved from SF years ago) had to stop back in to Little Baobab when we were in the city on a weekend trip. The food was great and ambiance was as cozy as we remembered (even though they changed locations).
author: Mike C.

description:
the two stars is for the teeny tiny venu which makes me think that i can host a club in my apartment.  

i heard the food was deelish but i have yet to savor it so this is just for dancing.

the place gets too packed but i guess the guys at the door see cha-ching! with each person they charge cover.  if it wasn't for a friend's b-day bash here, i'd probably skip it.  yeah, the music is kickin' but the sweaty crowd gets old.  

there is a small outside area for the nicotine fiends.  if ya need some space to chill, just stand by me, my stinky cigars usually shoo away the cigarette smokers.
author: Anh V.

description: This place is purrrrrrfect for taking someone who you just can't work the nerve to get freaky with because it is so damn crowded that you have no choice but to end up bumpn' & grindn'.  However, if ur trying to look for a place that u can dance w/ your friends AND be able to sit & have a drink - this place ain't it!  Speaking of getting drinks, I thought my man ditched me cause he took so damn long.  Now the crowd is generally mellow and the music is pretty cool though it did use to play more international world music.  Overall, the place is cool especially if you want to get your freak on.
author: Mabel L.

description: Yet another reason I would get fat if I lived in the Mission.  I can't get enough of the food at this place, and the drinks are very tasty.  My personal fave is the Le Roi.  I've only been there in the early evening, so I'm not sure about all of these sweaty cramped closet references, but dinner is great.
author: Meghan S.

description: I love this place!  It's much better than the big one, the decor is unique - makes you feel like you've stepped out of SF and into a funky, charming island-ish cafe.  The food is yummy - a much needed change from the typical uber hipster haunts.
author: Aga N.

description: I really like this place during the week for dinner.  I've also been on a Saturday night for the music and It was a little too crowded and way too noisy (that's the point of the music).  The food is great and the house specialty cocktails are amazing.  Everyone who works there is nice and the atmosphere makes you feel like you could step out onto the beach.  Nothing in the place is expensive either.
author: Corey V.

description:
I was lured in by the tales of cheap happy hour, which I was informed by my waiter two weeks no longer exists.  The pitcher of margaritas we ordered was great, after we waited half an hour to get said waiter/bartender's attention while he chatted with a steady stream of friends coming in and out of the locale. At one point I tried to order from the bar and he shooed me away indicating that he was coming... ten minutes later. The chips and guac my friend ordered was decent although definitely not a good chip to guacamole ratio (not enough chips by far).

On the whole, a disappointing experience. It is quite possibly a much better place later in the night, but I didn't feel the desire to stay to find out.


****************
UPDATE

When I did go back for the nightlife, I was ENCHANTED. For anyone who loves world beats, Little Baobab will not disappoint. However cold it is in San Francisco outside, come prepared to sweat inside! And dance your booty off...
author: Rickie I.

description: I've been trying to grab a bite here forever, but I finally got the chance last week. I like the shabby ambiance of B.B. I had a lamb dish, very good. The plantains were a bit greasy, but that's a too easy complaint. But a dance club... Really? If it is, I would be afraid of doing a shimmy right into a bowl of couscous!!!
author: wayne s.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is...I think the majority of good reviews were for the dancing/dance club?

Anyway, the food I had tasted horrible I think I ordered chicken of some sort. It was covered in this sauce that had the distinct flavor of charcoal. 

The plantains were good...but they are better next door at Triple CHA. 

My advice, go to Triple CHA and get the sangria and the plantains...you'll be happier.
author: Matt G.

description: This is for the night life only - i used to LOVE coming to this place! I didnt mind when it was packed and could hardly move or plenty of space and first on the dance floor, was great people and great fun!!!! Then one night a friend and I were dancing on the floor when a random lady pushed my friend for no reason, almost knocking her on me. Remind you this is a packed club and my friend and I usually ignore random bumps and elbows since it will happen at a club. But my friend turned around when it happened a second time and said  "EXCUSE YOU" - may not have been in a nice tone, but neither was the push. Immediately this woman starts placing the palm of her hand in my friends face and told her "I need my space, b****!" We have been dancing in the same spot for over 2 hours already, and we are peaceful people who have NEVER EVER in the 15 years I have known my friend, NEVER ONCE have been in a fight or even a heated conversation with another person. My friend felt threatened and was ready to defend herself from this crazy person who was continuing with her threats and "ENTITLEMENT" of the spot she has now claimed on the very packed dance floor. I grabbed my friend and we went outside, I told the bouncer that there was a woman inside that was starting fights and pushing random people and that she pushed my friend and started attacking us. They asked me to point her out and I did, I told them I don't mind giving a statement and pointing this person out because I would hate another person who was having a great time to be disturbed by a person on the dance floor pushing her way through. They then told my friend and I that this person knew the owner and there was nothing else but to talk to her about the incident. As I was waiting on another friend to come out of the bathroom, I noticed the bouncer talking to this woman and thought good, they got her. Then saw her go back in. The bouncer told my friend and I that they cannot kick her out because she knew the owner, so we left! I am sorry, but I will not give business to someone who allows their friends to disrespect their place of business (who does that - FYI I would never have the nerve to disrespect any of my friends places of business, whether they work there or own them!) and has the right to disturb and harass their PAYING customers in that sort of way. I will truly miss you Baobab, you were a great place to go EVERY weekend! I will no longer recommend this place when anyone asks where a great place to dance was! very sad and disappointing indeed!
author: Nia A.

description: The music's phenomenal hip hop, African, and some Latin beats. The crowd is consistently gorgeous, the dancing is phenomenal, and the drinks are delicious. Just come during the week or early on the weekend to avoid the hot sweaty crowds.
author: Seiji C.

description: Went here to dance after dinner elsewhere.  It's itsy-bitsy, but they play a fun mix of music.  A little hip-hop, a little top 40, and a little stuff from other countries (is there a term for non-American music?  international music?  world music?).  I don't remember the crowd much, except that it was crowded.  It gets hot.  There's one bathroom, and it's a bit nasty.
author: S J.

description: I went here for my birthday because I heard the dancing was good.  The place had a real feel of authenticity and I was impressed by how the space was used.  The drinks were great and the dancing was awesome.  I look forward to coming earlier next time to try the food.
author: lena m.

description: My wonderful, crazy French friend brought me here, the two of us sans enfants for the first time together. I was a bit skeptical, as I scanned the crowd that looked like they were mostly born the year I graduated high school. A couple of tart, lovely hibiscus margaritas and infectious beats later, and it became a whole new experience. I felt like I was transported to a foreign land where all ages and colors and creeds meshed together in a sweetly, sweaty, sexy vibing dance party. It was only a matter of time that we were surrounded by the most charming Colombian mathemeticians, who were also amazing dancers. The tallest Colombian, with the Andy Garcia eyes, not only made an awesome merengue partner, but he also made my week, by sincerely assuring me that I had to  be much younger than he. Of course, I was right, and he was born when I was a sophomore. But, Hey on a cool, foggy Friday night  at Little Baobab...the world seems warm and sensuous and magical...and for that moment in time, there is no such thing as age.
author: christine a.

description: I come here when I want to be transported back in time to the dark & sweaty tropic-raggae bar in Puerto Viejo de Talamanca.  Or when I want to feel that spicy gurgly goodness in my belly the way I felt after my first glass of jus de gingembre on Air Afrique en route Paris to Abidjan.  Or when I want to remember the stunning ivory light shining upon me like rays of sunshine from heaven that is a Senegalese smile.   Or when I want to drink Red Stripe for $3 like I did in Jamaica mon.  Oh wait, I've haven't been to Jamaica.  Yet.  But I bet $3 for a beer is a fair price there too.
author: Molasses C.

description: This place would be way cooler (literally) if they had proper ventilation and the bar wasn't cash only at night. 2.4 Stars. I have not had the food so don't let this rating dissuade you from that.
author: Shooter M.

description: It's been 4 years since my last visit to Little Baobab.  I spent my 30th birthday there in a ginger infused fog dancing the night away.  Upon my arrival last night I saw many of the same faces and a few new ones.  The drinks are better than ever and the dancing just as fun.  I always meet sweet genuine people there and leave with a sense of happiness.  Little Baobab is one of those rare little gems in this city that I hope has lasting staying power.
author: Anne D.

description: Had a great time with two of my girls.  Walking into this place, you feel as if you're on an Island Paradise.  The world of SF leaves not only your sight, but also your mind.  The music was old school hip hop with some island flavor mixed in.  The crowd was very "Mission" and unpretentious.  Check it out...you'll be glad you did!
author: Shane P.

description: Do you love Dirty Dancing?  Do you still say "no one puts baby in a corner"?  If so, this is the place to be on the weekends.  A date and I stumbled upon this little club a couple of months ago for the "nectar infused" margueritas and ended up submerged in an awesome african funk dance party.  People were sweating, people were grinding and my normally conservative boy toy became a Justin Timberlake-like dancing machine.  Wooow.  A few weeks later I took some girlfriends from out of town, and while we didn't get kinky, we def cut up a rug.  Be warned that you will leave with your neighbors sweat all over your shirt...but I kind of like that....
author: Claire C.

description: Tamarind juice and alcohol and Senegalese dance music? I'll go.
author: patrick g.

description: You sort of saunter in to the threads of Bobby Womack crooning over bedraggled bar-top speakers. The turnstile light spins to catch you in the eye, before turning it's attention to a disco ball rolling through its perennial summer groove. Shut those eyes she smiles - him drifting into a chorus, a choir of afro-haired black broads in rollergirl get-up spinning circles to your mood, teeth flashing and tummy's bare. Nobody's saying nothing, faces attached to undulating nods. I push past a random thought and pull up a chair at the bar, couscous and a coloured drink has me set. This was the good life.
author: Marc M.

description: One of my favorite places in the city! The drinks are unique, strong, and tasty as hell! The security and bartenders are friendly. Most importantly the music is awesome!! If you're not dancing in this club then you've never learned to walk, cause the vibe of the club will make you wanna shake whatever you got. Most Saturdays no matter where I start my night out in the city I'll usually end up there somehow.. No dress code, close to nothing cover, great music and  fun people. Go Check it out!
author: Zack A.

description: great music, crowded as hell, great for dancing up against a ton of others, fun fun fun, even when you can't dance worth shit but like to nonetheless. Again, great music.
author: Today Y.

description: Yummy food. Amazing DJ. Dance floor is too small. Diasporic black men looking for homely white girls ........and finding them. Yawn.
author: Leah K.

description: I have been wanting to try this place for 3 years.  Thanks to my friend having her going away party it finally happened.  We got there early and caught the happy hour just in time...nothing better than a 2.50$  Sierra.  The second was caipirinha cocktail - amazing - a blend between a margarita and a mojito and I hate mojitos.  The food was fantastic and very moderately priced.  My first Senegalese experience.  The best part is that they were playing great Reggaeton music - Caribbean music.  Even though we couldn't stay for the DJ, they stamped us and encouraged us to return.  I could easily become a regular at this little joint.
author: J J.

description: Get a closet, make it 400 degrees in there, give it a Senagalese flair with some bumpin' music and wa-lah! Lil Baobab is your place! Gets super crowded so come early or totally wasted, your choice.
author: Michael E.
