description: good food. free pitcher of margarita on birthday when you buy a few dishes. i especially liked the hibiscus margarita. see also: the coconut shrimp and the plantains with tamarind sauce, they are glorious. no cover if you go there for dinner; at 10 it becomes a little dance hall with awesome music (some nights it's senegalese with electronic drum circle feel at times) but get out of there by 11:45 because it becomes kind of a clusterfuck, unless you particularly enjoy being smooshed in a sweaty crowd. sometimes i do sometimes i don't, i just like to give the warning.
author: Josie K.

description: Great spot with great drinks and music. The only reason I took off a star was the number of annoying folks trying to out-africa each other with stories from their year abroad - but perhaps i should be more forgiving.
author: Casey W.

description:
$5 cover for dancing all night, inexpensive drinks, and friendly staff.

It is crowded, hot, sweaty, and all about the dancing.  The music is great.

What more do you need in life?
author: K V.

description:
This review is on the dancing... not the food.

I was getting down on dancing in this city.  I was on board for the big electronic music scene in 2000, but over time the scene became incredibly repetitive... same people, same music, same everything... and the reality no longer lived up to the hype the way it used to.

And besides, I'm a breaks girl... hands down.  Finding good breaks is next to impossible these days with the glitch & constant house overload.

I think I've found a good compromise though at Little Baobab.  I first found the music at this place during carnival & I loved the vibe.  I've started going on the occasional Friday night for some really great African fusion that gives me the syncopation of breaks, the hip action from the latin influences, and a generally good crowd.

It's small, sweaty, and crowded as hell, but I'm completely down with the hibiscus drinks and fun djs.  It's a place where you might get groped, but it's also a place where someone could be asking you to dance because they genuinely want to DANCE with you.  Refreshing.
author: Kelly W.

description:
i came here with a couple friends for something a little different. i ordered a dish with chicken in a red sauce and couscous that was good. 
my friend ordered the special which came with all kinds of stuff--the fish was a little overcooked and he didn't finish his order because there were a bit too many things going on on his plate. prices are decent.
author: Kan L.

description: The fried plantains tasted like candy and the Little Baobab cocktail was divinely delicious! When the bill came, I felt like we had robbed the place. Wonderful prices for such decadent food :)
author: Elise H.

description: Dark, hole in the wall, decor supplied by good will with a touch of cultural flair...SO not there for the scenery.  The food is full of flavor, the drinks are fun and they will squeeze u in somehow.
author: Julia W.

description: You come here to dance. End of story. I didn't know they had food here... huh.
author: Jessica W.

description: Gotta love it for salsa wednesday, reggae thursday, world beat weekends...if only there were more places in the city with good world music (and hot west african men). it gets really crowded, especially on the weekends. and there is no dress code and people are pretty friendly and just there to have a good time. the hibiscus and ginger drinks are incredible!
author: Natasha F.

description: A fun funky tiki bar on a beach like shack surrounded by the cement of the Mission. Nice to pop in early sit at the bar and get a tropical cocktail then head out to nether areas of life. Sit outside if they have the chairs and grass mat fence up for a warm day in ...Indian Summer .... Dance floor is pretty tiny, but good mix of people.
author: miriam b.

description: You can dance, eat, and did I mention dance? I haven't eaten here in years and really don't remember what I had. I think it was good though. Anywho, this is a dependable spot for dancing. If you just want to dance with no pretense this is the place to go. The men are assertive, which can be a good thing if you're interested, but if you're not, you can tell them to back off and they will. Great beats, great crowd, great times, 'nuff said.
author: Wa W.

description: I have heard about this venue from my Timba friends. These are the same friends I hang out with at Pirata on Fridays, but to my dismay, when I went last Wednesday night, I was shocked. It's a dump and the place is very small. Won't go again.
author: Sandra M.

description: Diverse and hot.  Literally hot.  Paws on my tits.  Amazing.
author: Brenda J.

description: (For late night) Better on week nights and on busy nights you got to have "ass cover" i.e. someone to dance behind you, but even then this is, hands down, my favorite place to go dancing in a 30 mile radius. Great tunes, great vibe, hilarious staff . . . I FUCKING DARE YOU to find a more universally excellent place to get down.
author: Jen A.

description: The baked Salmon in banana leaves is pretty memorable. The place was strangely empty for a Saturday evening. Hopefully not a bad sign.
author: Teju A.

description: How the hell did I not know about this place for so long! DELICIOUS smart soulful food, and charming smiling soulful staff. Dude, you need to check this spot out. It's open late and going to be my new spot. Lil Beobap iz da BOMB!
author: Christine M.

description: This is an interesting place. I had no idea this existed until my DJ friends from Portland decided to spin it here last night. It's pretty small (little is an apt name) .... and the location easily fits in 75 to 100 people. Wow, that gets kinda sweaty but apparently, their reputation hold things up.
author: Sav B.

description: Amazing time!!  I went on a Saturday after looking on Yelp for any good spots for dancing, and I was NOT disappointed!  As soon as you walk in, you are hit with a wall of heat...but you don't mind, because the music is so good.  Your body can't help but start moving along with the rest of the gyrating crowd.  The drinks are really tasty too.  I can't wait to go back!
author: S W.

description: This place has a very down-to-earth vibe.  When I went there, almost everyone seemed to be having a blast (aside from a few dudes standing in the corners, watching people dance in a slightly creepy way).  A great mix of people with only perhaps a few former frat boys, and even they were acting decidedly non-frat boy-ish.  I was actually grateful that my drink was watered down, because I needed the hydration after all that hot and sweaty dancing.
author: Emma K.

description: Wow, I was not expecting to go into this tiny place and feel like I was on a Caribbean vacation! Do not miss.
author: Laural B.

description:
We were planing on being somewhere else, but it turned out to be quite crowded there, so we ended up here.
'Eek! ok. who knows, let's give a shot.' Was what I thought when we got there.
We walk in, and was greeted. Cool. I had to do a double take. the guy who greeted us looked more like a bouncer/dancer, rather than a server/host.  After a few seconds I found his whole style rather cool.
I dunno if if I like dark places to have dinner, anymore. It always feel as if the establishment is hiding something.
I make my way to the restroom. Which was near someone's table. Eek.
I couldn't see the light switch. Is this it? I flick up and down a few times. Oh, shit. That's the dining room light!
MORON!! I say to myself. Well, fuck. I can''t see the fucking switch in the fucking restroom...oh. Here it is...ew. Ok. Tiny, awkward, yuck.

After a quick catch up and time deliberating over the menu, the lady server ( who almost psychically ) comes over and takes our order.
I order the spicy shrimp appetizer and the 'E'dole (?)' Spicy Lamb with spinach and peanut sauce. And the Sande. Vodka with ginger and oj. I like spicy. It's like 'Vivacious'
Sounds good right?
Between 7 and 10 minutes my our drinks arrive. Hey, the bartender was busy. 
Wait. This don't taste like what I ordered. I taste gin, grapefruit juice and ginger.
'Dude. I think she got you the Saff!' My friend tells me.
Ah well. Just as good.
About 15 minutes. My App  shows up. Small. Oh well.
Nice soft bread like stuff. Damn. The sauce was incredible! The shrimp was good. But I wanted to drink the sauce from the bowl.
Yeah. That good. I was sad when she took the bowl away, because I was using my fork to eat the rest of the sauce. She didn't even ask if we were done with it. Sigh, so sad.
I finished my drink, and needed a smoke.
Came back 10 minutes later and our food was on the table.
(about a whole 30 minutes after we ordered.  There is maybe about a 18-20 tables in the whole place. small kitchen? 1 cook? who knows?)
i look at my plate.
there is 1 scoop of rice (about 6 0z.) on the plate. and some brown lumpy stuff.
ok.
I taste. Mmmm...pretty good. Nice size cut of lamb. So where is the spinach and the peanut flavor?
Thoughts of ordering another dish pass through my thoughts.
But the love and small tummy of Lolo B. prompts her to give me most of her rice.
My hero. I eat. It's tasty. I'm satisfied.
I thought the bill/prices a bit too high for the totality of what we got, but hey, it's SF,right?
What tripped me out the most was that we were in the middle of their transition from dining room to club/dance place. Tables were being taken away. Our bill was dropped even though we didn't ask for it and i was planning to order more drinks. It was freaky. We were finishing our dinner and there was people sitting and milling about. And we were  one of the last tables. Some guy came by and said something incoherent to us and stamped our wrist.
Wait? What? What's this for?
We figured it out. Finished up. And got out.
Strange. 
Oh well, next stop.
author: Kione E.

description: It's like going to a house party with good friends whom you've never met.  Definitely not a meat market scene.  International music (not just Senegalese when I went), diverse crowd, and great ginger based drinks.
author: Mark D.

description: So this review is for one visit.  DJs were good playing a good mix of reggae, latin, and hip hop music which got me dancing most of the night.  So Little Baobab is a very small restaurant turned into a club at night and it gets very very crowded as the night goes on.  To the point where you can't even walk but reason being the place is not much bigger than my living room.  So the more people the hotter it gets and I was sweating profusely due to the fact that it was hot and I was dancing.  There's only one bathroom and it's in the back so you have to push through the crowd to get to it.  But the biggest thing is that drinks are expensive.  Not a big fan of paying $8 for Jamesons on the rocks.  Besides the music, there isn't anything that great about the place.
author: David C.

description: One of the most unique, wonderful places in town. A great place to go with a friend or partner for a special dinner, drink, dancing. A night to remember.
author: Jenni O.

description:
I first went here a little way back, maybe late '05.  It started on a wednesday night and a co-worker was telling me that there's this koo ass spot on mission that plays some good dancehall.  Knowing me, I'm all down for dancehall so a bunch of us went to go check it out after work.  

So this review is for Wednesday night at Baobab..
Well, to start, this place is very small.  If you think Milk on Haight or Blue Triangle (do they still call it that?) on Fillmore/Lombard was tiny, you'll be amazed how small this spot was.  the DJ took up most of the spot, and it's hard to distinguish what part is bar area or dance area.  Dancefloor is small and can get crowded with drunk people dancin all over the place. Cover was like $2 I think, somewhere rougly at that price. It has a small (very very small) patio outside where people socialize and blah.  The crowd is diverse and down to earth, none of that "I'm urban and I only listen to underground hiphop" or "i'm a bimbo and I'm here to listen to some radio top 40"  type of people that flood the MILK bar (haight).  Ok. Lemme apologize that all sounded kinda stereotypical but, it's not a stereotype for nothin.  But anyhoo, the music was good.  I forgot who was mixin, but I heard alot of music I haven't heard of at that time.  It was koo, because each time a song came up I would tell someone, or anyone, "This is my jam!!" or "Oh My God!! I love this song" and I'd just pull anyone to dance with me.  It could be guy, girl, animal, whatever.  and that's the story of what happens when they play good music.

I know it doesn't sound much exciting, but I had a blast there.  People that go there usually are strictly into the music, and just bein high and sittin there jammin is already good enough. Not sayin I do (don't tell), but also I'm just the type of person that don't care much about goin to a spot JUST to talk to the opposite sex.  Which is the reason why there's so many whack people at clubs.  Whatever.  Thats just some fake ass shit to me.  Why can't alot of people just meet someone when they're sober at  a more suitable spot. Why you gotta have a girl or a guy drunk to be attractive to you? or even ATTRACTED TO YOU? haha! that's some lame game. My bad, needed to vent..but back to the point..

You'll enjoy this spot if your into dancehall, and fine with dancing in with limited space..
and another thing, I don't know how it is now cuz everytime time I pass by there on wed night, it's packed.  Is this another found hidden jewel?
author: ShayShay G.

description: A nice place for a small group to get together for drinks.  Fairly nice selection on the menu of African cuisine.  I've sampled most and they are well prepared.  Dancing usually ensues around 10pm so finish up to avoid having your chair removed out from under you.
author: Ken B.

description: To start, I have to give the staff a lot of credit, everyone was very nice and understanding. That said, my experience here was a bit disappointing. I had been to a big birthday part at Bissap Baobab (what I guess was the larger version of Little Baobab...duh) and really enjoyed myself. The decor, the food, the drinks, everything. Upon returning in search of a unique, fun experience I was disappointed to find out they had downsized to what was no longer fun funky, but sort of depressing funky. The food was even funky, a bit scary to behold and not very impressive in flavor. We ordered the crab and avocado appetizer and I could have sworn it was canned crab with mayonnaise and cumin. Kind of gross, and presented with no care. Basically, its a sad shadow of what it once was and it left me with a bad feeling in my stomach. Whether or not it was the food is still to be determined.
author: Faye M.

description: Yeah, ti is always party time at the Little Baobab. Get ready to mix with friendly, sweaty, smiling crowd, don't take yourself very seriously, and you will enjoy. If you want your space, this place is just not for you. I can't say anything about the food, but I want to try it.
author: Javi V.

description: YUMMIEST drinks!! smaller and more intimate than the other (if i'm not confused), and a great place to get together with friends on a night that's not too crowded.
author: Hae-Jin K.

description: We were trying to get to Bissap Baobab, but since it was closed, we went to this incarnation of it. I liked the intimate bar feeling, and everyone seemed laid back and upbeat there. They had cheap beer (could it have been a mistake that I was charged only $1.75 for a Franzikaner in SF?), tasty fried plaintains and shrimp with coconut, all rocking to African music, not bad at all.
author: Shannon R.

description:
I came here after a friend's birthday dinner for much dancing and joyousness.
It feels more like a house party than a club in the city, which i'm totally down with.

I am going with 4 as opposed to 5 because I didn't experience anything more than the music.

Maybe next time I'll get a chance to take it the whole shebang.
author: Sean R.

description: Only OK.  Review for this past Fri night bar/club. $5 cover even if it's past 12midnight. I was DD, so I laid off the drinks.. can't review for that. It was a packed night.  About a 5:1 ratio of men:women.  Come here if you want to have 3-4 guys come up n hump you from every direction while on the dance floor.  The guys are definitely aggressive and doesn't understand "down boy".
author: Christi S.

description: like bissap baobab, the food is spectacular (especially the plantains and coconut shrimp thingy).  The Salsa music is DJ - good music.  Great dancers to watch.  friendly atmosphere.
author: rosalyn m.

description:
great music, great drinks, great people! reggae night is extra fun here. 

unknowingly, i also went into baobab on salsa night and it was great. the people were friendly even if you didn't salsa! 

disadvantages: the space is super small and when it gets crowded, it gets pretty musty and humid. but hey, maybe its supposed to mimic an evening in africa?
author: Jeanne F.

description: This place was jumping last Friday night. I've always heard good things about it but never had the chance to go. After braving the cold on the roof top at Medjool and then trying to brave the dance floor we sauntered down the block to Little Baobab and rocked out to great world music till they turned the lights on.  The DJ was great, played soca, dancehall, reggae and some merengue at the end of the night. Unpretentious crowd just looking to dance and party, looking forward to coming back.
author: Jason H.

description: There is nothing i don't love about this place.  Just like the other reviews say, there's a great crowd, amazing music, cheap drinks, and it's just a good time all around.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Cate M.

description: fun, very small and intimate dance club with some great music that gets everyone up and dancing. smiles all around and just an overall great vibe. it gets sweaty and crowded but if you like fun, you won't mind. tasty drinks as well.
author: michella s.

description: This place is soo crowded. I think it took us 20 minutes to make our way to the front of the tiny room. It also took us 40 minutes to get a drink. But awesome music...so if you want to get your dance on, this is the place to be.
author: Preeya J.

description: Hot, Crowded, Loud Music, Fun Drinks and the closest thing to being back in a West African Club I've found in 5 years... Even when the djs can spin worth crap, the music is always fun and I have a GREAT time!
author: Joy C.

description: I went to Bhangra night here and had an awesome time.  Their drinks are interesting, and really decently priced.  The place looks like a wooden shack on the inside, but somehow it works.  The DJ that night was awesome.  Surprisingly, when I looked up, he definitely was NOT Indian.  I'm pretty sure he was white, but man did he rock that bhangra set.
author: Danielle P.

description: They were able to accommodate 8 of us last night for dinner and everything was fantastic--especially the drinks, food, and music. The server was very patient w/us and way cool.  Thanks for giving us a great evening.
author: Dave G.

description:
i love little baobab!!

i love it so much that i pout hardcore when they're closed on sunday's and i've brought my sister here to feast.

i love it so much that i order baobab take-out and sit in my apartment and squeal like a little pig while i chow down on the cari yap.

i love it so much that i recommend it to people who don't even want to hear about it. "what, you looking for a fancy restaurant to take your parents - go to baobab!" "first date? baobab!" "you look hungry, let's go to baobab."
author: Brittany E.

description:
This place blew my fucking mind.  I have been to literally hundreds of spots in the city, and I have never once deemed any spot worthy of the "blew my fucking mind" distinction.  This place earned it on a Monday night.   

Hands down, thee best music I have ever heard in the city.  The DJ was spinning the illest string of eclectic beats that left me wondering where exactly the fuck i was.  It was like some sort of 4th dimension.  

As soon as a buddy and I rolled up to this place I was groovin.  Within 2 seconds I knew I had just found my favorite spot in the city.   

Reggae, hip hop, east indian, african, salsa, caribbean, creole, french, latin music they were dropping it ALL.  On Monday, it wasnt crowded.  There were probably not more than 15 people in there - and everyone was getting DOWN.   Absolutely no pretension at this spot.  Everyone was there to have fun and bust moves like they were dancing in their own living room.  

Drinks were nice, had a very exotic, fruity vibe to them, but not quite strong enough for me.   I'd definitely recommend them for the ladies, however.

Overall, you go to this place for the music.   This vibe is so chill, so comfortable, so unassuming that you can even bring your typically wallflower-esque friends here and even they'll be down to shake their respective tail-feathers.  

Also, a very exotic, beautiful blend of women here.  All types of ladies including, latinas, africanas, indian women, white women, all there to have fun.  

Seriously, this place left me wanting to join the Peace Corps.   I can't think of a more fun experience in the city.  Blew my mind.
author: Nathan D.

description: One of the few places in SF that actually plays good music.  Good as in, not the same club music you hear every single weekend.  If you want a different vibe, check this place out.  Culture, good music, strong (and tasty) drinks.  It's a funky treasure.  And I mean funk in more ways than one.
author: Ames P.

description: This place is CRAZY. It's my favourite dancing spot in the city. It's hot, it's sweaty, it's always jam packed and pumping, and the margaritas and the beats are killer. If you get claustrophobic this is probably not the place for you. One word of warning for my fellow ladies, watch out for the wandering enthusiatic hands. And one more thing... there's only one bathroom so be prepared for a long wait  time.
author: MissSkip Z.

description: this was my home..did a thursday night event here for 2+ years they treated me like fam. The food is great i think i have had everything in the menu by now....drinks are dope....and a very cool spot to find international music..Friday and Saturday get packed...spot is small tho but folks keep rolling in
author: Mwapagha M.

description: Great place to stumble home from after many Happy Hour PITCHERS!!!!  The food is good too.  It is my neighborhood hangout.  OHHH and I love the picture of "Le Futballer"
author: Alex S.

description: Awesome, awesome halibut.  Good and unique (though I wouldn't exactly say mind blowing) drinks.  One of the best spots the Mission has to offer, although the other reviewer's roach story is a bit disturbing.
author: Jon S.

description: Hot men, hot women, tropical drinks, dancy music and smiles on all the faces. Not much more I could ask for.
author: Lisa P.

description: this little spot in the mission is perfect for a low key Monday night dinner.  i went ti the main one but they were closed and a sign said go to the other one around the corner.  When we arrived it just so happened to be happy hour and we had a delicious hibiscus and lime cocktail.  We then ordered the most tender and succulent lamb i had ever tasted. the spices and flavors went well with our fried plantains and avocado stuffed with crab.  This restaurant isn't a corp place either, its ran by real people from Senegal.  Besides them not having soap in the bathroom the place will definitely get another visit
author: byron l.

description:
I went on a Saturday night to dance.  The music was awesome but the DJs need to work on smoothing out the transitions from song to song.  

The crowd --eclectic.  

Really, really, really crowded with the occasional guy "coping a feel."  I danced my ass off all night long.  Great time except for the obnoxious couple who wouldn't stop making out and knocking me around on the dance floor.  The guy was so f---ing oblivious he clocked me in the eye with his elbow while I waited in line for the bathroom and didn't even notice.  (I sure hope he got some).  

Fun and funky  African style.   Not for the faint of heart.   I'll be back.
author: Kimberly d.

description: this was fantastic! i came here with a group of 4, one of them being vegan and we all found feed we loved. the drinks are amazing- fruity, strong but taste like heaven. we got the pitcher of banana margs. the appetizers are to die for- the crab and the hummus are insane. the service was so nice- they gave me samples of things to try since i couldnt decide what to order and the ambiance was dope- lots of hip hop and cool art hung up. cant wait to come back and also try bissap baobab.
author: Emmie B.

description: the most fun!  lots of island boys, some hippies, me... awesome music, sexy, sweaty, unself-consious dancing.
author: Caitlin M.

description: Oh my gawd.... soooo good.  Make a reservation!  We didn't, so we were told to wait 30-45 minutes, but after our sad faces, they decided to try and accomodate us by taking in one of their tiny tables from outside and set 4 chairs around it.  We were fine w/ being cramped... the food made up for it, and it was easier to hear each other's conversations.  We shared the crab/avacado dish (the taste was perfect, but I think the avocado was a little too hard and should have ripened for one more day), lamb salad (I'm not a fan of lamb, although, I did try one bite, and I admit it's the best lamb I've eaten... still wouldn't eat it again though), chicken curry w/ couscous (awesome!), plantains (the sauce that goes w/ it is sweet and tangy... a good addition, but I can happily eat plantains by it's lonesome), and curried shrimp (maybe a little too sweet or coconutty?, but worth a try).  We each had two rounds of our fave drinks (little baobob & hibiscus margarita)... so good & so cheap!  I love it.  And, to top it off, we dug into a warm brownie a la mode.  That night couldn't have gotten better.  The cool guy who sat us even gave us free admittance back in for dancing.  And, my friend commented that our bill entailed we were cheap dates... I'm cool with that.
author: Christine O.

description: I came by here on the insistence of my friend.  Being my attempt at senegalese cuisine, I really had no idea what to expect.  I ended up getting the N'Dole as an entree, while we split the Plaintain appetizer.  The plaintains were quite good, lightly fried on the outside, tender on the inside...how it should be.  The N'Dole on the other hand was pretty mediocre.  It was advertised to be spicy and was not spicy at all.  In fact, I would say the entire entree was on the bland side.  The lamb itself was not particularly tender slices of meat.  On the other hand, my friend got the Cari Yap.  I was able to get one piece of the lamb, which was far more juicy and tender than the lamb in the N'Dole.  I also got a Banana Drop as a cocktail, and the fresh ginger is definitely a nice touch in a cocktail.  Overall, there were some decent things that I would try it again (but not the N'Dole), but I would say I was rather lukewarm about the whole thing.
author: David L.

description: get the dish with shrimp and coconut, and the ginger rum punch with tamarind. this was my first time trying senegalese food, and i'm definitely a convert. the vibe here is hot--i actually think it'd make a great date place. it's right off mission but yet feels cozy and tucked away, like some sort of hidden treasure.
author: Marla W.

description: I don't usually like dance clubs. Too grabby and stupid music for the most part, and I hate having to dress all slutty or risk looking like the old lady. But this place was awesome! The music was fun (even though I didn't know a lot of it) and the crowd was all there pretty much just to have fun, from what I could judge - and I know I had a lot of fun. Cover was cheap ($5) and they have a free water cooler. I hate when clubs charge for water. I was driving so I didn't try their drinks. The missing star is because the decor could use some work and there was pee all over the one tiny bathroom, but really not such a big deal in the big picture. If your goal is low maintenance sweaty dancing fun, check it out!
author: Melissa K.

description: delicious food, homemade coconut rum and ginger beer rock the house!
author: gemma h.

description: i had dinner w/ my friend here last night and then stayed for the music.  it was so much fun!  the atmosphere here during dinner is really chill.  i think bissap baobab is a TAD fancier, b/c you basically sit on folding chairs at little baobab.  my friend and i shared the fried plantains, shrimp kebab and a chicken curry dish which were all tasty.  their drinks are really yummy...get anything w/ hibiscus juice, tamarind or ginger.  you can't go wrong!  wed night was salsa night which was a lot of fun!  everyone seemed to know what they were doing but me and my friend, but people are eager to teach you and dance w/ you.  good times!
author: Helen T.

description: My friend introduced me to this place and it is madmadmadmad fun for such a tiny space. My apartment is larger than the entire club, yet they somehow cram in 60+ people, a DJ booth, coat check, bar and 1stall bathroom into the space without violating fire code. They have a cover ($3 before midnight, $5 afterward--we got there at like 12:15, so they probably would've had 5 stars had we not had to pay the extra--I know so little money, but it's the principal of the thing) but once you're inside, you're treated to some of the most delightful drinks (delightful, that is, if you like your drinks sweet, like House Party 1 kool-aid sweet-holla at me if you know what I mean). $5 got you a strong mix of ginger, tamarind, hibiscus and rum. Great stuff, goes straight to your head. The music is a booty-shaking mix of dance hall and reggaeton.  I definitely had fun and will be back again, this time arriving before midnight.
author: Donna W.

description: This is my favorite place to go dancing in the Bay Area! Friday nights are the best - zouk, soukous and reggae are playing all night long, people (not all) can really dance, and the vibe is so good. If you're missing a hole-in-the-wall type , sweaty dance spot in your life, this is defintely the place for you.
author: sol da liberdade j.

description: props for nice staff, fun ambiance.  anti-props for bad food (much better at Bissap Baobab), somewhat chaotic table-seating process (more or less arbitrary).  will go back for dancing and update review after I see that side of the house
author: James R.

description: we shake, grind, pant, gulp, laugh and then gasp some more. when i go to lil baobab i dont stop, my body is out of my mind's reign. i cannot help but stamp and praise the sound of the drums, reverberating. refresh with hibicus, ginger or tamarind coolers and watch the steam rise off people. i feel like im in a sauna, door opens with a pleasant breeze. we stand in front of the door and dance like maniacs.
author: Ligaya T.

description: spent 4th of July here for a minute waiting for the crowd.  i will be able to give it a proper review when i actually get to shake my nyash with some folks on the dancefloor.  the space is tight but the vibe is definitely african and spare with the emphasis on close but not rude sweaty moves.
author: John S.

description: i'd never thought about senegal long enough to consider whether it had food, but it does...and it's damn good!  it's not the typical ethiopian/eritrean fare we come to expect of african food (more rice, less bread).  fragrant spices, interesting combinations (crab-stuffed avocado?!?), and thick meaty stews.  it all works out and tastes great.  the ambience reminds me a little of some sort of island hut (dark but with bright colors, really small, lots of loud colorful music).
author: Roshni R.

description: Cool place with interesting food. The mixed drinks are great.  I highly recommend this place for dinner.  Afrikan house music is poppin'
author: Mister G.

description: been here before for a birthday dinner followed by a little rump shakin' .  last night i stuck to drinks and food.  half off cocktails until 8pm.  who doesn't love that?  i've had the rose in the past, but last night it was the flamboyant.  it was hibisicus, lime, vodka goodness.  could have used more vodka, but you can't really complain for $2.50.  i've had the mafe in the past and it's been my go to dish, but i wanted to branch out so i got the cofi volaille (sp?).  it was a curry with veggies, potatoes and grilled chicken breast with couscous.  yumtastic!
author: Sharlene C.

description: shake it, work it, like your dinner depended on it.
author: jen b.

description: celebrated my fiance's birthday here and frequented this establishment with some outta town buddies, on separate occassions, and found my experience here to be highly enjoyable. i haven't had the chance to eat there yet, however their late night dance scene is great!!! super music, small intimate space (can be a sweety negative for some, but you just need to remember to take a smoke break every 15, 20 minutes and you're set to get back on the dance floor), and great crowd. drinks are a little on the stiff side, though. and i wouldn't reccomend getting their ginger cocktails (who knows, it might be your steez, just not mine). overall, a hippity-happening joint, minus the hipsters!
author: MrBoomBastic ..

description: We finally tried Little Baobab the other day for dinner. We had a party of 6, which gave us the opportunity to sample most of the menu. We went for the $20 3-course prix fixe menu (served until 7:00pm) which includes appetizer, entre, dessert, and cocktail and is a huge bargain. The appetizers were a little hit-or-miss. The best were the gambas (shrimp), perfectly cooked and served in an intensely flavorful broth accompanied by little pieces of pita bread, and the fried plantains with tamarind sauce. The crab and avocado appetizer was underwhelming (it seemed to be mostly canned tuna with a little bit of crab meat mixed in), and the salads were fine but unexceptional. The entrees were all excellent. I had the salmon and also tried two different lamb dishes (one in a peanut sauce and one in a curry sauce), a chicken dish, a tofu dish, and a shrimp dish. Everything was great but the lamb, and especially the curry lamb, really stood out. Dessert was a little bit of a letdown, as they were out of several items and the only option was a chocolate souffle with vanilla ice cream. The souffle was quite dry but was tasty enough. The cocktails were also a bit hit and miss. I had a "fleur," a strong ginger and whiskey concoction which I quite liked. I sampled a banana drink which was drowned in what seemed like generic margarita mix to the point where you could barely taste the banana. Overall, the food and drinks were very good, if a little uneven, with a few standout dishes. At $20 the overall value was outstanding, and this is what really pushes Little Baobab into 4 star territory. I might even consider rating Little Baobab 5 stars if not for the terrible service. Our waiter was extremely inattentive and impossible to flag down  (or even find- taking a "smoke" break maybe?). In an establishment this small, where there were maybe one or two other parties dining, this was just inexcusable. Despite its flaws, I'd certainly recommend Little Baobab for a casual, bargain-priced dinner or drinks.
author: Brian H.

description: Best Cuban salsa spot in the city (on wednesday nights)... the food is really good too!
author: Patricia M.

description: bring someone who can dance and only come if you can bc if you can't you'll lose youre date to someone who can. (I almost lost mine.)
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: This is hands down my favorite place to dance in SF. But, if you are coming on a Friday or Saturday, you better come early or be ready to sweat up against the next moving body, because everyone wants to come on the weekend. The mix of African, Reggae, Hip Hop, and Middle Eastern tunes are so danceable. The mixed drinks with fresh ginger or hibiscus juices are deeelicious. Come on Wednesdays for the largest Cuban-Salsa gathering in the Bay Area.
author: Lisa B.

description: the food is divine, and the drinks a little taste of heaven. very out of the ordinary
author: Lauren V.

description: small, hot and on great nights it is powerful...the music is fantastic, a place for great memories...
author: Lisa F.

description:
for people who wanna move so hard, african music in the house

i wish you wouldnt have to pay to get in ($5, friday)
author: xo x.

description: i really like it! haven't been here for a long time, and went couple of saturdays ago and had a blast, came back on wednesday and was impressed by the salsa night! love the drinks!! yumm!  love that it is and stays true to its roots, love that it draws african diaspora from all sides of the world, love that it's so international. overall a very, very cool place!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: what a cool place, good dancing, music and vibes.
author: Sebastian J.

description: This place has good food, and has a nice ambiance. Once, there was a belly dance show going on. They have a bar too. The place is crowded, and service can be a little slow. But they have good food, and beer !
author: Kuldeep T.
